.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
down
,
and
let
's
show
you
the
way
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
after
jerking
the
miserable
girl
down
with
a
force
which
made
her
stagger
on
the
pavement
,
she
got
into
the
vehicle
,
and
was
followed
by
her
wretched
companion
.
   
<EOS>
These
two
girls
had
been
thrown
upon
London
streets
,
their
vices
and
debauchery
,
by
a
sordid
and
rapacious
mother
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
younger
girl
was
then
,
the
elder
had
been
once
;
and
what
the
elder
then
was
,
the
younger
must
soon
become
.
 
<EOS>
A
melancholy
prospect
,
but
how
surely
to
be
realised
;
a
tragic
drama
,
but
how
often
acted
!
 
<EOS>
Turn
to
the
prisons
and
police
offices
of
London
---
nay
,
look
into
the
very
streets
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
These
things
pass
before
our
eyes
,
day
after
day
,
and
hour
after
hour
---
they
have
become
such
matters
of
course
,
that
they
are
utterly
disregarded
.
 
<EOS>
The
progress
of
these
girls
in
crime
will
be
as
rapid
as
the
flight
of
a
pestilence
,
resembling
it
too
in
its
baneful
influence
and
wide
-
spreading
infection
.
 
<EOS>
Step
by
step
,
how
many
wretched
females
,
within
the
sphere
of
every
man
's
observation
,
have
become
involved
in
a
career
of
vice
,
frightful
to
contemplate
;
hopeless
at
its
commencement
,
loathsome
and
repulsive
in
its
course
;
friendless
,
forlorn
,
and
unpitied
,
at
its
miserable
conclusion
!
   
<EOS>
There
were
other
prisoners
---
boys
of
ten
,
as
hardened
in
vice
as
men
of
fifty
---
a
houseless
vagrant
,
going
joyfully
to
prison
as
a
place
of
food
and
shelter
,
handcuffed
to
a
man
whose
prospects
were
ruined
,
character
lost
,
and
family
rendered
destitute
,
by
his
first
offence
.
 
<EOS>
Our
curiosity
,
however
,
was
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
group
had
left
an
impression
on
our
mind
we
would
gladly
have
avoided
,
and
would
willingly
have
effaced
.
   
<EOS>
The
crowd
dispersed
;
the
vehicle
rolled
away
with
its
load
of
guilt
and
misfortune
;
and
we
saw
no
more
of
the
Prisoners
'
Van
.
    
TALES
 
<EOS>
The
boarding
-
house
.
<EOS>
Chapter
the
First
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
was
,
beyond
all
dispute
,
the
most
tidy
,
fidgety
,
thrifty
little
personage
that
ever
inhaled
the
smoke
of
London
;
and
the
house
of
Mrs
Tibbs
was
,
decidedly
,
the
neatest
in
all
Great
Coram
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
area
and
the
area
-
steps
,
and
the
street
-
door
and
the
street
-
door
steps
,
and
the
brass
handle
,
and
the
door
-
plate
,
and
the
knocker
,
and
the
fan
-
light
,
were
all
as
clean
and
bright
,
as
indefatigable
white
-
washing
,
and
hearth
-
stoning
,
and
scrubbing
and
rubbing
,
could
make
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
wonder
was
,
that
the
brass
door
-
plate
,
with
the
interesting
inscription
"
MRS
TIBBS
,
"
had
never
caught
fire
from
constant
friction
,
so
perseveringly
was
it
polished
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
meat
-
safe
-
looking
blinds
in
the
parlour
-
windows
,
blue
and
gold
curtains
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
spring
-
roller
blinds
,
as
Mrs
Tibbs
was
wo
nt
in
the
pride
of
her
heart
to
boast
,
"
all
the
way
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
bell
-
lamp
in
the
passage
looked
as
clear
as
a
soap
-
bubble
;
you
could
see
yourself
in
all
the
tables
,
and
French
-
polish
yourself
on
any
one
of
the
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
banisters
were
bees
-
waxed
;
and
the
very
stair
-
wires
made
your
eyes
wink
,
they
were
so
glittering
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
was
somewhat
short
of
stature
,
and
Mr
Tibbs
was
by
no
means
a
large
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
,
moreover
,
very
short
legs
,
but
,
by
way
of
indemnification
,
his
face
was
peculiarly
long
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
his
wife
what
the
0
is
in
90
<EOS>
---
he
was
of
some
importance
WITH
her
---
he
was
nothing
without
her
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
was
always
talking
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tibbs
rarely
spoke
;
but
,
if
it
were
at
any
time
possible
to
put
in
a
word
,
when
he
should
have
said
nothing
at
all
,
he
had
that
talent
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
detested
long
stories
,
and
Mr
Tibbs
had
one
,
the
conclusion
of
which
had
never
been
heard
by
his
most
intimate
friends
.
 
<EOS>
It
always
began
,
"
I
recollect
when
I
was
in
the
volunteer
corps
,
in
eighteen
hundred
and
six
,
"
---
<EOS>
but
,
as
he
spoke
very
slowly
and
softly
,
and
his
better
half
very
quickly
and
loudly
,
he
rarely
got
beyond
the
introductory
sentence
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
melancholy
specimen
of
the
story
-
teller
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
wandering
Jew
of
Joe
Millerism
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tibbs
enjoyed
a
small
independence
from
the
pension
-
list
---
about
43L.
<EOS>
15S.
10D.
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
,
mother
,
and
five
interesting
scions
from
the
same
stock
,
drew
a
like
sum
from
the
revenue
of
a
grateful
country
,
though
for
what
particular
service
was
never
known
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
this
said
independence
was
not
quite
sufficient
to
furnish
two
people
with
ALL
the
luxuries
of
this
life
,
it
had
occurred
to
the
busy
little
spouse
of
Tibbs
,
that
the
best
thing
she
could
do
with
a
legacy
of
700L.
,
would
be
to
take
and
furnish
a
tolerable
house
---
somewhere
in
that
partially
-
explored
tract
of
country
which
lies
between
the
British
Museum
,
and
a
remote
village
called
Somers
-
town
---
for
the
reception
of
boarders
.
 
<EOS>
Great
Coram
-
street
was
the
spot
pitched
upon
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
had
been
furnished
accordingly
;
two
female
servants
and
a
boy
engaged
;
and
an
advertisement
inserted
in
the
morning
papers
,
informing
the
public
that
"
Six
individuals
would
meet
with
all
the
comforts
of
a
cheerful
musical
home
in
a
select
private
family
,
residing
within
ten
minutes
'
walk
of
"
---
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
Answers
out
of
number
were
received
,
with
all
sorts
of
initials
;
all
the
letters
of
the
alphabet
seemed
to
be
seized
with
a
sudden
wish
to
go
out
boarding
and
lodging
;
voluminous
was
the
correspondence
between
Mrs
Tibbs
and
the
applicants
;
and
most
profound
was
the
secrecy
observed
.
 
<EOS>
"
E
"
did
n't
like
this
;
"
I
"
could
n't
think
of
putting
up
with
that
;
"
I*O*U^
"
did
n't
think
the
terms
would
suit
him
;
and
"
G*R
"
had
never
slept
in
a
French
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
,
however
,
was
,
that
three
gentlemen
became
inmates
of
Mrs
Tibbs
's
house
,
on
terms
which
were
"
agreeable
to
all
parties
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
went
the
advertisement
again
,
and
a
lady
with
her
two
daughters
,
proposed
to
increase
---
not
their
families
,
but
Mrs
Tibbs
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
woman
,
that
Mrs
Maplesone
!
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
as
she
and
her
spouse
were
sitting
by
the
fire
after
breakfast
;
the
gentlemen
having
gone
out
on
their
several
avocations
.
 
<EOS>
"
Charming
woman
,
indeed
!
"
repeated
little
Mrs
Tibbs
,
more
by
way
of
soliloquy
than
anything
else
,
for
she
never
thought
of
consulting
her
husband
.
"
<EOS>
And
the
two
daughters
are
delightful
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
some
fish
to
-
day
;
they
'll
join
us
at
dinner
for
the
first
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tibbs
placed
the
poker
at
right
angles
with
the
fire
shovel
,
and
essayed
to
speak
,
but
recollected
he
had
nothing
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
,
"
continued
Mrs
T
,
"
have
kindly
volunteered
to
bring
their
own
piano
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs
thought
of
the
volunteer
story
,
but
did
not
venture
it
.
   
<EOS>
A
bright
thought
struck
him
---
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
likely
---
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
lean
your
head
against
the
paper
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Tibbs
;
"
and
do
n't
put
your
feet
on
the
steel
fender
;
that
's
worse
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs
took
his
head
from
the
paper
,
and
his
feet
from
the
fender
,
and
proceeded
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
likely
one
of
the
young
ladies
may
set
her
cap
at
young
Mr
Simpson
,
and
you
know
a
marriage
---
"
   
"
A
what
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
Mrs
Tibbs
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
modestly
repeated
his
former
suggestion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
you
wo
n't
mention
such
a
thing
,
"
said
Mrs
T.
 
<EOS>
"
A
marriage
,
indeed
to
rob
me
of
my
boarders
---
no
,
not
for
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs
thought
in
his
own
mind
that
the
event
was
by
no
means
unlikely
,
but
,
as
he
never
argued
with
his
wife
,
he
put
a
stop
to
the
dialogue
,
by
observing
it
was
"
time
to
go
to
business
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
always
went
out
at
ten
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
and
returned
at
five
in
the
afternoon
,
with
an
exceedingly
dirty
face
,
and
smelling
mouldy
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
knew
what
he
was
,
or
where
he
went
;
but
Mrs
Tibbs
used
to
say
with
an
air
of
great
importance
,
that
he
was
engaged
in
the
City
.
   
<EOS>
The
Miss
Maplesones
and
their
accomplished
parent
arrived
in
the
course
of
the
afternoon
in
a
hackney
-
coach
,
and
accompanied
by
a
most
astonishing
number
of
packages
.
 
<EOS>
Trunks
,
bonnet
-
boxes
,
muff
-
boxes
and
parasols
,
guitar
-
cases
,
and
parcels
of
all
imaginable
shapes
,
done
up
in
brown
paper
,
and
fastened
with
pins
,
filled
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
there
was
such
a
running
up
and
down
with
the
luggage
,
such
scampering
for
warm
water
for
the
ladies
to
wash
in
,
and
such
a
bustle
,
and
confusion
,
and
heating
of
servants
,
and
curling
-
irons
,
as
had
never
been
known
in
Great
Coram
-
street
before
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Mrs
Tibbs
was
quite
in
her
element
,
bustling
about
,
talking
incessantly
,
and
distributing
towels
and
soap
,
like
a
head
nurse
in
a
hospital
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
was
not
restored
to
its
usual
state
of
quiet
repose
,
until
the
ladies
were
safely
shut
up
in
their
respective
bedrooms
,
engaged
in
the
important
occupation
of
dressing
for
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
these
gals
'
andsome
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Simpson
of
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
,
another
of
the
boarders
,
as
they
were
amusing
themselves
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
before
dinner
,
by
lolling
on
sofas
,
and
contemplating
their
pumps
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
,
who
was
a
tallish
,
white
-
faced
young
man
,
with
spectacles
,
and
a
black
ribbon
round
his
neck
instead
of
a
neckerchief
---
a
most
interesting
person
;
a
poetical
walker
of
the
hospitals
,
and
a
"
very
talented
young
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
fond
of
"
lugging
"
into
conversation
all
sorts
of
quotations
from
Don
Juan
,
without
fettering
himself
by
the
propriety
of
their
application
;
in
which
particular
he
was
remarkably
independent
.
<EOS>
The
other
,
Mr
Simpson
,
was
one
of
those
young
men
,
who
are
in
society
what
walking
gentlemen
are
on
the
stage
,
only
infinitely
worse
skilled
in
his
vocation
than
the
most
indifferent
artist
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
empty
-
headed
as
the
great
bell
of
St
Paul
's
;
always
dressed
according
to
the
caricatures
published
in
the
monthly
fashion
;
and
spelt
Character
with
a
K^.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
a
devilish
number
of
parcels
in
the
passage
when
I
came
home
,
"
simpered
Mr
Simpson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Materials
for
the
toilet
,
no
doubt
,
"
rejoined
the
Don
Juan
reader
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
Much
linen
,
lace
,
and
several
pair
Of
stockings
,
slippers
,
brushes
,
combs
,
complete
;
With
other
articles
of
ladies
fair
,
To
keep
them
beautiful
,
or
leave
them
neat
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
from
Milton
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Simpson
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
from
Byron
,
"
returned
Mr
Hicks
,
with
a
look
of
contempt
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
sure
of
his
author
,
because
he
had
never
read
any
other
.
"
<EOS>
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Here
come
the
gals
,
"
and
they
both
commenced
talking
in
a
very
loud
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Maplesone
and
the
Miss
Maplesones
,
Mr
Hicks
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Hicks
---
Mrs
Maplesone
and
the
Miss
Maplesones
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
with
a
very
red
face
,
for
she
had
been
superintending
the
cooking
operations
below
stairs
,
and
looked
like
a
wax
doll
on
a
sunny
day
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
,
I
beg
your
pardon
---
Mr
Simpson
---
Mrs
Maplesone
and
the
Miss
Maplesones
"
---
and
\
vice
versa
\.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
immediately
began
to
slide
about
with
much
politeness
,
and
to
look
as
if
they
wished
their
arms
had
been
legs
,
so
little
<EOS>
did
they
know
what
to
do
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
smiled
,
curtseyed
,
and
glided
into
chairs
,
and
dived
for
dropped
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
:
 
<EOS>
the
gentlemen
leant
against
two
of
the
curtain
-
pegs
;
Mrs
Tibbs
went
through
an
admirable
bit
of
serious
pantomime
with
a
servant
who
had
come
up
to
ask
some
question
about
the
fish
-
sauce
;
and
then
the
two
young
ladies
looked
at
each
other
;
and
everybody
else
appeared
to
discover
something
very
attractive
in
the
pattern
of
the
fender
.
   
<EOS>
"
Julia
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mrs
Maplesone
to
her
youngest
daughter
,
in
a
tone
loud
enough
for
the
remainder
of
the
company
to
hear
---
"
Julia
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Ma
.
"
   
"
Do
n't
stoop
.
"
<EOS>
---
This
was
said
for
the
purpose
of
directing
general
attention
to
Miss
Julia
's
figure
,
which
was
undeniable
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
looked
at
her
,
accordingly
,
and
there
was
another
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
had
the
most
uncivil
hackney
-
coachman
to
-
day
,
you
can
imagine
,
"
said
Mrs
Maplesone
to
Mrs
Tibbs
,
in
a
confidential
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
replied
the
hostess
,
with
an
air
of
great
commiseration
.
<EOS>
She
could
n't
say
more
,
for
the
servant
again
appeared
at
the
door
,
and
commenced
telegraphing
most
earnestly
to
her
"
Missis
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
hackney
-
coachmen
generally
ARE
uncivil
,
"
said
Mr
Hicks
in
his
most
insinuating
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Positively
I
think
they
are
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maplesone
,
as
if
the
idea
had
never
struck
her
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
cabmen
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Simpson
.
 
<EOS>
This
remark
was
a
failure
,
for
no
one
intimated
,
by
word
or
sign
,
the
slightest
knowledge
of
the
manners
and
customs
of
cabmen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Robinson
,
what
DO
you
want
?
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
to
the
servant
,
who
,
by
way
of
making
her
presence
known
to
her
mistress
,
had
been
giving
sundry
hems
and
sniffs
outside
the
door
during
the
preceding
five
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Please
,
ma'am
,
master
wants
his
clean
things
,
"
replied
the
servant
,
taken
off
her
guard
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
young
men
turned
their
faces
to
the
window
,
and
"
went
off
"
like
a
couple
of
bottles
of
ginger
-
beer
;
the
ladies
put
their
handkerchiefs
to
their
mouths
;
and
little
Mrs
Tibbs
bustled
out
of
the
room
to
give
Tibbs
his
clean
linen
,
---
and
the
servant
warning
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Calton
,
the
remaining
boarder
,
shortly
afterwards
made
his
appearance
,
and
proved
a
surprising
promoter
of
the
conversation
.
<EOS>
Mr
Calton
was
a
superannuated
beau
---
an
old
boy
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
to
say
of
himself
that
although
his
features
were
not
regularly
handsome
,
they
were
striking
.
 
<EOS>
They
certainly
were
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
look
at
his
face
without
being
reminded
of
a
chubby
street
-
door
knocker
,
half
-
lion
half
-
monkey
;
and
the
comparison
might
be
extended
to
his
whole
character
and
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
stood
still
,
while
everything
else
had
been
moving
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
originated
a
conversation
,
or
started
an
idea
;
but
if
any
commonplace
topic
were
broached
,
or
,
to
pursue
the
comparison
,
if
anybody
LIFTED
HIM
UP
,
he
would
hammer
away
with
surprising
rapidity
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
tic
-
douloureux
occasionally
,
and
then
he
might
be
said
to
be
muffled
,
because
he
did
not
make
quite
as
much
noise
as
at
other
times
,
when
he
would
go
on
prosing
,
rat
-
tat
-
tat
the
same
thing
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
been
married
;
but
he
was
still
on
the
look
-
out
for
a
wife
with
money
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
life
interest
worth
about
300L.
a
year
---
he
was
exceedingly
vain
,
and
inordinately
selfish
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
acquired
the
reputation
of
being
the
very
pink
of
politeness
,
and
he
walked
round
the
park
,
and
up
Regent
-
street
,
every
day
.
   
<EOS>
This
respectable
personage
had
made
up
his
mind
to
render
himself
exceedingly
agreeable
to
Mrs
Maplesone
---
indeed
,
the
desire
of
being
as
amiable
as
possible
extended
itself
to
the
whole
party
;
Mrs
Tibbs
having
considered
it
an
admirable
little
bit
of
management
to
represent
to
the
gentlemen
that
she
had
SOME
reason
to
believe
the
ladies
were
fortunes
,
and
to
hint
to
the
ladies
,
that
all
the
gentlemen
were
"
eligible
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
little
flirtation
,
she
thought
,
might
keep
her
house
full
,
without
leading
to
any
other
result
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Maplesone
was
an
enterprising
widow
of
about
fifty
:
 
shrewd
,
scheming
,
and
good
-
looking
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
amiably
anxious
on
behalf
of
her
daughters
;
in
proof
whereof
she
used
to
remark
,
that
she
would
have
no
objection
to
marry
again
,
if
it
would
benefit
her
dear
girls
---
she
could
have
no
other
motive
.
 
<EOS>
The
"
dear
girls
"
themselves
were
not
at
all
insensible
to
the
merits
of
"
a
good
establishment
.
"
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
was
twenty
-
five
;
the
other
,
three
years
younger
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
at
different
watering
-
places
,
for
four
seasons
;
they
had
gambled
at
libraries
,
read
books
in
balconies
,
sold
at
fancy
fairs
,
danced
at
assemblies
,
talked
sentiment
---
in
short
,
they
had
done
all
that
industrious
girls
could
do
---
but
,
as
yet
,
to
no
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
magnificent
dresser
Mr
Simpson
is
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Matilda
Maplesone
to
her
sister
Julia
.
   
<EOS>
"
Splendid
!
"
returned
the
youngest
.
 
<EOS>
The
magnificent
individual
alluded
to
wore
a
maroon
-
coloured
dress
-
coat
,
with
a
velvet
collar
and
cuffs
of
the
same
tint
---
very
like
that
which
usually
invests
the
form
of
the
distinguished
unknown
who
condescends
to
play
the
"
swell
"
in
the
pantomime
at
"
Richardson
's
Show
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
whiskers
!
"
said
Miss
Julia
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
!
"
responded
her
sister
;
"
and
what
hair
!
"
 
<EOS>
His
hair
was
like
a
wig
,
and
distinguished
by
that
insinuating
wave
which
graces
the
shining
locks
of
those
CHEF
-
D'OEUVRES
of
art
surmounting
the
waxen
images
in
Bartellot
's
window
in
Regent
-
street
;
his
whiskers
meeting
beneath
his
chin
,
seemed
strings
wherewith
to
tie
it
on
,
ere
science
had
rendered
them
unnecessary
by
her
patent
invisible
springs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dinner
's
on
the
table
,
ma'am
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
the
boy
,
who
now
appeared
for
the
first
time
,
in
a
revived
black
coat
of
his
master
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Calton
,
will
you
lead
Mrs
Maplesone
?
---
Thank
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
offered
his
arm
to
Miss
Julia
;
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
escorted
the
lovely
Matilda
;
and
the
procession
proceeded
to
the
dining
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tibbs
was
introduced
,
and
Mr
Tibbs
bobbed
up
and
down
to
the
three
ladies
like
a
figure
in
a
Dutch
clock
,
with
a
powerful
spring
in
the
middle
of
his
body
,
and
then
dived
rapidly
into
his
seat
at
the
bottom
of
the
table
,
delighted
to
screen
himself
behind
a
soup
-
tureen
,
which
he
could
just
see
over
,
and
that
was
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
boarders
were
seated
,
a
lady
and
gentleman
alternately
,
like
the
layers
of
bread
and
meat
in
a
plate
of
sandwiches
;
and
then
Mrs
Tibbs
directed
James
to
take
off
the
covers
.
 
<EOS>
Salmon
,
lobster
-
sauce
,
giblet
-
soup
,
and
the
usual
accompaniments
were
discovered
:
potatoes
like
petrifactions
,
and
bits
of
toasted
bread
,
the
shape
and
size
of
blank
dice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Soup
for
Mrs
Maplesone
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
bustling
Mrs
Tibbs
.
<EOS>
She
always
called
her
husband
"
my
dear
"
before
company
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
,
who
had
been
eating
his
bread
,
and
calculating
how
long
it
would
be
before
he
should
get
any
fish
,
helped
the
soup
in
a
hurry
,
made
a
small
island
on
the
table
-
cloth
,
and
put
his
glass
upon
it
,
to
hide
it
from
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Julia
,
shall
I
assist
you
to
some
fish
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
---
very
little
---
oh
!
plenty
,
thank
you
"
(
a
bit
about
the
size
of
a
walnut
put
upon
the
plate
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Julia
is
a
VERY
little
eater
,
"
said
Mrs
Maplesone
to
Mr
Calton
.
   
<EOS>
The
knocker
gave
a
single
rap
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
busy
eating
the
fish
with
his
eyes
:
 
<EOS>
so
he
only
ejaculated
,
"
Ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
to
her
spouse
after
every
one
else
had
been
helped
,
"
what
do
YOU
take
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
inquiry
was
accompanied
with
a
look
intimating
that
he
must
n't
say
fish
,
because
there
was
not
much
left
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
thought
the
frown
referred
to
the
island
on
the
table
-
cloth
;
he
therefore
coolly
replied
,
"
Why
---
I
'll
take
a
little
---
fish
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
fish
,
my
dear
?
"
<EOS>
(
another
frown
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
dear
,
"
replied
the
villain
,
with
an
expression
of
acute
hunger
depicted
in
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
The
tears
almost
started
to
Mrs
Tibbs
's

,
as
she
helped
her
"
wretch
of
a
husband
,
"
as
she
inwardly
called
him
,
to
the
last
eatable
bit

.
   
<EOS>
"
James
,
take
this
to
your
master
,
and
take

's

.
"
 
<EOS>
This
was

,
as
Tibbs
never
could
eat
fish
without
one
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
however
,
constrained
to
chase
small

of

round
and
round
his

with
a

and
a

,
<EOS>
the
number
of
successful

being
about
one
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
away
,
James
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
as

swallowed
the
fourth

---
and

the

like

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
a
bit
of
bread
,
James
,
"
said
the
poor
"
master
of
the
house
,
"
more

than

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never

your

now
,
James
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
"
see
about
the

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
conveyed
in
the
tone
in
which
ladies
usually
give

to
servants
in
company
,
that
is
to
say
,
a

;
but

,
like

,
from

,

.
   
<EOS>
A

,
before

---

Mr
Simpson

Mr

,

Mr

,

,

,
and
took
wine
with

---

.
 
<EOS>
No
one
ever
thought
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
Between

fish
and
an

,

.
   
<EOS>
Here

an

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
He

---
   
"
<EOS>
But
beef
is
rare
within

;
Goats
'
flesh
there

,
no

,
and
kid
,

,
And

upon

,
A
joint
upon

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

,
"
to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tom
Moore

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
mine
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Look

,
"
resumed

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

sure
,
"
said
Simpson
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
at
Don
Juan
,
"

Mr
Septimus
Hicks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Julia
's

,
"

Miss

.
   
<EOS>
"
Can

grander

Fire

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Or

and

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
or
Paradise
and
the
Peer
,
"
repeated
Simpson
,
who
thought
he
was
getting

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

Mr

Hicks
,
who
,
as
we

before
hinted
,
never

anything
but
Don

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where

anything

the

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Talking
of

,
"
said
Tibbs
,
with

---
"
when

,

,

;

,

,
says

,
Tibbs
(

)
,
Tibbs
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tell

,
James
,
"

,
in

,
"

if
he
<EOS>
WON'T
carve

,
to

.
"
 
<EOS>
The
discomfited

instantly

,
and
carved

almost

as

wife

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

ever
finished
the
story
is
not
known
<EOS>
but
,
if
he
did
,
nobody
heard

.
   
<EOS>
As
the
ice
was
now
broken
,
and
the
new
inmates
more
at
home
,
every
member
of
the
company
felt
more

.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
himself
most
certainly
did
,
because
he
went
to
sleep
immediately
after
dinner
.
<EOS>
Mr
Hicks
and
the
ladies
discoursed
most
eloquently
about
poetry
,
and
the
theatres
,
and
Lord
Chesterfield
's
Letters
;
and
Mr
Calton
followed
up
what
everybody
said
,
with
continuous
double
knocks
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
highly
approved
of
every
observation
that
fell
from
Mrs
Maplesone
;
and
as
Mr
Simpson
sat
with
a
smile
upon

face
and
said
"
Yes
,
"
or
"
Certainly
,
"
at
intervals
of
about
four
minutes
each
,
he
received
full
credit
for
understanding
what
was
going
forward
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
rejoined
the
ladies
in
the
drawing
-
room
very

after

had
left
the

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Maplesone
and
Mr
Calton
played
cribbage
,
and
the
"
young
people
"
amused
themselves
with
music
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
Miss
Maplesones
sang
the
most
fascinating
duets
,
and
accompanied
themselves
on

,
ornamented
with
bits
of

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
put
on
a
pink

,
and
said
he
was
in

;
and
Mr
Hicks
felt
in
the
seventh
heaven
of
poetry
or
the
seventh
canto
of
Don
Juan
---
it
was

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
was
quite
charmed
with
the
newcomers
;
and
Mr
Tibbs
spent
the
evening
in
his
usual
way
<EOS>
---
he
went
to
sleep
,
and
woke
up
,
and
went
to
sleep
again
,
and
woke
at
supper
-

.
   
<EOS>
We
are
not
about
to

-

,
and
to
let
"
years
roll

;
"
but

requesting

reader
to
suppose
that
six
months
have

,
since
the

we
have
described
,
and
that
Mrs
Tibbs
's
boarders
have
,
during
that

,

,

,

,

,
as

,

,

.
<EOS>
And
we
will

,
the
period

mentioned

,
to

,
that
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
received
,
in

(
a

)
,

,

,

,
in

(
Calton
's
)

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
Mr
Calton
<EOS>
I
'll
come
down

,
"
said
Mr
Septimus
to

boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
---

Mr
Calton
unwell
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

,
as

-

-

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
as

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Please
,

,

rum
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very

:
 
I
'll
be

.
"
 
<EOS>
Downstairs
ran
the
boy
with
the

,
and
down

the
excited
Hicks
himself
,
almost

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tap
,
tap
.
"
<EOS>
"
Come
in
.
"
<EOS>
---
Door
opens
,
and

Mr
Calton
sitting
in

.
 
<EOS>
Mutual

of
the
hand
exchanged
,
and
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
motioned
to

seat
.
 
<EOS>
A

pause
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Hicks
coughed
,
and
Mr
Calton
took
a
pinch
of
snuff
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
interviews
where
neither
party
knows
what
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
broke
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
received
a
note
---
"
he
said
,
very

,
in
a

like
a
Punch

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
you
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
this
dialogue
must
have
been
satisfactory
,
both
gentlemen
felt
there
was
something
more
important
to

;
therefore

did
as

in

would

---
they
looked
at

table
with
a
determined

.
 
<EOS>
The
conversation
had
been
opened
,
however
,
and
Mr
Calton
had
made
up
his
mind
to
continue

with
a
regular

.
 
<EOS>
He
always
spoke
very
pompously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hicks
,
"
said

,
"
I
have

,
in

of
certain

which

this

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
marriage
!
"
<EOS>

,
compared
with
whose

of
countenance
,
Hamlet
's
,
when
he
sees

's

,
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
With
a

,
"
returned

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
sent
for
you
to
prove
the
great
confidence
I
can

in
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
will

me
?
"
<EOS>
eagerly

,
who
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

YOU
!
 
<EOS>
Wo

ME
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
:
 
no
one
shall
know
,
to

,

,
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
People

know

,

---

,

,
"

,
with
an

.
<EOS>
"
We
MAY

a

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
WE
!
---
<EOS>
That
wo
n't
affect
you
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
devil
it
wo
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
how
can

?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
Calton
was
too
much
inwrapped
in
the

of
his
happiness
to
see
the
equivoque
between
Hicks
and
himself
;
and
threw

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Matilda
!
"
sighed
the
antique
beau
,
in

-
a
-
daisical
voice
,
and
applying
his
right
hand
a
little
to

left
of
the
fourth
button
of
his

,
counting
from
the
bottom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Matilda
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
Matilda
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Hicks
,
starting
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Matilda
Maplesone
,
"
responded

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

-

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

:
 
<EOS>
"
I

her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

Matilda
Maplesone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Matilda
Maplesone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
MISS
Maplesone
marry

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Maplesone
!
 
<EOS>
No
;
Mrs
Maplesone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
said
Hicks
,
falling
into

:
 
<EOS>
"
You
marry
the
mother
,
and
I
the
daughter
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most

!
"

,
"

;

,

owing
to
Matilda

,

does

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
One

<EOS>
There
's
Simpson
<EOS>
---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
he

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
looked
up

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

?
'
<EOS>
Tis
---
'
<EOS>

's
---
<EOS>
fixed

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

:
 
<EOS>
"
but
,

,

,
for

<EOS>
I

,
is

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

she
wo

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

MY

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
A

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Tibbs
;
it
could
be
no
one
else
;
for
no
one
else
occupied
five
minutes
in
rubbing

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
out
to
pay

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tibbs
,
"
called
Mr
Calton
in
a

,
looking
over

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
replied
he
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

-
door
was
carefully

,
and
Tibbs
,

(
as

)
,

with

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

,
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs

,

deuce

could

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

resumed
;
"
I

,
Mr

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs

,
as

Mr
H
's

-

;

Lor
!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

,
<EOS>

---

---
that

of

married
to
-
morrow

.
"
 
<EOS>
And

,
several

,

.
   
<EOS>
If

---

,

---

,

"
Just

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>

its

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

I

!
 
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

---
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
No
;
<EOS>

,
"

"

"

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
No

;

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>

Why

,

"

;
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
the
Byron
-

;
"
Simpson
marries
Julia
Maplesone
to
-
morrow
morning
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Tibbs
,
thoroughly
satisfied
,
"
of
course
he
does
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
would
require
the
pencil
of
Hogarth
to
illustrate
---
our
feeble
pen
is
inadequate
to
describe
---
the
expression
which
the
countenances
of
Mr
Calton
and
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
respectively
assumed
,
at
this
unexpected
announcement
.
 
<EOS>
Equally
impossible
is
it
to
describe
,
although
perhaps
it
is
easier
for
our
lady
readers
to
imagine
,
what
arts
the
three
ladies
could
have
used
,
so
completely
to
entangle
their
separate
partners
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
they
were
,
however
,
they
were
successful
.
 
<EOS>
The
mother
was
perfectly
aware
of
the
intended
marriage
of
both
daughters
;
and
the
young
ladies
were
equally
acquainted
with
the
intention
of
their
estimable
parent
.
<EOS>
They
agreed
,
however
,
that
it
would
have
a
much
better
appearance
if
each
feigned
ignorance
of
the
other
's
engagement
;
and
it
was
equally
desirable
that
all
the
marriages
should
take
place
on
the
same
day
,
to
prevent
the
discovery
of
one
clandestine
alliance
,
operating
prejudicially
on
the
others
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
,
the
mystification
of
Mr
Calton
and
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
,
and
the
pre
-
engagement
of
the
unwary
Tibbs
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
,
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
was
united
to
Miss
Matilda
Maplesone
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
also
entered
into
a
"
holy
alliance
"
with
Miss
Julia
;
Tibbs
acting
as
father
,
"
his
first
appearance
in
that
character
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Calton
,
not
being
quite
so
eager
as
the
two
young
men
,
was
rather
struck
by
the
double
discovery
;
and
as
he
had
found
some
difficulty
in
getting
any
one
to
give
the
lady
away
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
the
best
mode
of
obviating
the
inconvenience
would
be
not
to
take
her
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
,
however
,
"
appealed
,
"
as
her
counsel
said
on
the
trial
of
the
cause
,
MAPLESONE
v
CALTON
,
for
a
breach
of
promise
,
"
with
a
broken
heart
,
to
the
outraged
laws
of
her
country
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
recovered
damages
to
the
amount
of
1,000L.
which
the
unfortunate
knocker
was
compelled
to
pay
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Septimus
Hicks
having
walked
the
hospitals
,
took
it
into
his
head
to
walk
off
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
His
injured
wife
is
at
present
residing
with
her
mother
at
Boulogne
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
,
having
the
misfortune
to
lose
his
wife
six
weeks
after
marriage
(
by
her
eloping
with
an
officer
during
his
temporary
sojourn
in
the
Fleet
Prison
,
in
consequence
of
his
inability
to
discharge
her
little
mantua
-
maker
's
bill
)
,
and
being
disinherited
by
his
father
,
who
died
soon
afterwards
,
was
fortunate
enough
to
obtain
a
permanent
engagement
at
a
fashionable
haircutter
's
;
hairdressing
being
a
science
to
which
he
had
frequently
directed
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
situation
he
had
necessarily
many
opportunities
of
making
himself
acquainted
with
the
habits
,
and
style
of
thinking
,
of
the
exclusive
portion
of
the
nobility
of
this
kingdom
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
fortunate
circumstance
are
we
indebted
for
the
production
of
those
brilliant
efforts
of
genius
,
his
fashionable
novels
,
which
so
long
as
good
taste
,
unsullied
by
exaggeration
,
ca
nt
,
and
quackery
,
continues
to
exist
,
can
not
fail
to
instruct
and
amuse
the
thinking
portion
of
the
community
.
   
<EOS>
It
only
remains
to
add
,
that
this
complication
of
disorders
completely
deprived
poor
Mrs
Tibbs
of
all
her
inmates
,
except
the
one
whom
she
could
have
best
spared
---
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
That
wretched
little
man
returned
home
,
on
the
day
of
the
wedding
,
in
a
state
of
partial
intoxication
;
and
,
under
the
influence
of
wine
,
excitement
,
and
despair
,
actually
dared
to
brave
the
anger
of
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Since
that
ill
-
fated
hour
he
has
constantly
taken
his
meals
in
the
kitchen
,
to
which
apartment
,
it
is
understood
,
his
witticisms
will
be
in
future
confined
:
 
a
turn
-
up
bedstead
having
been
conveyed
there
by
Mrs
Tibbs
's
order
for
his
exclusive
accommodation
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
he
will
be
enabled
to
finish
,
in
that
seclusion
,
his
story
of
the
volunteers
.
   
<EOS>
The
advertisement
has
again
appeared
in
the
morning
papers
.
<EOS>
Results
must
be
reserved
for
another
chapter
.
 
<EOS>
Chapter
the
Second
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
said
little
Mrs
Tibbs
to
herself
,
as
she
sat
in
the
front
parlour
of
the
Coram
-
street
mansion
one
morning
,
mending
a
piece
of
stair
-
carpet
off
the
first
Landings
;
---
"
Things
have
not
turned
out
so
badly
,
either
,
and
if
I
only
get
a
favourable
answer
to
the
advertisement
,
we
shall
be
full
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
resumed
her
occupation
of
making
worsted
lattice
-
work
in
the
carpet
,
anxiously
listening
to
the
twopenny
postman
,
who
was
hammering
his
way
down
the
street
,
at
the
rate
of
a
penny
a
knock
.
<EOS>
The
house
was
as
quiet
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
low
sound
to
be
heard
---
it
was
the
unhappy
Tibbs
cleaning
the
gentlemen
's
boots
in
the
back
kitchen
,
and
accompanying
himself
with
a
buzzing
noise
,
in
wretched
mockery
of
humming
a
tune
.
   
<EOS>
The
postman
drew
near
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
---
so
did
Mrs
Tibbs
.
 
<EOS>
A
knock
---
a
bustle
---
a
letter
---
post
-
paid
.
   
<EOS>
"
T*I
presents
compt
.
<EOS>
to
I*T%
and
T*I
begs
<EOS>
To
say
that
i
see
the
advertisement
<EOS>
And
she
will
Do
Herself
the
pleasure
of
calling
On
you
at
12
o'clock
to
-
morrow
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
T*I
as
To
apologise
to
I*T%
for
the
shortness
Of
the
notice
<EOS>
But
i
hope
it
will
not
unconvenience
you
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
remain
yours
<EOS>
Truly
   
"
Wednesday
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Mrs
Tibbs
perused
the
document
,
over
and
over
again
;
and
the
more
she
read
it
,
the
more
was
she
confused
by
the
mixture
of
the
first
and
third
person
;
the
substitution
of
the
"
i
"
for
the
"
T*I
;
"
and
the
transition
from
the
"
I*T%
"
to
the
"
You
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
writing
looked
like
a
skein
of
thread
in
a
tangle
,
and
the
note
was
ingeniously
folded
into
a
perfect
square
,
with
the
direction
squeezed
up
into
the
right
-
hand
corner
,
as
if
it
were
ashamed
of
itself
.
 
<EOS>
The
back
of
the
epistle
was
pleasingly
ornamented
with
a
large
red
wafer
,
which
,
with
the
addition
of
divers
ink
-
stains
,
bore
a
marvellous
resemblance
to
a
black
beetle
trodden
upon
.
 
<EOS>
One
thing
,
however
,
was
perfectly
clear
to
the
perplexed
Mrs
Tibbs
.
<EOS>
Somebody
was
to
call
at
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
The
drawing
-
room
was
forthwith
dusted
for
the
third
time
that
morning
;
three
or
four
chairs
were
pulled
out
of
their
places
,
and
a
corresponding
number
of
books
carefully
upset
,
in
order
that
there
might
be
a
due
absence
of
formality
.
 
<EOS>
Down
went
the
piece
of
stair
-
carpet
before
noticed
,
and
up
ran
Mrs
Tibbs
"
to
make
herself
tidy
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
clock
of
New
Saint
Pancras
Church
struck
twelve
,
and
the
Foundling
,
with
laudable
politeness
,
did
the
same
ten
minutes
afterwards
,
Saint
something
else
struck
the
quarter
,
and
then
there
arrived
a
single
lady
with
a
double
knock
,
in
a
pelisse
<EOS>
the
colour
of
the
interior
of
a
damson
pie
;
a
bonnet
of
the
same
,
with
a
regular
conservatory
of
artificial
flowers
;
a
white
veil
,
and
a
green
parasol
,
with
a
cobweb
border
.
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
(
who
was
very
fat
and
red
-
faced
)
was
shown
into
the
drawing
-
room
;
Mrs
Tibbs
presented
herself
,
and
the
negotiation
commenced
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
called
in
consequence
of
an
advertisement
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
in
a
voice
as
if
she
had
been
playing
a
set
of
Pan
's
pipes
for
a
fortnight
without
leaving
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
rubbing
her
hands
very
slowly
,
and
looking
the
applicant
full
in
the
face
---
<EOS>
two
things
she
always
did
on
such
occasions
.
   
<EOS>
"
Money
is
n't
no
object
<EOS>
whatever
to
me
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
so
much
as
living
in
a
state
of
retirement
and
obtrusion
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
acquiesced
in
such
an
exceedingly
natural
desire
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
constantly
attended
by
a
medical
man
,
"
resumed
the
pelisse
wearer
;
"
I
have
been
a
shocking
unitarian
for
some
time
---
<EOS>
I
,
indeed
,
have
had
very
little
peace
since
the
death
of
Mr
Bloss
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
looked
at
the
relict
of
the
departed
Bloss
,
and
thought
he
must
have
had
very
little
peace
in
his
time
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
she
could
not
say
so
;
so
she
looked
very
sympathising
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
a
good
deal
of
trouble
to
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
;
"
but
,
for
that
trouble
I
am
willing
to
pay
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
through
a
course
of
treatment
which
renders
attention
necessary
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
one
mutton
-
chop
in
bed
at
half
-
past
eight
,
and
another
at
ten
,
every
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
,
as
in
duty
bound
,
expressed
the
pity
she
felt
for
anybody
placed
in
such
a
distressing
situation
;
and
the
carnivorous
Mrs
Bloss
proceeded
to
arrange
the
various
preliminaries
with
wonderful
despatch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
mind
,
"
said
that
lady
,
after
terms
were
arranged
;
"
I
am
to
have
the
second
-
floor
front
,
for
my
bed
-
room
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
'll
find
room
for
my
little
servant
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
can
have
one
of
the
cellars
in
the
area
for
my

porter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
greatest
pleasure
;
---
James
shall
get
it
ready
for
you
by
Saturday
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
'll
join
the
company
at
the
breakfast

table
on
Sunday
morning
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
get
up
on
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
returned
Mrs
Tibbs
,
in
her
most
amiable
tone
;
for
satisfactory
references
had
"
been
given
and
required
,
"
and
it
was
quite
certain
that
the
new
-
comer
had
plenty
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
rather
singular
,
"
continued
Mrs
Tibbs
,
with
what
was
meant
for
a
most

,
"
that
we
have
a
gentleman
now
with
us
,
who
is
in
a

state
of
health
---
a
Mr
Gobler
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
His
apartment
is
the
back

-
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
next
room
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mrs
Bloss
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
next
room
,
"
repeated
the
hostess
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
very
promiscuous
!
"
ejaculated
the
widow
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
hardly
ever
gets
up
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
"
cried
Mrs
Bloss
,
in
an
equally
low
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
he
is
up
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
"
we
never
can
persuade
him
to
go
to
bed
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
the
astonished
Mrs
Bloss
,
drawing
her
chair
nearer
Mrs
Tibbs
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
his
complaint
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
fact
is
,
"
replied
Mrs
Tibbs
,
with
a
most
communicative
air
,
"
he
has
no
stomach
whatever
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
what
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs
Bloss
,
with
a
look
of
the
most
indescribable

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
stomach
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Tibbs
,
with
a
shake
of
the
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
us
!
<EOS>
what
an
extraordinary
case
!
"
gasped
Mrs
Bloss
,
as
if
she
understood
the
communication
in
its
literal
sense
,
and
was
astonished
at
a
gentleman
without
a
stomach
finding
it
necessary
to
board
anywhere
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
say
he
has
no
stomach
,
"
explained
the
chatty
little
Mrs
Tibbs
,
"
I
mean
that
his
digestion
is
so
much
impaired
,
and
his
interior
so
deranged
,
that
his
stomach
is
not
of
the
least
use
to
him
;
---
in
fact
,
it
's
an
inconvenience
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
heard
such
a
case
in
my
life
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
's
worse
than
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
replied
Mrs
Tibbs
;
---
"
certainly
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
said
this
with
great
confidence
,
for
the
damson
pelisse
suggested
that
Mrs
Bloss
,
at
all
events
,
was
not
suffering
under
Mr
Gobler
's
complaint
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
quite
incited
my
curiosity
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
as
she
rose
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
I
long
to
see
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
generally
comes
down
,
once
a
week
,
"
replied
Mrs
Tibbs
;
"
I
dare
say
you
'll
see
him
on
Sunday
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
consolatory
promise
Mrs
Bloss
was
obliged
to
be
contented
.
 
<EOS>
She
accordingly
walked
slowly
down
the
stairs
,
detailing
her
complaints
all
the
way
;
and
Mrs
Tibbs
followed
her
,
uttering
an
exclamation
of
compassion
at
every
step
.
 
<EOS>
James
(
who
looked
very
gritty
,
for
he
was
cleaning
the
knives
)
fell
up
the
kitchen
-
stairs
,
and
opened
the
street
-
door
;
and
,
after
mutual
farewells
,
Mrs
Bloss
slowly
departed
,
down
the
shady
side
of
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
almost
superfluous
to
say
,
that
the
lady
whom
we
have
just
shown
out
at
the
street
-
door
(
and
whom
the
two
female
servants
are
now
inspecting
from
the
second
-
floor
windows
)
was
exceedingly
vulgar
,
ignorant
,
and
selfish
.
 
<EOS>
Her
deceased
better
-
half
had
been
an
eminent
cork
-
cutter
,
in
which
capacity
he
had
amassed
a
decent
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
relative
but
his
nephew
,
and
no
friend
but
his
cook
.
 
<EOS>
The
former
had
the
insolence
one
morning
to
ask
for
the
loan
of
fifteen
pounds
;
and
,
by
way
of
retaliation
,
he
married
the
latter
next
day
;
he
made
a
will
immediately
afterwards
,
containing
a
burst
of
honest
indignation
against
his
nephew
(
who
supported
himself
and
two
sisters
on
100L.
a
year
)
,
and
a
bequest
of
his
whole
property
to
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
ill
after
breakfast
,
and
died
after
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
mantelpiece
-
looking
tablet
in
a
civic
parish
church
,
setting
forth
his
virtues
,
and
deploring
his
loss
.
<EOS>
He
never
dishonoured
a
bill
,
or
gave
away
a
halfpenny
.
   
<EOS>
The
relict
and
sole
executrix
of
this
noble
-
minded
man
was
an
odd
mixture
of
shrewdness
and
simplicity
,
liberality
and
meanness
.
<EOS>
Bred
up
as
she
had
been
,
she
knew
no
mode
of
living
so
agreeable
as
a
boarding
-
house
:
 
and
having
nothing
to
do
,
and
nothing
to
wish
for
<EOS>
,
she
naturally
imagined
she
must
be
ill
---
an
impression
which
was
most
assiduously
promoted
by
her
medical
attendant
,
Dr
Wosky
,
and
her
handmaid
Agnes
:
 
both
of
whom
,
doubtless
for
good
reasons
,
encouraged
all
her
extravagant
notions
.
   
<EOS>
Since
the
catastrophe
recorded
in
the
last
chapter
,
Mrs
Tibbs
had
been
very
shy
of
young
-
lady
boarders
.
 
<EOS>
Her
present
inmates
were
all
lords
of
the
creation
,
and
she
availed
herself
of
the
opportunity
of
their
assemblage
at
the
dinner
-
table
,
to
announce
the
expected
arrival
of
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
received
the
communication
with
stoical
indifference
,
and
Mrs
Tibbs
devoted
all
her
energies
to
prepare
for
the
reception
of
the
valetudinarian
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
-
floor
front
was
scrubbed
,
and
washed
,
and
flannelled
,
till
the
wet
went
through
to
the
drawing
-
room
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
Clean
white
counterpanes
,
and
curtains
,
and
napkins
,
water
-
bottles
as
clear
as
crystal
,
blue
jugs
,
and
mahogany
furniture
,
added
to
the
splendour
,
and
increased
the
comfort
,
of
the
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
The
warming
-
pan
was
in
constant
requisition
,
and
a
fire
lighted
in
the
room
every
day
.
<EOS>
The
chattels
of
Mrs
Bloss
were
forwarded
by
instalments
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
there
came
a
large
hamper
of
Guinness
's
stout
,
and
an
umbrella
;
then
,
a
train
of
trunks
;
then
,
a
pair
of
clogs
and
a
bandbox
;
then
,
an
easy
chair
with
an
air
-
cushion
;
then
,
a
variety
of
suspicious
-
looking
packages
;
and
---
"
though
last
not
least
"
---
Mrs
Bloss
and
Agnes
:
 
the
latter
in
a
cherry
-
coloured
merino
dress
,
open
-
work
stockings
,
and
shoes
with
sandals
:
 
like
a
disguised
Columbine
.
   
<EOS>
The
installation
of
the
Duke
of
Wellington
,
as
Chancellor
of
the
University
of
Oxford
,
was
nothing
,
in
point
of
bustle
and
turmoil
,
to
the
installation
of
Mrs
Bloss
in
her
new
quarters
.
 
<EOS>
True
,
there
was
no
bright
doctor
of
civil
law
to
deliver
a
classical
address
on
the
occasion
;
but
there
were
several
other
old
women
present
,
who
spoke
quite
as
much
to
the
purpose
,
and
understood
themselves
equally
well
.
 
<EOS>
The
chop
-
eater
was
so
fatigued
with
the
process
of
removal
that
she
declined
leaving
her
room
until
the
following
morning
;
so
a
mutton
-
chop
,
pickle
,
a
pill
,
a
pint
bottle
of
stout
,
and
other
medicines
,
were
carried
up
-
stairs
for
her
consumption
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
DO
you
think
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
inquisitive
Agnes
of
her
mistress
,
after
they
had
been
in
the
house
some
three
hours
;
"
what
DO
you
think
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
the
lady
of
the
house
is
married
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Married
!
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
taking
the
pill
and
a
draught
of
Guinness
---
"
married
!
 
<EOS>
Unpossible
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
indeed
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
the
Columbine
;
"
and
her
husband
,
ma'am
,
lives
---
<EOS>
he
---
<EOS>
he
---
<EOS>
he
---
lives
in
the
kitchen
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
kitchen
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
:
 
<EOS>
and
he
---
<EOS>
he
---
<EOS>
he
---
the
housemaid
says
,
he
never
goes
into
the
parlour
except
on
Sundays
;
and
that
Ms.
Tibbs
makes
him
clean
the
gentlemen
's
boots
;
and
that
he
cleans
the
windows
,
too
,
sometimes
;
and
that
one
morning
early
,
when
he
was
in
the
front
balcony
cleaning
the
drawing
-
room
windows
,
he
called
out
to
a
gentleman
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
who
used
to
live
here
---
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Calton
,
<EOS>
sir
,
how
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
"
 
Here
the
attendant
laughed
till
Mrs
Bloss
was
in
serious
apprehension
of
her
chuckling
herself
into
a
fit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
never
!
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
please
,
ma'am
,
the
servants
gives
him
gin
-
and
-
water
sometimes
;
and
then
he
cries
,
and
says
he
hates
his
wife
and
the
boarders
,
and
wants
to
tickle
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tickle
the
boarders
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Bloss
,
seriously
alarmed
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
ma'am
,
not
<EOS>
the
boarders
,
the
servants
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
that
all
!
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
quite
satisfied
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
wanted
to
kiss
me
as
I
came
up
the
kitchen
-
stairs
,
just
now
,
"
said
Agnes
,
indignantly
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
gave
it
him
---
a
little
wretch
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
intelligence
was
but
too
true
.
 
<EOS>
A
long
course
of
snubbing
and
neglect
;
his
days
spent
in
the
kitchen
,
and
his
nights
in
the
turn
-
up
bedstead
,
had
completely
broken
the
little
spirit
that
the
unfortunate
volunteer
had
ever
possessed
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
one
to
whom
he
could
detail
his
injuries
but
the
servants
,
and
they
were
almost
of
necessity
his
chosen
confidants
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
no
less
strange
than
true
,
however
,
that
the
little
weaknesses
which
he
had
incurred
,
most
probably
during
his
military
career
,
seemed
to
increase
as
his
comforts
diminished
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
actually
a
sort
of
journeyman
Giovanni
of
the
basement
story
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
morning
,
being
Sunday
,
breakfast
was
laid
in
the
front
parlour
at
ten
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Nine
was
the
usual
time
,
but
the
family
always
breakfasted
an
hour
later
on
sabbath
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
enrobed
himself
in
his
Sunday
costume
---
a
black
coat
,
and
exceedingly
short
,
thin
trousers
;
with
a
very
large
white
waistcoat
,
white
stockings
and
cravat
,
and
Blucher
boots
---
and
mounted
to
the
parlour
aforesaid
.
<EOS>
Nobody
had
come
down
,
and
he
amused
himself
by
drinking
the
contents
of
the
milkpot
with
a
teaspoon
.
   
<EOS>
A
pair
of
slippers
were
heard
descending
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
flew
to
a
chair
;
and
a
stern
-
looking
man
,
of
about
fifty
,
with
very
little
hair
on
his
head
,
and
a
Sunday
paper
in
his
hand
,
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
Mr
Evenson
,
"
said
Tibbs
,
very
humbly
,
with
something
between
a
nod
and
a
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Tibbs
?
<EOS>
"
replied
he
of
the
slippers
,
as
he
sat
himself
down
,
and
began
to
read
his
paper
without
saying
another
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Wisbottle
in
town
to
-
day
,
do
you
know
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tibbs
,
just
for
the
sake
of
saying
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
he
was
,
"
replied
the
stern
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
whistling
"
The
Light
Guitar
,
"
in
the
next
room
to
mine
,
at
five
o'clock
this
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
very
fond
of
whistling
,
"
said
Tibbs
,
with
a
slight
smirk
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
I
ai
n't
,
"
was
the
laconic
reply
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
John
Evenson
was
in
the
receipt
of
an
independent
income
,
arising
chiefly
from
various
houses
he
owned
in
the
different
suburbs
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
morose
and
discontented
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
thorough
radical
,
and
used
to
attend
a
great
variety
of
public
meetings
,
for
the
express
purpose
of
finding
fault
with
everything
that
was
proposed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wisbottle
,
on
the
other
hand
,
was
a
high
Tory
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
clerk
in
the
Woods
and
Forests
Office
,
which
he
considered
rather
an
aristocratic
employment
;
he
knew
the
peerage
by
heart
,
and
,
could
tell
you
,
off
-
hand
,
where
any
illustrious
personage
lived
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
good
set
of
teeth
,
and
a
capital
tailor
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Evenson
looked
on
all
these
qualifications
with
profound
contempt
;
and
the
consequence
was
that
the
two
were
always
disputing
,
much
to
the
edification
of
the
rest
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
should
be
added
,
that
,
in
addition
to
his
partiality
for
whistling
,
Mr
Wisbottle
had
a
great
idea
of
his
singing
powers
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
other
boarders
,
besides
the
gentleman
in
the
back
drawing
-
room
---
Mr
Alfred
Tomkins
and
Mr
Frederick
O'Bleary
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tomkins
was
a
clerk
in
a
wine
-
house
;
he
was
a
connoisseur
in
paintings
,
and
had
a
wonderful
eye
for
the
picturesque
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
O'Bleary
was
an
Irishman
,
recently
imported
;
he
was
in
a
perfectly
wild
state
;
and
had
come
over
to
England
to
be
an
apothecary
,
a
clerk
in
a
government
office
,
an
actor
,
a
reporter
,
or
anything
else
that
turned
up
---
he
was
not
particular
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
familiar
terms
with
two
small
Irish
members
,
and
got
franks
for
everybody
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
convinced
that
his
intrinsic
merits
must
procure
him
a
high
destiny
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
shepherd's
-
plaid
inexpressibles
,
and
used
to
look
under
all
the
ladies
'
bonnets
as
he
walked
along
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
His
manners
and
appearance
reminded
one
of
Orson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
comes
Mr
Wisbottle
,
"
said
Tibbs
;
and
Mr
Wisbottle
forthwith
appeared
in
blue
slippers
,
and
a
shawl
dressing
-
gown
,
whistling
"
DI
PIACER
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
sir
,
"
said
Tibbs
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
almost
the
only
thing
he
ever
said
to
anybody
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
Tibbs
?
"
<EOS>
condescendingly
replied
the
amateur
;
and
he
walked
to
the
window
,
and
whistled
louder
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
air
,
that
!
"
said
Evenson
,
with
a
snarl
,
and
without
taking
his
eyes
off
the
paper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Glad
you
like
it
,
"
replied
Wisbottle
,
highly
gratified
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
it
would
sound
better
,
if
you
whistled
it
a
little
louder
?
"
inquired
the
mastiff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
I
do
n't
think
it
would
,
"
rejoined
the
unconscious
Wisbottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
Wisbottle
,
"
said
Evenson
,
who
had
been
bottling
up
his
anger
for
some
hours
---
"
<EOS>
the
next
time
you
feel
disposed
to
whistle
"
The
Light
Guitar
"
at
five
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
I
'll
trouble
you
to
whistle
it
with
your
head
out
o
'
window
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
,
I
'll
learn
the
triangle
---
<EOS>
I
will
,
by
---
"
   
The
entrance
of
Mrs
Tibbs
(
with
the
keys
in
a
little
basket
)
<EOS>
interrupted
the
threat
,
and
prevented
its
conclusion
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
apologised
for
being
down
rather
late
;
the
bell
was
rung
;
James
brought
up
the
urn
,
and
received
an
unlimited
order
for
dry
toast
and
bacon
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
sat
down
at
the
bottom
of
the
table
,
and
began
eating
water
-
cresses
like
a
Nebuchadnezzar
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
O'Bleary
appeared
,
and
Mr
Alfred
Tomkins
.
 
<EOS>
The
compliments
of
the
morning
were
exchanged
,
and
the
tea
was
made
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Tomkins
,
who
had
been
looking
out
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
<EOS>
---
Wisbottle
---
pray
come
here
---
make
haste
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wisbottle
started
from
the
table
,
and
every
one
looked
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
,
"
said
the
connoisseur
,
placing
Wisbottle
in
the
right
position
---
"
a
little
more
this
way
:
 
there
---
<EOS>
do
you
see
how
splendidly
the
light
falls
upon
the
left
side
of
that
broken
chimney
-
pot
at
No
.
48
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
,
"
replied
Wisbottle
,
in
a
tone
of
admiration
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
an
object
stand
out
so
beautifully
against
the
clear
sky
in
my
life
,
"
ejaculated
Alfred
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
(
except
John
Evenson
)
echoed
the
sentiment
;
for
Mr
Tomkins
had
a
great
character
for
finding
out
beauties
which
no
one
else
could
discover
---
he
certainly
deserved
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
frequently
observed
a
chimney
-
pot
in
College
-
green
,
Dublin
,
which
has
a
much
better
effect
,
"
said
the
patriotic
O'Bleary
,
who
never
allowed
Ireland
to
be
outdone
on
any
point
.
   
<EOS>
The
assertion
was
received
with
obvious
incredulity
,
for
Mr
Tomkins
declared
that
no
other
chimney
-
pot
in
the
United
Kingdom
,
broken
or
unbroken
,
could
be
so
beautiful
as
the
one
at
No
.
48
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
-
door
was
suddenly
thrown
open
,
and
Agnes
appeared
,
leading
in
Mrs
Bloss
,
who
was
dressed
in
a
geranium
-
coloured
muslin
gown
,
and
displayed
a
gold
watch
of
huge
dimensions
;
a
chain
to
match
;
and
a
splendid
assortment
of
rings
,
with
enormous
stones
.
 
<EOS>
A
general
rush
was
made
for
a
chair
,
and
a
regular
introduction
took
place
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
John
Evenson
made
a
slight
inclination
of
the
head
;
Mr
Frederick
O'Bleary
,
Mr
Alfred
Tomkins
,
and
Mr
Wisbottle
,
bowed
like
the
mandarins
in
a
grocer
's
shop
;
Tibbs
rubbed
hands
,
and
went
round
in
circles
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
observed
to
close
one
eye
,
and
to
assume
a
clock
-
work
sort
of
expression
with
the
other
;
this
has
been
considered
as
a
wink
,
and
it
has
been
reported
that
Agnes
was
its
object
.
 
<EOS>
We
repel
the
calumny
,
and
challenge
contradiction
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
inquired
after
Mrs
Bloss
's
health
in
a
low
tone
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bloss
,
with
a
supreme
contempt
for
the
memory
of
Lindley
Murray
,
answered
the
various
questions
in
a
most
satisfactory
manner
;
and
a
pause
ensued
,
during
which
the
eatables
disappeared
with
awful
rapidity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
been
very
much
pleased
with
the
appearance
of
the
ladies
going
to
the
Drawing
-
room
the
other
day
,
Mr
O'Bleary
?
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
hoping
to
start
a
topic
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Orson
,
with
a
mouthful
of
toast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
saw
anything
like
it
before
,
I
suppose
?
"
suggested
Wisbottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
---
except
the
Lord
Lieutenant
's
levees
,
"
replied
O'Bleary
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
at
all
equal
to
our
drawing
-
rooms
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
infinitely
superior
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gad
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
the
aristocratic
Wisbottle
,
"
the
Dowager
Marchioness
of
Publiccash
was
most
magnificently
dressed
,
and
so
was
the
Baron
Slappenbachenhausen
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
he
presented
on
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Evenson
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
his
arrival
in
England
.
"
   
"
I
thought
so
,
"
growled
the
radical
;
"
you
never
hear
of
these
fellows
being
presented
on
their
going
away
again
.
 
<EOS>
They
know
better
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
somebody
pervades
them
with
an
apintment
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
joining
in
the
conversation
in
a
faint
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Wisbottle
,
evading
the
point
,
"
it
's
a
splendid
sight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
did
it
never
occur
to
you
,
"
inquired
the
radical
,
who
never
would
be
quiet
;
"
did
it
never
occur
to
you
,
that
you
pay
for
these
precious
ornaments
of
society
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
certainly
HAS
occurred
to
me
,
"
said
Wisbottle
,
who
thought
this
answer
was
a
poser
;
"
it
HAS
occurred
to
me
,
and
I
am
willing
to
pay
for
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
it
has
occurred
to
me
too
,
"
replied
John
Evenson
,
"
and
I
ai
n't
willing
to
pay
for
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Then
why
should
I
?
<EOS>
---
I
say
,
why
should
I
?
"
<EOS>
continued
the
politician
,
laying
down
the
paper
,
and
knocking
his
knuckles
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
are
two
great
principles
---
demand
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
A
cup
of
tea
if
you
please
,
dear
,
"
interrupted
Tibbs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
supply
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
trouble
you
to
hand
this
tea
to
Mr
Tibbs
?
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
interrupting
the
argument
,
and
unconsciously
illustrating
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
thread
of
the
orator
's
discourse
was
broken
.
 
<EOS>
He
drank
his
tea
and
resumed
the
paper
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
very
fine
,
"
said
Mr
Alfred
Tomkins
,
addressing
the
company
in
general
,
"
I
shall
ride
down
to
Richmond
to
-
day
,
and
come
back
by
the
steamer
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
some
splendid
effects
of
light
and
shade
on
the
Thames
;
the
contrast
between
the
blueness
of
the
sky
and
the
yellow
water
is
frequently
exceedingly
beautiful
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wisbottle
hummed
,
"
Flow
on
,
thou
shining
river
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
some
splendid
steam
-
vessels
in
Ireland
,
"
said
O'Bleary
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
delighted
to
find
a
subject
broached
in
which
she
could
take
part
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
accommodations
are
extraordinary
,
"
said
O'Bleary
.
   
<EOS>
"
Extraordinary
indeed
,
"
returned
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
Mr
Bloss
was
alive
,
he
was
promiscuously
obligated
to
go
to
Ireland
on
business
.
<EOS>
I
went
with
him
,
and
raly
the
manner
in
which
the
ladies
and
gentlemen
were
accommodated
with
berths
,
is
not
creditable
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tibbs
,
who
had
been
listening
to
the
dialogue
,
looked
aghast
,
and
evinced
a
strong
inclination
to
ask
a
question
,
but
was
checked
by
a
look
from
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wisbottle
laughed
,
and
said
Tomkins
had
made
a
pun
;
and
Tomkins
laughed
too
,
and
said
he
had
not
.
   
<EOS>
The
remainder
of
the
meal
passed
off
as
breakfasts
usually
do
.
<EOS>
Conversation
flagged
,
and
people
played
with
their
teaspoons
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
looked
out
at
the
window
;
walked
about
the
room
;
and
,
when
they
got
near
the
door
,
dropped
off
one
by
one
.
 
<EOS>
Tibbs
retired
to
the
back
parlour
by
his
wife
's
orders
,
to
check
the
green
-
grocer
's
weekly
account
;
and
ultimately
Mrs
Tibbs
and
Mrs
Bloss
were
left
alone
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
"
said
the
latter
,
"
I
feel
alarmingly
faint
;
it
's
very
singular
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
It
certainly
was
,
for
she
had
eaten
four
pounds
of
solids
that
morning
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
By
-
the
-
bye
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
"
I
have
not
seen
Mr
What's
-
his
-
name
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Gobler
?
"
suggested
Mrs
Tibbs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
"
he
is
a
most
mysterious
person
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
his
meals
regularly
sent
up
-
stairs
,
and
sometimes
do
n't
leave
his
room
for
weeks
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
seen
or
heard
nothing
of
him
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Bloss
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
you
'll
hear
him
to
-
night
,
"
replied
Mrs
Tibbs
;
"
he
generally
groans
a
good
deal
on
Sunday
evenings
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
felt
such
an
interest
in
any
one
in
my
life
,
"
ejaculated
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
double
-
knock
interrupted
the
conversation
;
Dr
Wosky
was
announced
,
and
duly
shown
in
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
man
with
a
red
face
---
dressed
of
course
in
black
,
with
a
stiff
white
neckerchief
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
very
good
practice
,
and
plenty
of
money
,
which
he
had
amassed
by
invariably
humouring
the
worst
fancies
of
all
the
females
of
all
the
families
he
had
ever
been
introduced
into
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
offered
to
retire
,
but
was
entreated
to
stay
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
and
how
are
we
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wosky
,
in
a
soothing
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
ill
,
doctor
---
very
ill
,
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
in
a
whisper
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
we
must
take
care
of
ourselves
;
---
we
must
,
indeed
,
"
said
the
obsequious
Wosky
,
as
he
felt
the
pulse
of
his
interesting
patient
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
our
appetite
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bloss
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
friend
requires
great
care
,
"
said
Wosky
,
appealing
to
Mrs
Tibbs
,
who
of
course
assented
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
however
,
with
the
blessing
of
Providence
,
that
we
shall
be
enabled
to
make
her
quite
stout
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
wondered
in
her
own
mind
what
the
patient
would
be
when
she
was
made
quite
stout
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
take
stimulants
,
"
said
the
cunning
Wosky
---
"
plenty
of
nourishment
,
and
,
above
all
,
we
must
keep
our
nerves
quiet
;
we
positively
must
not
give
way
to
our
sensibilities
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
take
all
we
can
get
,
"
concluded
the
doctor
,
as
he
pocketed
his
fee
,
"
and
we
must
keep
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
man
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Bloss
,
as
the
doctor
stepped
into
the
carriage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
creature
indeed
---
quite
a
lady
's
man
!
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
and
Dr
Wosky
rattled
away
to
make
fresh
gulls
of
delicate
females
,
and
pocket
fresh
fees
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
had
occasion
,
in
a
former
paper
,
to
describe
a
dinner
at
Mrs
Tibbs
's
;
and
as
one
meal
went
off
very
like
another
on
all
ordinary
occasions
;
we
will
not
fatigue
our
readers
by
entering
into
any
other
detailed
account
of
the
domestic
economy
of
the
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
therefore
proceed
to
events
,
merely
premising
that
the
mysterious
tenant
of
the
back
drawing
-
room
was
a
lazy
,
selfish
hypochondriac
;
always
complaining
and
never
ill
.
 
<EOS>
As
his
character
in
many
respects
closely
assimilated
to
that
of
Mrs
Bloss
,
a
very
warm
friendship
soon
sprung
up
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
tall
,
thin
,
and
pale
;
he
always
fancied
he
had
a
severe
pain
somewhere
or
other
,
and
his
face
invariably
wore
a
pinched
,
screwed
-
up
expression
;
he
looked
,
indeed
,
like
a
man
who
had
got
his
feet
in
a
tub
of
exceedingly
hot
water
,
against
his
will
.
   
<EOS>
For
two
or
three
months
after
Mrs
Bloss
's
first
appearance
in
Coram
-
street
,
John
Evenson
was
observed
to
become
,
every
day
,
more
sarcastic
and
more
ill
-
natured
;
and
there
was
a
degree
of
additional
importance
in
his
manner
,
which
clearly
showed
that
he
fancied
he
had
discovered
something
,
which
he
only
wanted
a
proper
opportunity
of
divulging
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
it
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
One
evening
,
the
different
inmates
of
the
house
were
assembled
in
the
drawing
-
room
engaged
in
their
ordinary
occupations
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gobler
and
Mrs
Bloss
were
sitting
at
a
small
card
-
table
near
the
centre
window
,
playing
cribbage
;
Mr
Wisbottle
was
describing
semicircles
on
the
music
-
stool
,
turning
over
the
leaves
of
a
book
on
the
piano
,
and
humming
most
melodiously
;
Alfred
Tomkins
was
sitting
at
the
round
table
,
with
his
elbows
duly
squared
,
making
a
pencil
sketch
of
a
head
considerably
larger
than
his
own
;
O'Bleary
was
reading
Horace
,
and
trying
to
look
as
if
he
understood
it
;
and
John
Evenson
had
drawn
his
chair
close
to
Mrs
Tibbs
's
work
-
table
,
and
was
talking
to
her
very
earnestly
in
a
low
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
assure
you
,
Mrs
Tibbs
,
"
said
the
radical
,
laying
his
forefinger
on
the
muslin
she
was
at
work
on
;
"
I
can
assure
you
,
Mrs
Tibbs
,
that
nothing
but
the
interest
I
take
in
your
welfare
would
induce
me
to
make
this
communication
.
 
<EOS>
I
repeat
,
I
fear
Wisbottle
is
endeavouring
to
gain
the
affections
of
that
young
woman
,
Agnes
,
and
that
he
is
in
the
habit
of
meeting
her
in
the
store
-
room
on
the
first
floor
,
over
the
leads
.
 
<EOS>
From
my
bedroom
I
distinctly
heard
voices
there
,
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
my
door
immediately
,
and
crept
very
softly
on
to
the
landing
;
there
I
saw
Mr
Tibbs
,
who
,
it
seems
,
had
been
disturbed
also
.
<EOS>
---
Bless
me
,
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
,
you
change
colour
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
---
it
's
nothing
,
"
returned
Mrs
T
in
a
hurried
manner
;
"
it
's
only
the
heat
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
flush
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mrs
Bloss
from
the
card
-
table
;
"
that
's
good
for
four
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
thought
it
was
Mr
Wisbottle
,
"
said
Mrs
Tibbs
,
after
a
pause
,
"
he
should
leave
this
house
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
!
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
I
thought
,
"
continued
the
hostess
with
a
most
threatening
air
,
"
if
I
thought
he
was
assisted
by
Mr
Tibbs
---
"
   
"
One
for
his
nob
!
"
said
Gobler
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
Evenson
,
in
a
most
soothing
tone
---
he
liked
to
make
mischief
---
<EOS>
"
I
should
hope
Mr
Tibbs
was
not
in
any
way
implicated
.
<EOS>
He
always
appeared
to
me
very
harmless
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
generally
found
him
so
,
"
sobbed
poor
little
Mrs
Tibbs
;
crying
like
a
watering
-
pot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
hush
!
<EOS>
pray
---
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
---
consider
---
we
shall
be
observed
---
<EOS>
pray
,
do
n't
!
"
said
John
Evenson
,
fearing
his
whole
plan
would
be
interrupted
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
set
the
matter
at
rest
with
the
utmost
care
,
and
I
shall
be
most
happy
to
assist
you
in
doing
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
murmured
her
thanks
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
think
every
one
has
retired
to
rest
to
-
night
,
"
said
Evenson
very
pompously
,
"
if
you
'll
meet
me
without
a
light
,
just
outside
my
bedroom
door
,
by
the
staircase
window
<EOS>
,
I
think
we
can
ascertain
who
the
parties
really
are
,
and
you
will
afterwards
be
enabled
to
proceed
as
you
think
proper
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
was
easily
persuaded
;
her
curiosity
was
excited
,
her
jealousy
was
roused
,
and
the
arrangement
was
forthwith
made
.
 
<EOS>
She
resumed
her
work
,
and
John
Evenson
walked
up
and
down
the
room
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
looking
as
if
nothing
had
happened
.
 
<EOS>
The
game
of
cribbage
was
over
,
and
conversation
began
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
O'Bleary
,
"
said
the
humming
-
top
,
turning
round
on
his
pivot
,
and
facing
the
company
,
"
what
did
you
think
of
Vauxhall
the
other
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
very
fair
,
"
replied
Orson
,
who
had
been
enthusiastically
delighted
with
the
whole
exhibition
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
saw
anything
like
that
Captain
Ross
's
set
-
out
---
eh
?
"
   
"
No
,
"
returned
the
patriot
,
with
his
usual
reservation
---
"
except
in
Dublin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
the
Count
de
Canky
and
Captain
Fitzthompson
in
the
Gardens
,
"
said
Wisbottle
;
"
they
appeared
much
delighted
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
it
MUST
be
beautiful
,
"
snarled
Evenson
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
the
white
bears
is
partickerlerly
well
done
,
"
suggested
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
their
shaggy
white
coats
,
they
look
just
like
Polar
bears
---
<EOS>
do
n't
you
think
they
do
,
Mr
Evenson
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
they
look
a
great
deal
more
like
omnibus
cads
on
all
fours
,
"
replied
the
discontented
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
the
whole
,
I
should
have
liked
our
evening
very
well
,
"
gasped
Gobler
;
"
only
I
caught
a
desperate
cold
which
increased
my
pain
dreadfully
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
have
several
shower
-
baths
,
before
I
could
leave
my
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
things
those
shower
-
baths
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wisbottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Excellent
!
"
said
Tomkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
!
"
<EOS>
chimed
in
O'Bleary
.
 
<EOS>
(
He
had
once
seen
one
,
outside
a
tinman
's
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Disgusting
machines
!
"
rejoined
Evenson
,
who
extended
his
dislike
to
almost
every
created
object
,
masculine
,
feminine
,
or
neuter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Disgusting
,
Mr
Evenson
!
"
said
Gobler
,
in
a
tone
of
strong
indignation
.
<EOS>
---
"
Disgusting
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
their
utility
---
consider
how
many
lives
they
have
saved
by
promoting
perspiration
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Promoting
perspiration
,
indeed
,
"
growled
John
Evenson
,
stopping
short
in
his
walk
across
the
large
squares
in
the
pattern
of
the
carpet
---
<EOS>
"
I
was
ass
enough
to
be
persuaded
some
time
ago
to
have
one
in
my
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
'
Gad
,
I
was
in
it
once
,
and
it
effectually
cured
ME
,
for
the
mere
sight
of
it
<EOS>
threw
me
into
a
profuse
perspiration
for
six
months
afterwards
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
titter
followed
this
announcement
,
and
before
it
had
subsided
James
brought
up
"
the
tray
,
"
containing
the
remains
of
a
leg
of
lamb
which
had
made
its
DEBUT
at
dinner
;
bread
;
cheese
;
an
atom
of
butter
in
a
forest
of
parsley
;
one
pickled
walnut
and
the
third
of
another
;
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
disappeared
,
and
returned
again
with
another
tray
,
containing
glasses
and
jugs
of
hot
and
cold
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
brought
in
their
spirit
-
bottles
;
the
housemaid
placed
divers
plated
bedroom
candlesticks
under
the
card
-
table
;
and
the
servants
retired
for
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
Chairs
were
drawn
round
the
table
,
and
the
conversation
proceeded
in
the
customary
manner
.
 
<EOS>
John
Evenson
,
who
never
ate
supper
,
lolled
on
the
sofa
,
and
amused
himself
by
contradicting
everybody
.
<EOS>
O'Bleary
ate
as
much
as
he
could
conveniently
carry
,
and
Mrs
Tibbs
felt
a
due
degree
of
indignation
thereat
;
Mr
Gobler
and
Mrs
Bloss
conversed
most
affectionately
on
the
subject
of
pill
-
taking
,
and
other
innocent
amusements
;
and
Tomkins
and
Wisbottle
"
got
into
an
argument
;
"
that
is
to
say
,
they
both
talked
very
loudly
and
vehemently
,
each
flattering
himself
that
he
had
got
some
advantage
about
something
,
and
neither
of
them
having
more
than
a
very
indistinct
idea
of
what
they
were
talking
about
.
 
<EOS>
An
hour
or
two
passed
away
;
and
the
boarders
and
the
plated
candlesticks
retired
in
pairs
to
their
respective

.
 
<EOS>
John
Evenson
pulled
off
his
boots
,
locked
his
door
,
and
determined
to
sit
up
until
Mr
Gobler
had
retired
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
sat
in
the
drawing
-
room
an
hour
after
everybody
else
had
left
it
,
taking
medicine
,
and
groaning
.
   
<EOS>
Great
Coram
-
street
was
hushed
into
a
state
of
profound
repose
:
 
<EOS>
it
was
nearly
two
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
A
hackney
-
coach
now
and
then
rumbled
slowly
by
;
and
occasionally
some
stray
lawyer
's
clerk
,
on
his
way
home
to
Somers
-
town
,
struck
his
iron
heel
on
the
top
of
the
coal
-
cellar
with
a
noise
resembling
the
click
of
a
smoke
-
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
A
low
,
monotonous
,
gushing
sound
was
heard
,
which
added
considerably
to
the
romantic
dreariness
of
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
water
"
coming
in
"
at
number
eleven
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
asleep
by
this
time
,
"
said
John
Evenson
to
himself
,
after
waiting
with
exemplary

for
nearly
an
hour
after
Mr
Gobler
had
left
the
drawing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
listened
for
a
few
moments
;
the
house
was
perfectly
quiet
;
he
extinguished
his
rushlight
,
and
opened
his
bedroom
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
staircase
was
so
dark
that
it
was
impossible
to
see
anything
.
   
<EOS>
"
S
-
s
-
s
!
"
whispered
the
mischief
-
maker
,
making
a

like
the
first
indication
a
catherine
-
wheel
gives
of
the
probability
of
its

off
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is

you
,
Mrs
Tibbs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
;
"
and

of

appeared

,
like

Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
This

,

,
"

:
 
"
give
me

---
there
!
 
<EOS>
Whoever

,
they
are
in

,

I

,

that
they

upset

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
little
Mrs
Tibbs
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
;
I
have

,

,
close

,

;
"

stairs
<EOS>
they

,
every

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
Wisbottle
and
somebody
,

,
"
exclaimed
the
radical
in

,
when

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
---
pray

's

!
"

Mrs
Tibbs
,
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
if

but

,
"

,
"
I

missis

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

Evenson
,

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

What

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

But

<EOS>

The

<EOS>

.

The

,

,

.

<EOS>

Oh
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

Hush
!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

What

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
---
It

Wisbottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Glorious
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
---
This

Alfred
Tomkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lord

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well

<EOS>
"
Not

!

<EOS>

ca

,

<EOS>
"

ca

---
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

-

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"
Oh

"
   
<EOS>
"
Be

"
 
<EOS>

A

.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Hag
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Be

,

---
I

.
 
<EOS>
Think

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

!
<EOS>
"

,

gin

-

,

;
"

ate

!
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

?
"
 
<EOS>

)

What

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
What

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
Why

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
have

,

,
"

,

's

,
which
would

hollow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Tibbs
!
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
!
<EOS>
"
called
out
Mrs
Bloss
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Tibbs
,
pray
get
up
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Here
the
imitation
of
a
woodpecker
was
resumed
with
tenfold
violence
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
---
dear
!
"
exclaimed
the
wretched
partner
of
the
depraved
Tibbs
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
knocking
at
my
door
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
be
discovered
!
 
<EOS>
What
will
they
think
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Tibbs
!
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
!
"
screamed
the
woodpecker
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
!
"
<EOS>
shouted
Gobler
,
bursting
out
of
the
back
drawing
-
room
,
like
the
dragon
at
Astley
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
Gobler
!
"
cried
Mrs
Bloss
,
with
a
proper

to

;
"
I
think
the
house
is
on
fire
,
or
else
there
's
thieves
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
the
most

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
devil
you
have
!
"
shouted
Gobler
again
,
bouncing
back
into
his
den
,
in
happy
imitation
of
the

,
and
returning

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
's

?
 
<EOS>
Wisbottle
!
<EOS>
Tomkins
!
 
<EOS>
O'Bleary
!
 
<EOS>
Agnes
!
 
<EOS>
What
the
deuce
!
<EOS>
all
up
and
dressed
?
"
   
"
Astonishing
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Bloss
,
who
had
run
down

,
and

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Call

,

,
"
said

,

into

.
<EOS>
---
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
and
Mr
Evenson
!
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Tibbs
and
Mr
Evenson
!
"
<EOS>
repeated

,
as
that
unhappy
pair
were
discovered
:
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tibbs
seated
in
an
arm

chair
by
the

,
and
Mr
Evenson
standing
by
her
side
,
   
<EOS>
We
must
leave
the
scene
that
ensued
to
the
reader
's
imagination
.
<EOS>
We
could
tell
,
how
Mrs
Tibbs
forthwith
fainted
away
,
and
how
it
required
the
united
strength
of
Mr
Wisbottle
and
Mr
Alfred
Tomkins
to
hold

in

chair
;
how
Mr
Evenson
explained
,
and
how
his

was
evidently

;
how
Agnes
repelled
the

of
Mrs
Tibbs
by
proving
that
she
was
negotiating
with
Mr
O'Bleary
to

her

's

in
his

;
and
how
Mr
Gobler
threw
a
damp
counterpane
on
the

of
Mr
O'Bleary
by
avowing
that
he
(
Gobler
)
had
already
proposed
to
,
and
been

by
,
Mrs
Bloss
;
how
Agnes
was
discharged

that

's

;
how
Mr
O'Bleary
discharged

from
Mrs
Tibbs
's
house
,

;
and

rails
against

English
,
and
vows
there

no

,
"
except

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
We
repeat
that
we
COULD
tell
all
this
,
but
we
love
to
exercise
our
self
-
denial
,
and
we
therefore
prefer
leaving

to

.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
whom
we
have
hitherto
described
as
Mrs
Bloss
,
is
no
more
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Gobler
exists
:
 
Mrs
Bloss
has
left
us
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
secluded
retreat
in
Newington
Butts
,
far
,
far
removed
from
the
noisy
strife
of
that
great
boarding
-
house
,
the
world
,
the
enviable
Gobler
and
his
pleasing
wife
revel
in
retirement
:
 
happy
in
their
complaints
,
their
table
,
and
their
medicine
,
wafted
through
life
by
the
grateful
prayers
of
all
the
purveyors
of
animal
food
within
three
miles
round
.
   
<EOS>
We
would
willingly
stop
here
,
but
we
have
a
painful
duty
imposed
upon
us
,
which
we
must
discharge
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Tibbs
have
separated
by
mutual
consent
,
Mrs
Tibbs
receiving
one
moiety
of
43L.
 
<EOS>
15S.
10D.
,
which
we
before
stated
to
be
the
amount
of
her
husband
's
annual
income
,
and
Mr
Tibbs
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
spending
the
evening
of
his
days
in
retirement
;
and
he
is
spending
also
,
annually
,
that
small
but
honourable
independence
.
 
<EOS>
He
resides
among
the
original
settlers
at
Walworth
;
and
it
has
been
stated
,
on
unquestionable
authority
,
that
the
conclusion
of
the
volunteer
story
has
been
heard
in
a
small
tavern
in
that
respectable
neighbourhood
.
   
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
Mrs
Tibbs
has
determined
to
dispose
of
the
whole
of
her
furniture
by
public
auction
,
and
to
retire
from
a
residence
in
which
she
has
suffered
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Robins
has
been
applied
to
,
to
conduct
the
sale
,
and
the
transcendent
abilities
of
the
literary
gentlemen
connected
with
his
establishment
are
now
devoted
to
the
task
of
drawing
up
the
preliminary

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
to
contain
,
among
a
variety
of
brilliant
matter
,
seventy
-
eight
words
in
large
capitals
,
and
six
original
quotations
in
inverted

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Minns
and
his
cousin
Mr
Augustus
Minns
was
a
bachelor
,
of
about
forty
as
he
said
---
of
about
eight
-
and
-
forty
as
his
friends
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
exceedingly
clean
,
precise
,
and
tidy
;
perhaps
somewhat
priggish
,
and
the
most
retiring
man
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
He
usually
wore
a
brown
frock
-
coat
without
a
wrinkle
,
light
inexplicables
without
a
spot
,
a
neat
neckerchief
with
a
remarkably
neat
tie
,
and
boots
without
a
fault
;
moreover
,
he
always
carried
a
brown
silk
umbrella
with
an
ivory
handle
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
clerk
in
Somerset
-
house
,
or
,
as
he
said
himself
,
he
held
"
a
responsible
situation
under
Government
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
good
and
increasing
salary
,
in
addition
to
some
10,000L.
of
his
own
(
invested
in
the
funds
)
,
and
he
occupied
a
first
floor
in
Tavistock
-
street
,
Covent
-
garden
,
where
he
had
resided
for
twenty
years
,
having
been
in
the
habit
of
quarrelling
with
his
landlord
the
whole
time
:
 
regularly
giving
notice
of
his
intention
to
quit
on
the
first
day
of
every
quarter
,
and
as
regularly
countermanding
it
on
the
second
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
classes
of
created
objects
which
he
held
in
the
deepest
and
most
unmingled
horror
;
these
were
dogs
,
and
children
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
unamiable
,
but
he
could
,
at
any
time
,
have
viewed
the
execution
of
a
dog
,
or
the
assassination
of
an
infant
,
with
the
liveliest
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
Their
habits
were
at
variance
with
his
love
of
order
;
and
his
love
of
order
was
as
powerful
as
his
love
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Augustus
Minns
had
no
relations
,
in
or
near
London
,
with
the
exception
of
his
cousin
,
Mr
Octavius
Budden
,
to
whose
son
,
whom
he
had
never
seen
(
for
he
disliked
the
father
)
,
he
had
consented
to
become
godfather
by
proxy
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Budden
having
realised
a
moderate
fortune
by
exercising
the
trade
or
calling
of
a
corn
-
chandler
,
and
having
a
great
predilection
for
the
country
,
had
purchased
a
cottage
in
the
vicinity
of
Stamford
-
hill
,
whither
he
retired
with
the
wife
of
his
bosom
,
and
his
only
son
,
Master
Alexander
Augustus
Budden
.
 
<EOS>
One
evening
,
as
Mr
and
Mrs
B
were
admiring
their
son
,
discussing
his
various
merits
,
talking
over
his
education
,
and
disputing
whether
the
classics
should
be
made
an
essential
part
thereof
,
the
lady
pressed
so
strongly
upon
her
husband
the
propriety
of
cultivating
the
friendship
of
Mr
Minns
in
behalf
of
their
son
,
that
Mr
Budden
at
last
made
up
his
mind
,
that
it
should
not
be
his
fault
if
he
and
his
cousin
were
not
in
future
more
intimate
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
break
the
ice
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Budden
,
stirring
up
the

at
the

of

of

-
and
-
water
,
and

to

of

,
"
by

Minns
down
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,
Budden
,
write

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who

,
if

could
only

down

,
but

Alexander
,

?
<EOS>
---
Alick
,
my
dear
,
take

off
the
rail
of

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
"
said
Mr
Budden
,
musing
,
"
very
true

,
my
love
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
,
as
Mr
Minns
was

-

,
alternately

dry

and

,
which
he
always
read
from
the
title
to
the

's

,

heard
a

at
the

;

,

,

"
Mr
Octavius
Budden
,
Amelia
Cottage
<EOS>
(
Mrs
B
's
name
was
Amelia
)
,
Poplar
-
walk
,
Stamford
-
hill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Budden
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Minns
,
"
what
can
bring
that
vulgar
man
here
!
<EOS>
---
say

'm

---
say

'm

,
and

never

---
anything

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

,

,

's

,
"

,
and

,
by

of

;
the
cause

,
Minns
could
not
,
for
the
life
of
him
,
divine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
---
show
the
gentleman
in
,
"
said
the
unfortunate

.
 
<EOS>
Exit

,
and
enter
Octavius
preceded
by
a
large
white
dog
,
dressed
in
a
suit
of
fleecy

,
with
pink

,
large

,
and
no
