.
   
<EOS>
The
cause
of
the
pattering
on
the
stairs
was
but
too
plain
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Augustus
Minns
staggered
beneath
the
shock
of
the
dog
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
how
are

?
"
said
Budden
,
as

entered
.
   
<EOS>
He
always
spoke
at
the
top
of
his
voice
,
and
always
said
the
same
thing
half
-
a
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

do
,
Mr
Budden
?
---
<EOS>
pray

chair
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

---
thank

---
<EOS>
well
---
how

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Uncommonly
well
,

,
"

,
casting

dog
,

,

,

,
was

out
of
a

,

to
devouring

,
with
the
buttered

next

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
rogue
!
<EOS>
"
said

to

;
"
you
see
,
Minns
,
he
's
like

,
always
at

,
eh
,
my

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Egad
,
I
'm
precious
hot

!
 
<EOS>
I
've

all
the
way
from

-
hill
this

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Have

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
---
came

;

ring

,

,

?
<EOS>
and

's

,

.
<EOS>
---
Make

at

,

!
"
<EOS>
continued

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
---
ha
!
---
ha
!
---
'
pon

,
I
'm

.
"
   
<EOS>
Minns
rang
the
bell
,
and
tried
to
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
decidedly
never
was
so
hot
in

,
"
continued
Octavius
,
wiping

;
"
<EOS>
well
,
but
how
are

,
Minns
?
 
<EOS>
"
Pon
my

,
you
wear

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
D'ye
think

?
"
said
Minns
;
and
he

another

.
   
<EOS>
"
'
Pon
my
life
,
I
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
B
and
<EOS>
---
what
's

name
---
quite
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Alick
---
my
son
,
you
mean
;
never
better
---
never

.
 
<EOS>
But
at
such

place
as
we
've

at
Poplar
-
walk
,
you
know
,
he
could
n't
be
ill
if

.
 
<EOS>
When
I
first
saw
it
,
by
Jove
!
<EOS>
it

so
knowing
,
with
the
front

,

and
the

knocker
,
and
all
that
<EOS>
---
I
really
thought
it
was
a
cut
above
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

you
think

'd

ham
better
,
"
interrupted
Minns
,
"
if
you
cut

the
other

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
saw
,
with
feelings
which
it
is
impossible
to
describe
,
that
his
visitor
was
cutting
or
rather
maiming
the
ham
,
in
utter
violation
of
all
established
rules
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
ye
,
"
returned
Budden
,
with
the
most
barbarous
indifference
to
crime
,
"
<EOS>
I
prefer
it
this
way
,
it
eats
short
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
say
,
Minns
,
when
will
you
come
down
and
see
us
?
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
delighted
with
the
place
;
I
know
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
Amelia
and
I
were
talking
about
you
the
other
night
,
and
Amelia
said
---
another
lump
of
sugar
,
please
;
thank
ye
---
<EOS>
she
said
,
<EOS>
do
n't
you
think
you
could
contrive
,
my
dear
,
to
say
to
Mr
Minns
,
in
a
friendly
way
---
come
down
,
sir
---
damn
the
dog
!
<EOS>
he
's
spoiling
your
curtains
,
Minns
---
ha
!
<EOS>
---
ha
!
<EOS>
---
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
Minns
leaped
from
his
seat
as
though
he
had
received
the
discharge
from
a
galvanic
battery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
out
,
sir
!
---
go
out
,
hoo
!
"
<EOS>
cried
poor
Augustus
,
keeping
,
nevertheless
,
at
a
very
respectful
distance
from
the
dog
;
having
read
of
a
case
of
hydrophobia
in
the
paper
of
that
morning
.
 
<EOS>
By
dint
of
great
exertion
,
much
shouting
,
and
a
marvellous
deal
of
poking
under
the
tables
with
a
stick
and
umbrella
,
the
dog
was
at
last
dislodged
,
and
placed
on
the
landing
outside
the
door
,
where
he
immediately
commenced
a
most
appalling
howling
;
at
the
same
time
vehemently
scratching
the
paint
off
the
two
nicely
-
varnished
bottom
panels
,
until
they
resembled
the
interior
of
a
backgammon
-
board
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
good
dog
for
the
country
that
!
"
<EOS>
coolly
observed
Budden
to
the
distracted
Minns
,
"
but
he
's
not
much
used
to
confinement
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
,
Minns
,
when
will
you
come
down
?
 
<EOS>
I
'll
take
no
denial
,
positively
.
<EOS>
Let
's
see
,
to
-
day
's
Thursday
.
<EOS>
---
Will
you
come
on
Sunday
?
 
<EOS>
We
dine
at
five
,
do
n't
say
no
---
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
great
deal
of
pressing
,
Mr
Augustus
Minns
,
driven
to
despair
,
accepted
the
invitation
,
and
promised
to
be
at
Poplar
-
walk
on
the
ensuing
Sunday
,
at
a
quarter
before
five
to
the
minute
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
mind
the
direction
,
"
said
Budden
:
 
"
the
coach
goes
from
the
Flower
-
pot
,
in
Bishopsgate
-
street
,
every
half
hour
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
coach
stops
at
the
Swan
,
you
'll
see
,
immediately
opposite
you
,
a
white
house
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
is
your
house
---
I
understand
,
"
said
Minns
,
wishing
to
cut
short
the
visit
,
and
the
story
,
at
the
same
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
that
's
not
mine
;
that
's
Grogus
's
,
the
great
ironmonger
's
.
<EOS>
I
was
going
to
say
<EOS>
---
you
turn
down
by
the
side
of
the
white
house
till
you
ca
n't
go
another
step
further
---
mind
that
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
then
you
turn
to
your
right
,
by
some
stables
---
well
;
close
to
you
,
<EOS>
you
'll
see
a
wall
with
"
Beware
of
the
Dog
"
written
on
it
in
large
letters
---
(
Minns
shuddered
)
---
<EOS>
go
along
by
the
side
of
that
wall
for
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
---
and
anybody
will
show
you
which
is
my
place
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
---
thank
ye
---
<EOS>
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Be
punctual
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
:
 
good
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Minns
,
you
've
got
a
card
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
;
thank
ye
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Octavius
Budden
departed
,
leaving
his
cousin
looking
forward
to
his
visit
on
the
following
Sunday
,
with
the
feelings
of
a
penniless
poet
to
the
weekly
visit
of
his
Scotch
landlady
.
   
<EOS>
Sunday
arrived
;
the
sky
was
bright
and
clear
;
crowds
of
people
were
hurrying
along
the
streets
,
intent
on
their
different
schemes
of
pleasure
for
the
day
;
everything
and
everybody
looked
cheerful
and
happy
except
Mr
Augustus
Minns
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
was
fine
,
but
the
heat
was
considerable
;
when
Mr
Minns
had
fagged
up
the
shady
side
of
Fleet
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
and
Threadneedle
-
street
,
he
had
become
pretty
warm
,
tolerably
dusty
,
and
it
was
getting
late
into
the
bargain
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
most
extraordinary
good
fortune
,
however
,
a
coach
was
waiting
at
the
Flower
-
pot
,
into
which
Mr
Augustus
Minns
got
,
on
the
solemn
assurance
of
the
cad
that
the
vehicle
would
start
in
three
minutes
---
that
being
the
very
utmost
extremity
of
time
it
was
allowed
to
wait
by
Act
of
Parliament
.
 
<EOS>
A
quarter
of
an
hour
elapsed
,
and
there
were
no
signs
of
moving
.
 
<EOS>
Minns
looked
at
his
watch
for
the
sixth
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Coachman
,
are
you
going
or
not
?
"
<EOS>
bawled
Mr
Minns
,
with
his
head
and
half
his
body
out
of
the
coach
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
Di
-
rectly
,
sir
,
"
said
the
coachman
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
looking
as
much
unlike
a
man
in
a
hurry
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
take
them
cloths
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
Five
minutes
more
elapsed
:
 
<EOS>
at
the
end
of
which
time
the
coachman
mounted
the
box
,
from
whence
he
looked
down
the
street
,
and
up
the
street
,
and
hailed
all
the
pedestrians
for
another
five
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Coachman
!
<EOS>
if
you
do
n't
go
this
moment
,
I
shall
get
out
,
"
said
Mr
Minns
,
rendered
desperate
by
the
lateness
of
the
hour
,
and
the
impossibility
of
being
in
Poplar
-
walk
at
the
appointed
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Going
this
minute
,
sir
,
"
was
the
reply
;
---
and
,
accordingly
,
the
machine
trundled
on
for
a
couple
of
hundred
yards
,
and
then
stopped
again
.
 
<EOS>
Minns
doubled
himself
up
in
a
corner
of
the
coach
,
and
abandoned
himself
to
his
fate
,
as
a
child
,
a
mother
,
a
bandbox
and
a
parasol
,
became
his
fellow
-
passengers
.
   
<EOS>
The
child
was
an
affectionate
and
an
amiable
infant
;
the
little
dear
mistook
Minns
for
his
other
parent
,
and
screamed
to
embrace
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
quiet
,
dear
,
"
said
the
mamma
,
restraining
the
impetuosity
of
the
darling
,
whose
little
fat
legs
were
kicking
,
and
stamping
,
and
twining
themselves
into
the
most
complicated
forms
,
in
an
ecstasy
of
impatience
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
quiet
,
dear
,
that
's
not
your
papa
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
<EOS>
I
am
not
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Minns
,
as
the
first
gleam
of
pleasure
he
had
experienced
that
morning
shone
like
a
meteor
through
his
wretchedness
.
   
<EOS>
Playfulness
was
agreeably
mingled
with
affection
in
the
disposition
of
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
When
satisfied
that
Mr
Minns
was
not
his
parent
,
he
endeavoured
to
attract
his
notice
by
scraping
his
drab
trousers
with
his
dirty
shoes
,
poking
his
chest
with
his
mamma
's
parasol
,
and
other
nameless
endearments
peculiar
to
infancy
,
with
which
he
beguiled
the
tediousness
of
the
ride
,
apparently
very
much
to
his
own
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
unfortunate
gentleman
arrived
at
the
Swan
,
he
found
to
his
great
dismay
,
that
it
was
a
quarter
past
five
.
 
<EOS>
The
white
house
,
the
stables
,
the
"
Beware
of
the
Dog
,
"
---
every
landmark
was
passed
,
with
a
rapidity
not
unusual
to
a
gentleman
of
a
certain
age
when
too
late
for
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
lapse
of
a
few
minutes
,
Mr
Minns
found
himself
opposite
a
yellow
brick
house
with
a
green
door
,
brass
knocker
,
and
door
-
plate
,
green
window
-
frames
and
ditto
railings
,
with
"
a
garden
"
in
front
,
that
is
to
say
,
a
small
loose
bit
of
gravelled
ground
,
with
one
round
and
two
scalene
triangular
beds
,
containing
a
fir
-
tree
,
twenty
or
thirty
bulbs
,
and
an
unlimited
number
of
marigolds
.
 
<EOS>
The
taste
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Budden
was
further
displayed
by
the
appearance
of
a
Cupid
on
each
side
of
the
door
,
perched
upon
a
heap
of
large
chalk
flints
,
variegated
with
pink
conch
-
shells
.
 
<EOS>
His
knock
at
the
door
was
answered
by
a
stumpy
boy
,
in
drab
livery
,
cotton
stockings
and
high
-
lows
,
who
,
after
hanging
his
hat
on
one
of
the
dozen
brass
pegs
which
ornamented
the
passage
,
denominated
by
courtesy
"
The
Hall
,
"
ushered
him
into
a
front
drawing
-
room
commanding
a
very
extensive
view
of
the
backs
of
the
neighbouring
houses
.
 
<EOS>
The
usual
ceremony
of
introduction
,
and
so
forth
,
over
,
Mr
Minns
took
his
seat
:
 
not
a
little
agitated
at
finding
that
he
was
the
last
comer
,
and
,
somehow
or
other
,
the
Lion
of
about
a
dozen
people
,
sitting
together
in
a
small
drawing
-
room
,
getting
rid
of
that
most
tedious
of
all
time
,
the
time
preceding
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Brogson
,
"
said
Budden
,
addressing
an
elderly
gentleman
in
a
black
coat
,
drab
knee
-
breeches
,
and
long
gaiters
,
who
,
under
pretence
of
inspecting
the
prints
in
an
Annual
,
had
been
engaged
in
satisfying
himself
on
the
subject
of
Mr
Minns
's
general
appearance
,
by
looking
at
him
over
the
tops
of
the
leaves
---
"
Well
,
Brogson
,
what
do
ministers
mean
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
Will
they
go
out
,
or
what
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
---
why
---
really
,
you
know
,
I
'm
the
last
person
in
the
world
to
ask
for
news
.
 
<EOS>
Your
cousin
,
from
his
situation
,
is
the
most
likely
person
to
answer
the
question
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Minns
assured
the
last
speaker
,
that
although
he
was
in
Somerset
-
house
,
he
possessed
no
official
communication
relative
to
the
projects
of
his
Majesty
's
Ministers
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
remark
was
evidently
received
incredulously
;
and
no
further
conjectures
being
hazarded
on
the
subject
,
a
long
pause
ensued
,
during
which
the
company
occupied
themselves
in
coughing
and
blowing
their
noses
,
until
the
entrance
of
Mrs
Budden
caused
a
general
rise
.
   
<EOS>
The
ceremony
of
introduction
being
over
,
dinner
was
announced
,
and
down
-
stairs
the
party
proceeded
accordingly
---
<EOS>
Mr
Minns
escorting
Mrs
Budden
as
far
as
the
drawing
-
room
door
,
but
being
prevented
,
by
the
narrowness
of
the
staircase
,
from
extending
his
gallantry
any
farther
.
 
<EOS>
The
dinner
passed
off
as
such
dinners
usually
do
.
<EOS>
Ever
and
anon
,
amidst
the
clatter
of
knives
and
forks
,
and
the
hum
of
conversation
,
Mr
B
's
voice
might
be
heard
,
asking
a
friend
to
take
wine
,
and
assuring
him
<EOS>
he
was
glad
to
see
him
;
and
a
great
deal
of
by
-
play
took
place
between
Mrs
B
and
the
servants
,
respecting
the
removal
of
the
dishes
,
during
which
her
countenance
assumed
all
the
variations
of
a
weather
-
glass
,
from
"
stormy
"
to
"
set
fair
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
the
dessert
and
wine
being
placed
on
the
table
,
the
servant
,
in
compliance
with
a
significant
look
from
Mrs
B
,
brought
down
"
Master
Alexander
,
"
habited
in
a
sky
-
blue
suit
with
silver
buttons
;
and
possessing
hair
of
nearly
the
same
colour
as
the
metal
.
 
<EOS>
After
sundry
praises
from
his
mother
,
and
various
admonitions
as
to
his
behaviour
from
his
father
,
he
was
introduced
to
his
godfather
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my
little
fellow
---
you
are
a
fine
boy
,
ai
n't
you
?
"
said
Mr
Minns
,
as
happy
as
a
tomtit
on
birdlime
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
old
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Eight
,
next
We'nsday
.
 
<EOS>
How
old
are
YOU
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Alexander
,
"
interrupted
his
mother
,
"
how
dare
you
ask
Mr
Minns
<EOS>
how
old
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
asked
me
how
old
I
was
,
"
said
the
precocious
child
,
to
whom
Minns
had
from
that
moment
internally
resolved
that
he
never
would
bequeath
one
shilling
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
titter
occasioned
by
the
observation
had
subsided
,
a
little
smirking
man
with
red
whiskers
,
sitting
at
the
bottom
of
the
table
,
who
during
the
whole
of
dinner
had
been
endeavouring
to
obtain
a
listener
to
some
stories
about
Sheridan
,
called
,
out
,
with
a
very
patronising
air
,
"
Alick
,
what
part
of
speech
is
BE
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
verb
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
good
boy
,
"
said
Mrs
Budden
,
with
all
a
mother
's
pride
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
you
know
what
a
verb
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
verb
is
a
word
which
signifies
to
be
,
to
do
,
or
to
suffer
;
as
,
I
am
---
<EOS>
I
rule
---
I
am
ruled
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
an
apple
,
Ma
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
give
you
an
apple
,
"
replied
the
man
with
the
red
whiskers
,
who
was
an
established
friend
of

"

"
 
<EOS>
[
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Jones

"

)

<EOS>
Mr

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

;

<EOS>
However
,

"

,

---

---

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
somewhere
about
three

in

morning
,
when
Mr
Augustus
Minns
knocked

at
the
street
-
door
of
his
lodgings
in
Tavistock
-

,
cold
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
made
his
will
next
morning
,
and
his
professional
man
informs
us
,
in
that
strict

in
which
we

,
that

of
Mr
Octavius

,

Mrs

,

Augustus

,

.
   
<EOS>
Sentiment
<EOS>
The
Miss
Crumptons
,
or
to
quote
the
authority
of
the
inscription
on
the
garden
-
gate
of
Minerva
House
,
Hammersmith
,
"
The
Misses
Crumpton
,
"
were
two
unusually
tall
,
particularly
thin
,
and
exceedingly
skinny
personages
:
 
very
upright
,
and
very
yellow
.
<EOS>
Miss
Amelia
Crumpton
owned
to
thirty
-
eight
,
and
Miss
Maria
Crumpton
admitted
she
was
forty
;
an
admission
which
was
rendered
perfectly
unnecessary
by
the
self
-
evident
fact
of
her
being
at
least
fifty
.
<EOS>
They
dressed
in
the
most
interesting
manner
---
like
twins
!
<EOS>
and
looked
as
happy
and
comfortable
as
a
couple
of
marigolds
run
to
seed
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
precise
,
had
the
strictest
possible
ideas
of
propriety
,
wore
false
hair
,
and
always
smelt
very
strongly
of
lavender
.
   
<EOS>
Minerva
House
,
conducted
under
the
auspices
of
the
two
sisters
,
was
a
"
finishing
establishment
for
young
ladies
,
"
where
some
twenty
girls
of
the
ages
of
from
thirteen
to
nineteen
inclusive
,
acquired
a
smattering
of
everything
,
and
a
knowledge
of
nothing
;
instruction
in
French
and
Italian
,
dancing
lessons
twice
a
-
week
;
and
other
necessaries
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
was
a
white
one
,
a
little
removed
from
the
roadside
,
with
close
palings
in
front
.
 
<EOS>
The
bedroom
windows
were
always
left
partly
open
,
to
afford
a
bird's
-
eye
view
of
numerous
little
bedsteads
with
very
white
dimity
furniture
,
and
thereby
impress
the
passer
-
by
with
a
due
sense
of
the
luxuries
of
the
establishment
;
and
there
was
a
front
parlour
hung
round
with
highly
varnished
maps
which
nobody
ever
looked
at
,
and
filled
with
books
which
no
one
ever
read
,
appropriated
exclusively
to
the
reception
of
parents
,
who
,
whenever
they
called
,
could
not
fail
to
be
struck
with
the
very
deep
appearance
of
the
place
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amelia
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Miss
Maria
Crumpton
,
entering
the
school
-
room
one
morning
,
with
her
false
hair
in
papers
:
 
as
she
occasionally
did
,
in
order
to
impress
the
young
ladies
with
a
conviction
of
its
reality
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amelia
,
my
dear
,
here
is
a
most

note
I
have
just

.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
mind
reading
it
aloud
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Amelia
,
thus
advised
,
proceeded
to
read
the
following
note
with
an
air
of
great

:
   
<EOS>
"
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
MP
,
presents

to
Miss
Crumpton
,
and
will

Miss

's

,
if

can
,
to
-
morrow
morning
at
one
o'clock
,
as
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
MP
,
is
anxious
to
see
Miss
Crumpton
on
the
subject
of
placing
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
under

.
   
<EOS>
"
Adelphi
.
   
<EOS>
"
Monday
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
Member
of
Parliament
's
daughter
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Amelia
,
in
an
ecstatic

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
Member
of
Parliament
's
daughter
!
"
repeated
Miss
Maria
,
with
a
smile
of
delight
,
which
,
of
course
,
elicited
a
concurrent

of
pleasure
from
all
the
young
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
exceedingly
delightful
!
"
said
Miss
Amelia
;
whereupon
all
the
young
ladies
murmured
their
admiration
again
.
 
<EOS>
Courtiers
are
but
school
-
boys
,
and
court
-
ladies
school
-
girl
's
.
   
<EOS>
So
important
an
announcement
at
once
superseded
the
business
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
A
holiday
was
declared
,
in
commemoration
of
the
great
event
;
the
Miss
Crumptons
retired
to
their
private
apartment
to
talk
it
over
;
the
smaller
girls
discussed
the
probable
manners
and
customs
of
the
daughter
of
a
Member
of
Parliament
;
and
the
young
ladies
verging
on
eighteen
wondered
whether
she
was
engaged
,
whether
she
was
pretty
,
whether
she
wore
much
bustle
,
and
many
other
WHETHERS
of
equal
importance
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
Miss
Crumptons
proceeded
to
the
Adelphi
at
the
appointed
time
next
day
,
dressed
,
of
course
,
in
their
best
style
,
and
looking
as
amiable
as
they
possibly
could
---
which
,
by
-
the
-
bye
,
is
not
saying
much
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Having
sent
in
their
cards
,
through
the
medium
of
a
red
-
hot
looking
footman
in
bright
livery
,
they
were
ushered
into
the
august
presence
of
the
profound
Dingwall
.
   
<EOS>
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
MP
,
was
very
haughty
,
solemn
,
and
portentous
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
,
naturally
,
a
somewhat
spasmodic
expression
of
countenance
,
which
was
not
rendered
the
less
remarkable
by
his
wearing
an
extremely
stiff
cravat
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
wonderfully
proud
of
the
MP
attached
to
his
name
,
and
never
lost
an
opportunity
of
reminding
people
of
his
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
great
idea
of
his
own
abilities
,
which
must
have
been
a
great
comfort
to
him
,
as
no
one
else
had
;
and
in
diplomacy
,
on
a
small
scale
,
in
his
own
family
arrangements
,
he
considered
himself
unrivalled
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
county
magistrate
,
and
discharged
the
duties
of
his
station
with
all
due
justice
and
impartiality
;
frequently
committing
poachers
,
and
occasionally
committing
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
was
one
of
that
numerous
class
of
young
ladies
,
who
,
like
adverbs
,
may
be
known
by
their
answering
to
a
commonplace
question
,
and
doing
nothing
else
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
,
this
talented
individual
was
seated
in
a
small
library
at
a
table
covered
with
papers
,
doing
nothing
,
but
trying
to
look
busy
,
playing
at
shop
.
 
<EOS>
Acts
of
Parliament
,
and
letters
directed
to
"
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
MP
,
"
were
ostentatiously
scattered
over
the
table
;
at
a
little
distance
from
which
,
Mrs
Brook
Dingwall
was
seated
at
work
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
those
public
nuisances
,
a
spoiled
child
,
was
playing
about
the
room
,
dressed
after
the
most
approved
fashion
---
in
a
blue
tunic
with
a
black
belt
---
a
quarter
of
a
yard
wide
,
fastened
with
an
immense
buckle
---
looking
like
a
robber
in
a
melodrama
,
seen
through
a
diminishing
glass
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
little
pleasantry
from
the
sweet
child
,
who
amused
himself
by
running
away
with
Miss
Maria
Crumpton
's
chair
as
fast
as
it
was
placed
for
her
,
the
visitors
were
seated
,
and
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
opened
the
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
sent
for
Miss
Crumpton
,
he
said
,
in
consequence
of
the
high
character
he
had
received
of
her
establishment
from
his
friend
,
Sir
Alfred
Muggs
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Crumpton
murmured
her
acknowledgments
to
him
(
Muggs
)
,
and
Cornelius
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
of
my
principal
reasons
,
Miss
Crumpton
,
for
parting
with
my
daughter
,
is
,
that
she
has
lately
acquired
some
sentimental
ideas
,
which
it
is
most
desirable
to
eradicate
from
her
young
mind
.
"
<EOS>
(
Here
the
little
innocent
before
noticed
,
fell
out
of
an
arm
-
chair
with
an
awful
crash
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Naughty
boy
!
<EOS>
"
said
his
mamma
,
who
appeared
more
surprised
at
his
taking
the
liberty
of
falling
down
,
than
at
anything
else
;
"
I
'll
ring
the
bell
for
James
to
take
him
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
check
him
,
my
love
,
"
said
the
diplomatist
,
as
soon
as
he
could
make
himself
heard
amidst
the
unearthly
howling
consequent
upon
the
threat
and
the
tumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
all
arises
from
his
great
flow
of
spirits
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
last
explanation
was
addressed
to
Miss
Crumpton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
antique
Maria
:
 
not
exactly
seeing
,
however
,
the
connexion
between
a
flow
of
animal
spirits
,
and
a
fall
from
an
arm
-
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Silence
was
restored
,
and
the
MP
resumed
:
 
"
Now
,
I
know
nothing
so
likely
to
effect
this
object
,
Miss
Crumpton
,
as
her
mixing
constantly
in
the
society
of
girls
of
her
own
age
;
and
,
as
I
know
that
in
your
establishment
she
will
meet
such
as
are
not
likely
to
contaminate
her
young
mind
,
I
propose
to
send
her
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
youngest
Miss
Crumpton
expressed
the
acknowledgments
of
the
establishment
generally
.
 
<EOS>
Maria
was
rendered
speechless
by
bodily
pain
.
 
<EOS>
The
dear
little
fellow
,
having
recovered
his
animal
spirits
,
was
standing
upon
her
most
tender
foot
,
by
way
of
getting
his
face
(
which
looked
like
a
capital
O
in
a
red
-
lettered
play
-
bill
)
on
a
level
with
the
writing
-
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
Lavinia
will
be
a
parlour
boarder
,
"
continued
the
enviable
father
;
"
and
on
one
point
I
wish
my
directions
to
be
strictly
observed
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
that
some
ridiculous
love
affair
,
with
a
person
much
her
inferior
in
life
,
has
been
the
cause
of
her
present
state
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
that
of
course
,
under
your
care
,
she
can
have
no
opportunity
of
meeting
this
person
<EOS>
,
I
do
not
object
to
---
<EOS>
indeed
,
I
should
rather
prefer
---
<EOS>
her
mixing
with
such
society
as
you
see
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
important
statement
was
again
interrupted
by
the
high
-
spirited
little
creature
,
in
the
excess
of
his
joyousness
breaking
a
pane
of
glass
,
and
nearly
precipitating
himself
into
an
adjacent
area
.
<EOS>
James
was
rung
for
;
considerable
confusion
and
screaming
succeeded
;
two
little
blue
legs
were
seen
to
kick
violently
in
the
air
as
the
man
left
the
room
,
and
the
child
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Brook
Dingwall
would
like
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
to
learn
everything
,
"
said
Mrs
Brook
Dingwall
,
who
hardly
ever
said
anything
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
both
the
Miss
Crumptons
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
I
trust
the
plan
I
have
devised
will
be
effectual
in
weaning
my
daughter
from
this
absurd
idea
,
Miss
Crumpton
,
"
continued
the
legislator
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
have
the
goodness
to
comply
,
in
all
respects
,
with
any
request
I
may
forward
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
promise
was
of
course
made
;
and
after
a
lengthened
discussion
,
conducted
on
behalf
of
the
Dingwalls
with
the
most
becoming
diplomatic
gravity
,
and
on
that
of
the
Crumptons
with
profound
respect
,
it
was
finally
arranged
that
Miss
Lavinia
should
be
forwarded
to
Hammersmith
on
the
next
day
but
one
,
on
which
occasion
the
half
-
yearly
ball
given
at
the
establishment
was
to
take
place
.
<EOS>
It
might
divert
the
dear
girl
's
mind
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
by
the
way
,
was
another
bit
of
diplomacy
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
was
introduced
to
her
future
governess
,
and
both
the
Miss
Crumptons
pronounced
her
"
a
most
charming
girl
;
"
an
opinion
which
,
by
a
singular
coincidence
,
they
always
entertained
of
any
new
pupil
.
   
<EOS>
Courtesies
were
exchanged
,
acknowledgments
expressed
,
condescension
exhibited
,
and
the
interview
terminated
.
   
<EOS>
Preparations
,
to
make
use
of
theatrical
phraseology
,
"
on
a
scale
of
magnitude
never
before
attempted
,
"
were
incessantly
made
at
Minerva
House
to
give
every
effect
to
the
forthcoming
ball
.
 
<EOS>
The
largest
room
in
the
house
was
pleasingly
ornamented
with
blue
calico
roses
,
plaid
tulips
,
and
other
equally
natural
-
looking
artificial
flowers
,
the
work
of
the
young
ladies
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
The
carpet
was
taken
up
,
the
folding
-
doors
were
taken
down
,
the
furniture
was
taken
out
,
and
rout
-
seats
were
taken
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
linen
-
drapers
of
Hammersmith
were
astounded
at
the
sudden
demand
for
blue
sarsenet
ribbon
,
and
long
white
gloves
.
 
<EOS>
Dozens
of
geraniums
were
purchased
for
bouquets
,
and
a
harp
and
two
violins
were
bespoke
from
town
,
in
addition
to
the
grand
piano
already
on
the
premises
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
who
were
selected
to
show
off
on
the
occasion
,
and
do
credit
to
the
establishment
,
practised
incessantly
,
much
to
their
own
satisfaction
,
and
greatly
to
the
annoyance
of
the
lame
old
gentleman
over
the
way
;
and
a
constant
correspondence
was
kept
up
,
between
the
Misses
Crumpton
and
the
Hammersmith
pastrycook
.
   
<EOS>
The
evening
came
;
and
then
there
was
such
a
lacing
of
stays
,
and
tying
of
sandals
,
and
dressing
of
hair
,
as
never
can
take
place
with
a
proper
degree
of
bustle
out
of
a
boarding
-
school
.
 
<EOS>
The
smaller
girls
managed
to
be
in
everybody
's
way
,
and
were
pushed
about
accordingly
;
and
the
elder
ones
dressed
,
and
tied
,
and
flattered
,
and
envied
,
one
another
,
as
earnestly
and
sincerely
as
if
they
had
actually
COME
OUT
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
I
look
,
dear
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Miss
Emily
Smithers
,
the
belle
of
the
house
,
of
Miss
Caroline
Wilson
,
who
was
her
bosom
friend
,
because
she
was
the
ugliest
girl
in
Hammersmith
,
or
out
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
charming
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
!
<EOS>
you
never
looked
so
handsome
,
"
returned
the
belle
,
adjusting
her
own
dress
,
and
not
bestowing
a
glance
on
her
poor
companion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
young
Hilton
will
come
early
,
"
said
another
young
lady
to
Miss
somebody
else
,
in
a
fever
of
expectation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
he
'd
be
highly
flattered
if
he
knew
it
,
"
returned
the
other
,
who
was
practising
L'ETE
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
he
's
so
handsome
,
"
said
the
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
Such
a
charming
person
!
"
added
a
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
Such
a
DISTINGUE
air
!
<EOS>
"
said
a
third
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
DO
you
think
?
"
said
another
girl
,
running
into
the
room
;
"
Miss
Crumpton
says
her
cousin
's
coming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Theodosius
Butler
?
"
said
everybody
in
raptures
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
HE
handsome
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
a
novice
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
particularly
handsome
,
"
was
the
general
reply
;
"
but
,
oh
,
so
clever
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Theodosius
Butler
was
one
of
those
immortal
geniuses
who
are
to
be
met
with
in
almost
every
circle
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
,
usually
,
very
deep
,
monotonous
voices
.
 
<EOS>
They
always
persuade
themselves
that
they
are
wonderful
persons
,
and
that
they
ought
to
be
very
miserable
,
though
they
do
n't
precisely
know
why
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
very
conceited
,
and
usually
possess
half
an
idea
;
but
,
with
enthusiastic
young
ladies
,
and
silly
young
gentlemen
,
they
are
very
wonderful
persons
.
 
<EOS>
The
individual
in
question
,
Mr
Theodosius
,
had
written
a
pamphlet
containing
some
very
weighty
considerations
on
the
expediency
of
doing
something
or
other
;
and
as
every
sentence
contained
a
good
many
words
of
four
syllables
,
his
admirers
took
it
for
granted
that
he
meant
a
good
deal
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
that
's
he
,
"
exclaimed
several
young
ladies
,
as
the
first
pull
of
the
evening
threatened
destruction
to
the
bell
of
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
An
awful
pause
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
Some
boxes
arrived
and
a
young
lady
---
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
,
in
full
ball
costume
,
with
an
immense
gold
chain
round
her
neck
,
and
her
dress
looped
up
with
a
single
rose
;
an
ivory
fan
in
her
hand
,
and
a
most
interesting
expression
of
despair
in
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
The
Miss
Crumptons
inquired
after
the
family
,
with
the
most
excruciating
anxiety
,
and
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
was
formally
introduced
to
her
future
companions
.
 
<EOS>
The
Miss
Crumptons
conversed
with
the
young
ladies
in
the
most
mellifluous
tones
,
in
order
that
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
might
be
properly
impressed
with
their
amiable
treatment
.
   
<EOS>
Another
pull
at
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dadson
the
writing
-
master
,
and
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
The
wife
in
green
silk
,
with
shoes
and
cap
-
trimmings
to
correspond
:
 
the
writing
-
master
in
a
white
waistcoat
,
black
knee
-
shorts
,
and
ditto
silk
stockings
,
displaying
a
leg
large
enough
for
two
writing
-
masters
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
whispered
one
another
,
and
the
writing
-
master
and
his
wife
flattered
the
Miss
Crumptons
,
who
were
dressed
in
amber
,
with
long
sashes
,
like
dolls
.
   
<EOS>
Repeated
pulls
at
the
bell
,
and
arrivals
too
numerous
to
particularise
:
 
papas
and
mammas
,
and
aunts
and
uncles
,
the
owners
and
guardians
of
the
different
pupils
;
the
singing
-
master
,
Signor
Lobskini
,
in
a
black
wig
;
the
piano
-
forte
player
and
the
violins
;
the
harp
,
in
a
state
of
intoxication
;
and
some
twenty
young
men
,
who
stood
near
the
door
,
and
talked
to
one
another
,
occasionally
bursting
into
a
giggle
.
 
<EOS>
A
general
hum
of
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Coffee
handed
round
,
and
plentifully
partaken
of
by
fat
mammas
,
who
looked
like
the
stout
people
who
come
on
in
pantomimes
for
the
sole
purpose
of
being
knocked
down
.
   
<EOS>
The
popular
Mr
Hilton
was
the
next
arrival
;
and
he
having
,
at
the
request
of
the
Miss
Crumptons
,
undertaken
the
office
of
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
,
the
quadrilles
commenced
with
considerable
spirit
.
<EOS>
The
young
men
by
the
door
gradually
advanced
into
the
middle
of
the
room
,
and
in
time
became
sufficiently
at
ease
to
consent
to
be
introduced
to
partners
.
 
<EOS>
The
writing
-
master
danced
every
set
,
springing
about
with
the
most
fearful
agility
,
and
his
wife
played
a
rubber
in
the
back
-
parlour
---
a
little
room
with
five
book
-
shelves
,
dignified
by
the
name
of
the
study
.
 
<EOS>
Setting
her
down
to
whist
was
a
half
-
yearly
piece
of
generalship
on
the
part
of
the
Miss
Crumptons
;
it
was
necessary
to
hide
her
somewhere
,
on
account
of
her
being
a
fright
.
   
<EOS>
The
interesting
Lavinia
Brook
Dingwall
was
the
only
girl
present
,
who
appeared
to
take
no
interest
in
the
proceedings
of
the
evening
.
<EOS>
In
vain
was
she
solicited
to
dance
;
in
vain
was
the
universal
homage
paid
to
her
as
the
daughter
of
a
member
of
parliament
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
equally
unmoved
by
the
splendid
tenor
of
the
inimitable
Lobskini
,
and
the
brilliant
execution
of
Miss
Laetitia
Parsons
,
whose
performance
of
"
The
Recollections
of
Ireland
"
was
universally
declared
to
be
almost
equal
to
that
of
Moscheles
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Not
even
the
announcement
of
the
arrival
of
Mr
Theodosius
Butler
could
induce
her
to
leave
the
corner
of
the
back

-

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Theodosius
,
"
said

Maria
Crumpton
,
after
that

had

the

company
,
"
I
must
introduce
you
to
our
new

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Theodosius
looked
as

he
cared
for
nothing

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
the
daughter
of
a
member
of

,
"
said
Maria
.
<EOS>
---
Theodosius
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
her
name
is
---
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Great
Heaven
!
"
poetically
exclaimed
Theodosius
,
in

low

.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Crumpton
commenced
the
introduction
in
due

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Brook
Dingwall
languidly
raised
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
Edward
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
with
a
half
-

,
on
seeing
the
well
-
known
nankeen
legs
.
   
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
as
Miss
Maria
Crumpton
possessed
no
remarkable
share
of

,
and
as
it
was
one
of
the
diplomatic

that
no

was

Miss
Lavinia
's

,
she

perfectly

of
the

of

;
and
therefore

Brook

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Edward
!
"
exclaimed
that
most
romantic

all

,

light

,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Edward
,
is

you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Theodosius
assured
the
dear
creature
,
in
the
most

manner
,
that
he
was
not
conscious
of
being
anybody
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
---
why
---
this
disguise
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Edward
M'Neville
Walter
,
what
have
I
not
suffered
on
your
account
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lavinia
,

me
,
"
replied
the
hero
,
in
his
most
poetic

.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
condemn
me
unheard
.
 
<EOS>
If
anything
that
emanates
from
the
soul
of
such
a
wretch
as
I
,
can
occupy
a
place
in
your

---
if
any
being
,
so
vile
,
deserve

notice
---
you
may
remember
that
I
once
published
a
pamphlet
(
and
paid
for

)
<EOS>
entitled
"
Considerations
on

of
Removing

Duty
on
Bees'-wax
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
I
do
---
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
sobbed

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
continued

,
"

a

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
---
he
was
!
"
reiterated

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew

,
"

,

;
"
I
knew
it
---
<EOS>
I
forwarded
him
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
wished
to
know

.
 
<EOS>
Could

?
 
<EOS>
Never
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
assumed
that
name
which
you
have
so
often

in

.
 
<EOS>
As

Walter
,
I

;

M'Neville
Walter

;

's

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

---
Theodosius
Butler
.
"
   
<EOS>

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
May

,
"

,
"

your

's

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

---

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
May

---

---

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

of

interesting
Butler
's

expressed
his

.
   
<EOS>
We
could

that

.
 
<EOS>
How
Mr
Theodosius
and
Miss

danced
,
and

,
and

---
how

Miss
Crumptons
were

thereat
.
 
<EOS>
How

writing
-

continued
to
frisk
about
with
one
-

,
and
how
his
wife
,
from

,

-

in
the

-

,
and

in

-

-

.
 
<EOS>
How

,

a

here
and

by

;
and

visitors
consumed
warm
water
disguised
with

,
and
dotted
with

,
under
the

of
negus
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
other

of
as
much
interest
<EOS>
,
however
,
we
pass
over
,
for
the
purpose
of
describing
a
scene
of
even
more

.
   
<EOS>
A

ball
,

Brook

,
Esq
,
MP
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

---
he

"
A

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

---

,

"
Miss
Crumpton
"

.
 
<EOS>
Permission

SANCTUM
;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
how

!
 
<EOS>
Even

.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Crumpton

.
 
<EOS>
She
hoped
Mrs
Brook
Dingwall
and
the
handsome
little
boy
were
in

.
   
<EOS>
They
were
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Brook
Dingwall
and

Frederick

at

.
   
<EOS>
"
Much

,

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
How
has

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

her

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

.
"
   
"
To

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
"
said

,
with

<EOS>
,
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
No
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless

!
 
<EOS>
Miss
Crumpton
,
you
look

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
"
Miss
Brook

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

?
"
   
"
Has

,

"
---

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Eloped
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Eloped
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Who
with
---
<EOS>
when
---
where
---
how
?
"
almost

.
   
<EOS>
The
natural
yellow
of
the
unfortunate
Maria
's
face
changed
to
all
the
hues
of
the

,
as

a
small

on

member
's

.
   
<EOS>
He
hurriedly
opened

.
 
<EOS>
A
letter
from
his
daughter
,
and
another
from
Theodosius
.
 
<EOS>
He
glanced
over
their
contents
---
"
Ere
this
reaches
you
,
far

---
appeal
to
feelings
---
love
to
distraction
---
bees'-wax
---
slavery
,
"
&
c
,
&
c.
 
<EOS>
He
dashed
his
hand
to
his

,
and
paced
the
room
with
fearfully
long
strides
,
to
the
great

of
the
precise
Maria
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
mind
;
from
this
time
forward
,
"
said
Mr
Brook
Dingwall
,
suddenly
stopping
at
the

,
and

upon

with

;
"
from
this
time
forward
,
I
never
will
,
under
any

whatever
,
permit
a
man
who
writes
pamphlets
to
enter
any
other
room
of
this
house
but
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
---
I
'll
allow
my
daughter
and
her
husband
one
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
a
-
year
,
and
never
see
their
faces
again
:
 
and
,
damme
!
<EOS>
ma'am
,
I
'll
bring
in
a
bill
for
the
abolition
of
finishing
-
schools
.
"
   
<EOS>
Some
time
has
elapsed
since
this
passionate
declaration
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Butler
are
at
present
rusticating
in
a
small
cottage
at
Ball's
-
pond
,
pleasantly
situated
in
the
immediate
vicinity
of
a
brick
-
field
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
no
family
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Theodosius
looks
very
important
,
and
writes
incessantly
;
but
,
in
consequence
of
a
gross
combination
on
the
part
of
publishers
,
none
of
his
productions
appear
in
print
.
 
<EOS>
His
young
wife
begins
to
think
that
ideal
misery
is
preferable
to
real
unhappiness
;
and
that
a
marriage
,
contracted
in
haste
,
and
repented
at
leisure
,
is
the
cause
of
more
substantial
wretchedness
than
she
ever
anticipated
.
   
<EOS>
On
cool
reflection
,
Cornelius
Brook
Dingwall
,
Esq
,
MP
,
was
reluctantly
compelled
to
admit
that
the
untoward
result
of
his
admirable
arrangements
was
attributable
,
not
to
the
Miss
Crumptons
,
but
his
own
diplomacy
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
consoles
himself
,
like
some
other
small
diplomatists
,
by
satisfactorily
proving
that
if
his
plans
did
not
succeed
,
they
ought
to
have
done
so
.
 
<EOS>
Minerva
House
is
IN
STATUS
QUO
,
and
"
The
Misses
Crumpton
"
remain
in
the
peaceable
and
undisturbed
enjoyment
of
all
the
advantages
resulting
from
their
Finishing
-
School
.
   
<EOS>
The
Tuggses
at
Ramsgate
Once
upon
a
time
there
dwelt
,
in
a
narrow
street
on
the
Surrey
side
of
the
water
,
within
three
minutes
'
walk
of
old
London
Bridge
,
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
---
a
little
dark
-
faced
man
,
with
shiny
hair
,
twinkling
eyes
,
short
legs
,
and
a
body
of
very
considerable
thickness
,
measuring
from
the
centre
button
of
his
waistcoat
in
front
,
to
the
ornamental
buttons
of
his
coat
behind
.
 
<EOS>
The
figure
of
the
amiable
Mrs
Tuggs
,
if
not
perfectly
symmetrical
,
was
decidedly
comfortable
;
and
the
form
of
her
only
daughter
,
the
accomplished
Miss
Charlotte
Tuggs
,
was
fast
ripening
into
that
state
of
luxuriant
plumpness
which
had
enchanted
the
eyes
,
and
captivated
the
heart
,
of
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
in
his
earlier
days
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
,
his
only
son
,
and
Miss
Charlotte
Tuggs
's
only
brother
,
was
as
differently
formed
in
body
,
as
he
was
differently
constituted
in
mind
,
from
the
remainder
of
his
family
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
that
elongation
in
his
thoughtful
face
,
and
that
tendency
to
weakness
in
his
interesting
legs
,
which
tell
so
forcibly
of
a
great
mind
and
romantic
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
The
slightest
traits
of
character
in
such
a
being
,
possess
no
mean
interest
to
speculative
minds
.
 
<EOS>
He
usually
appeared
in
public
,
in
capacious
shoes
with
black
cotton
stockings
;
and
was
observed
to
be
particularly
attached
to
a
black
glazed
stock
,
without
tie
or
ornament
of
any
description
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
perhaps
no
profession
,
however
useful
;
no
pursuit
,
however
meritorious
;
which
can
escape
the
petty
attacks
of
vulgar
minds
.
<EOS>
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
was
a
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
be
supposed
that
a
grocer
was
beyond
the
breath
of
calumny
;
but
no
---
the
neighbours
stigmatised
him
as
a
chandler
;
and
the
poisonous
voice
of
envy
distinctly
asserted
that
he
dispensed
tea
and
coffee
by
the
quartern
,
retailed
sugar
by
the
ounce
,
cheese
by
the
slice
,
tobacco
by
the
screw
,
and
butter
by
the
pat
.
 
<EOS>
These
taunts
,
however
,
were
lost
upon
the
Tuggses
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tuggs
attended
to
the
grocery
department
;
Mrs
Tuggs
to
the
cheesemongery
;
and
Miss
Tuggs
to
her
education
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
kept
his
father
's
books
,
and
his
own
counsel
.
   
<EOS>
One
fine
spring
afternoon
,
the
latter
gentleman
was
seated
on
a
tub
of
weekly
Dorset
,
behind
the
little
red
desk
with
a
wooden
rail
,
which
ornamented
a
corner
of
the
counter
;
when
a
stranger
dismounted
from
a
cab
,
and
hastily
entered
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
habited
in
black
cloth
,
and
bore
with
him
,
a
green
umbrella
,
and
a
blue
bag
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tuggs
?
"
said
the
stranger
,
inquiringly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
MY
name
is
Tuggs
,
"
replied
Mr
Simon
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
other
Mr
Tuggs
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
looking
towards
the
glass
door
which
led
into
the
parlour
behind
the
shop
,
and
on
the
inside
of
which
,
the
round
face
of
Mr
Tuggs
,
senior
,
was
distinctly
visible
,
peeping
over
the
curtain
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Simon
gracefully
waved
his
pen
,
as
if
in
intimation
of
his
wish
that
his
father
would
advance
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
with
considerable
celerity
,
removed
his
face
from
the
curtain
and
placed
it
before
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
come
from
the
Temple
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
bag
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
the
Temple
!
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
,
flinging
open
the
door
of
the
little
parlour
and
disclosing
Miss
Tuggs
in
perspective
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
the
Temple
!
"
said
Miss
Tuggs
and
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
at
the
same
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
the
Temple
!
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
turning
as
pale
as
a
Dutch
cheese
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
the
Temple
,
"
repeated
the
man
with
the
bag
;
"
from
Mr
Cower
's
,
the
solicitor
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tuggs
,
I
congratulate
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Ladies
,
I
wish
you
joy
of
your
prosperity
!
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
successful
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
man
with
the
bag
leisurely
divested
himself
of
his
umbrella
and
glove
,
as
a
preliminary
to
shaking
hands
with
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
Now
the
words
"
we
have
been
successful
,
"
had
no
sooner
issued
from
the
mouth
of
the
man
with
the
bag
,
than
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
rose
from
the
tub
of
weekly
Dorset
,
opened
his
eyes
very
wide
,
gasped
for
breath
,
made
figures
of
eight
in
the
air
with
his
pen
,
and
finally
fell
into
the
arms
of
his
anxious
mother
,
and
fainted
away
without
the
slightest
ostensible
cause
or
pretence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Water
!
"
screamed
Mrs
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
up
,
my
son
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Simon
!
<EOS>
dear
Simon
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
Miss
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
better
now
,
"
said
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
successful
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
as
corroborative
evidence
of
his
being
better
,
he
fainted
away
again
,
and
was
borne
into
the
little
parlour
by
the
united
efforts
of
the
remainder
of
the
family
,
and
the
man
with
the
bag
.
   
<EOS>
To
a
casual
spectator
,
or
to
any
one
unacquainted
with
the
position
of
the
family
,
this
fainting
would
have
been
unaccountable
.
 
<EOS>
To
those
who
understood
the
mission
of
the
man
with
the
bag
,
and
were
moreover
acquainted
with
the
excitability
of
the
nerves
of
Mr
Simon
Tuggs
,
it
was
quite
comprehensible
.
 
<EOS>
A
long
-
pending
lawsuit
respecting
the
validity
of
a
will
,
had
been
unexpectedly
decided
;
and
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
was
the
possessor
of
twenty
thousand
pounds
.
   
<EOS>
A
prolonged
consultation
took
place
,
that
night
,
in
the
little
parlour
---
a
consultation
that
was
to
settle
the
future
destinies
of
the
Tuggses
.
 
<EOS>
The
shop
was
shut
up
,
at
an
unusually
early
hour
;
and
many
were
the
unavailing
kicks
bestowed
upon
the
closed
door
by
applicants
for
quarterns
of
sugar
,
or
half
-
quarterns
of
bread
,
or
penn'orths
of
pepper
,
which
were
to
have
been
"
left
till
Saturday
,
"
but
which
fortune
had
decreed
were
to
be
left
alone
altogether
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
certainly
give
up
business
,
"
said
Miss
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
decidedly
,
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Simon
shall
go
to
the
bar
,
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
shall
always
sign
myself
"
Cymon
"
in
future
,
"
said
his
son
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
shall
call
myself
Charlotta
,
"
said
Miss
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
must
always
call
ME
"
Ma
,
"
and
father
"
Pa
,
"
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
Pa
must
leave
off
all
his
vulgar
habits
,
"
interposed
Miss
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
of
all
that
,
"
responded
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
complacently
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
at
that
very
moment
,
eating
pickled
salmon
with
a
pocket
-
knife
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
leave
town
immediately
,
"
said
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
concurred
that
this
was
an
indispensable
preliminary
to
being
genteel
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
then
arose
,
Where
should
they
go
?
   
<EOS>
"
Gravesend
?
"
<EOS>
mildly
suggested
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
was
unanimously
scouted
.
 
<EOS>
Gravesend
was
LOW
.
   
<EOS>
"
Margate
?
"
insinuated
Mrs
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
Worse
and
worse
<EOS>
---
nobody
there
,
but
tradespeople
.
   
<EOS>
"
Brighton
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
opposed
an
insurmountable
objection
.
<EOS>
All
the
coaches
had
been
upset
,
in
turn
,
within
the
last
three
weeks
;
each
coach
had
averaged
two
passengers
killed
,
and
six
wounded
;
and
,
in
every
case
,
the
newspapers
had
distinctly
understood
that
"
no
blame
whatever
was
attributable
to
the
coachman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ramsgate
?
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Cymon
,
thoughtfully
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
;
how
stupid
they
must
have
been
,
not
to
have
thought
of
that
before
!
<EOS>
Ramsgate
was
just
the
place
of
all
others
.
   
<EOS>
Two
months
after
this
conversation
,
the
City
of
London
Ramsgate
steamer
was
running
gaily
down
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
Her
flag
was
flying
,
<EOS>
her
band
was
playing
,
her
passengers
were
conversing
;
everything
about
her
seemed
gay
and
lively
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
No
wonder
---
the
Tuggses
were
on
board
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
in
a
bottle
-
green
great
-
coat
,
with
a
velvet
collar
of
the
same
,
and
a
blue
travelling
-
cap
with
a
gold
band
.
   
<EOS>
"
Soul
-
inspiring
,
"
replied
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
<EOS>
---
he
was
entered
at
the
bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
Soul
-
inspiring
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
morning
,
sir
!
"
said
a
stoutish
,
military
-
looking
gentleman
in
a
blue
surtout
buttoned
up
to
his
chin
,
and
white
trousers
chained
down
to
the
soles
of
his
boots
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
took
upon
himself
the
responsibility
of
answering
the
observation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heavenly
!
"
he
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
an
enthusiastic

of
the
beauties
of
Nature
,
sir
?
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Travelled
much
,
sir
?
"
inquired
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
"
replied
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
on
the
continent
,
of
course
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
,
"
replied
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
---
in
a
qualified
tone
,
as
if
he
wished
it
to
be
implied
that
he
had
gone
half
-
way
and
come
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
of
course
intend
your
son
to
make
the
grand
tour
,
sir
?
"
said
the
military
gentleman
,
addressing
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
did
not
precisely
understand
what
the
grand
tour
was
,
or
how
such
an
article
was
manufactured
,
he
replied
,
"
Of
course
.
"
 
<EOS>
Just
as
he
said
the
word
,
there
came
tripping
up
,
from
her
seat
at
the
stern
of
the
vessel
,
a
young
lady
in
a
puce
-
coloured
silk
cloak
,
and
boots
of
the
same
;
with
long
black

,
large
black

,
brief
petticoats
,
and
unexceptionable

.
   
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
young
lady
to
the
military

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Belinda
,
my
love
,
"
responded
the
military
gentleman
to
the
black
-
eyed
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
left
me
alone
so
long
for
?
"
said
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
stared
out
of
countenance
by
those
rude
young
men
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
stared
at
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
military
gentleman
,
with
an
emphasis
which
made
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
withdraw
his
eyes
from
the
young
lady
's

with
inconceivable

.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
young
men
---
where
?
"
and
the
military
gentleman
clenched
his
fist
,
and
glared
fearfully
on
the
cigar
-
smokers
around
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
calm
,
Walter
,
I
entreat
,
"
said
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
,
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
,
sir
,
"
interposed
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
ai
n't
worth
your
notice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
<EOS>
---
no
---
they
are
not
,
indeed
,
"
urged
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
WILL
be
calm
,
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
speak
truly
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
for
a
timely
remonstrance
,
which
may
have
spared
me
the
guilt
of
manslaughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Calming
his

,
the
military

wrung
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
by
the
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
sister
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
;
seeing
that
the
military
gentleman
was
casting
an
admiring
look
towards
Miss
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
wife
,
ma'am
---
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
"
said
the
military
gentleman
,
presenting
the
black
-
eyed
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
mother
,
ma'am
---
Mrs
Tuggs
,
"
said
Mr
Cymon
.
 
<EOS>
The
military
gentleman
and
his
wife
murmured
enchanting
courtesies
;
and
the
Tuggses
looked
as
unembarrassed
as
they
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
black
-
eyed
young
lady
,
after
they
had
sat
chatting
with
the
Tuggses
some
half
-
hour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
love
,
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
this
gentleman
(
with
an
inclination
of
the
head
towards
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
)
is
very
much
like
the
Marquis
Carriwini
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
me
,
very
!
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
struck
me
,
the
moment
I
saw
him
,
"
said
the
young
lady
,
gazing
intently
,
and
with
a

,
on
the
scarlet
