of
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
looked
at
everybody
;
and
finding
that
everybody
was
looking
at
him
,
appeared
to
feel
some
temporary
difficulty
in
disposing
of
his
eyesight
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
exactly
the
air
of
the
marquis
,
"
said
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
extraordinary
!
<EOS>
"
sighed
the
military
gentleman
's
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
the
marquis
,
sir
?
"
inquired
the
military
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
stammered
a
negative
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
did
,
"
continued
Captain
Walter
Waters
,
"
you
would
feel
how
much
reason
you
have
to
be
proud
of
the
resemblance
---
a
most
elegant
man
,
with
a
most
prepossessing
appearance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
---
he
is
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Belinda
Waters
energetically
.
 
<EOS>
As
her
eye
caught
that
of
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
she
withdrew
it
from
his
features
in
bashful
confusion
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
highly
gratifying
to
the
feelings
of
the
Tuggses
;
and
when
,
in
the
course
of
farther
conversation
,
it
was
discovered
that
Miss
Charlotta
Tuggs
was
the
FAC
SIMILE
of
a
titled
relative
of
Mrs
Belinda
Waters
,
and
that
Mrs
Tuggs
herself
was
the
very
picture
of
the
Dowager
Duchess
of
Dobbleton
,
their
delight
in
the
acquisition
of
so
genteel
and
friendly
an
acquaintance
,
knew
no
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
dignity
of
Captain
Walter
Waters
relaxed
,
to
that
degree
,
that
he
suffered
himself
to
be
prevailed
upon
by
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
to
partake
of
cold
pigeon
-
pie
and
sherry
,
on
deck
;
and
a
most
delightful
conversation
,
aided
by
these
agreeable
stimulants
,
was
prolonged
,
until
they
ran
alongside
Ramsgate
Pier
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
dear
!
"
said
Mrs
Captain
Waters
to
Miss
Charlotta
Tuggs
,
just
before
the
bustle
of
landing
commenced
;
"
we
shall
see
you
on
the
sands
in
the
morning
;
and
,
as
we
are
sure
to
have
found
lodgings
before
then
,
I
hope
we
shall
be
inseparables
for
many
weeks
to
come
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
hope
so
,
"
said
Miss
Charlotta
Tuggs
,
emphatically
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tickets
,
ladies
and
gen'lm'n
,
"
said
the
man
on
the
paddle
-
box
.
   
<EOS>
"
Want
a
porter
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
a
dozen
men
in
smock
-
frocks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
!
"
said
Captain
Waters
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Captain
Waters
---
"
good
-
bye
,
Mr
Cymon
!
"
<EOS>
and
with
a
pressure
of
the
hand
which
threw
the
amiable
young
man
's
nerves
into
a
state
of
considerable
derangement
,
Mrs
Captain
Waters
disappeared
among
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
A
pair
of
puce
-
coloured
boots
were
seen
ascending
the
steps
,
a
white
handkerchief
fluttered
,
a
black
eye
gleamed
.
 
<EOS>
The
Waterses
were
gone
,
and
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
was
alone
in
a
heartless
world
.
   
<EOS>
Silently
and
abstractedly
,
did
that
too
sensitive
youth
follow
his
revered
parents
,
and
a
train
of
smock
-
frocks
and
wheelbarrows
,
along
the
pier
,
until
the
bustle
of
the
scene
around
,
recalled
him
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
was
shining
brightly
;
the
sea
,
dancing
to
its
own
music
,
rolled
merrily
in
;
crowds
of
people
promenaded
to
and
fro
;
young
ladies
tittered
;
old
ladies
talked
;
nursemaids
displayed
their
charms
to
the
greatest
possible
advantage
;
and
their
little
charges
ran
up
and
down
,
and
to
and
fro
,
and
in
and
out
,
under
the
feet
,
and
between
the
legs
,
of
the
assembled
concourse
,
in
the
most
playful
and
exhilarating
manner
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
old
gentlemen
,
trying
to
make
out
objects
through
long
telescopes
;
and
young
ones
,
making
objects
of
themselves
in
open
shirt
-
collars
;
ladies
,
carrying
about
portable
chairs
,
and
portable
chairs
carrying
about
invalids
;
parties
,
waiting
on
the
pier
for
parties
who
had
come
by
the
steam
-
boat
;
and
nothing
was
to
be
heard
but
talking
,
laughing
,
welcoming
,
and
merriment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fly
,
sir
?
"
exclaimed
a
chorus
of
fourteen
men
and
six
boys
,
the
moment
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
at
the
head
of
his
little
party
,
set
foot
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
gen'lm'n
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
said
one
,
touching
his
hat
with
mock
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Werry
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
,
---
been
a
-
waitin
'
for
you
these
six
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
Jump
in
,
if
you
please
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nice
light
fly
and
a
fast
trotter
,
sir
,
"
said
another
:
 
"
fourteen
mile
a
hour
,
and
surroundin
'
objects
rendered
inwisible
by
ex
-
treme
welocity
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Large
fly
for
your
luggage
,
sir
,
"
cried
a
third
.
 
<EOS>
"
Werry
large
fly
here
,
sir
---
reg'lar
bluebottle
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
YOUR
fly
,
sir
!
"
shouted
another
aspiring
charioteer
,
mounting
the
box
,
and
inducing
an
old
grey
horse
to
indulge
in
some
imperfect
reminiscences
of
a
canter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
him
,
sir
!
<EOS>
---
temper
of
a
lamb
and
haction
of
a
steam
-
ingein
!
"
   
<EOS>
Resisting
even
the
temptation
of
securing
the
services
of
so
valuable
a
quadruped
as
the
last
named
,
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
beckoned
to
the
proprietor
of
a
dingy
conveyance
of
a
greenish
hue
,
lined
with
faded
striped
calico
;
and
,
the
luggage
and
the
family
having
been
deposited
therein
,
the
animal
in
the
shafts
,
after
describing
circles
in
the
road
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
at
last
consented
to
depart
in
quest
of
lodgings
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
many
beds
have
you
got
?
"
screamed
Mrs
Tuggs
out
of
the
fly
,
to
the
woman
who
opened
the
door
of
the
first
house
which
displayed
a
bill
intimating
that
apartments
were
to
be
let
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
many
did
you
want
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
was
,
of
course
,
the
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Three
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
step
in
,
ma'am
?
"
 
<EOS>
Down
got
Mrs
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
were
delighted
.
 
<EOS>
Splendid
view
of
the
sea
from
the
front
windows
 
---
charming
!
 
<EOS>
A
short
pause
.
 
<EOS>
Back
came
Mrs
Tuggs
again
.
<EOS>
---
One
parlour
and
a
mattress
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
the
devil
did
n't
they
say
so
at
first
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
rather
pettishly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
,
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wretches
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
nervous
Cymon
.
 
<EOS>
Another
bill
---
another
stoppage
.
 
<EOS>
Same
question
---
same
answer
---
similar
result
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
they
mean
by
this
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
thoroughly
out
of
temper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
,
"
said
the
placid
Mrs
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Orvis
the
vay
here
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
said
the
driver
,
by
way
of
accounting
for
the
circumstance
in
a
satisfactory
manner
;
and
off
they
went
again
,
to
make
fresh
inquiries
,
and
encounter
fresh
disappointments
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
grown
dusk
when
the
"
fly
"
---
the
rate
of
whose
progress
greatly
belied
its
name
---
after
climbing
up
four
or
five
perpendicular
hills
,
stopped
before
the
door
of
a
dusty
house
,
with
a
bay
window
,
from
which
you
could
obtain
a
beautiful
glimpse
of
the
sea
---
if
you
thrust
half
of
your
body
out
of
it
,
at
the
imminent
peril
of
falling
into
the
area
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tuggs
alighted
.
 
<EOS>
One
ground
-
floor
sitting
-
room
,
and
three
cells
with
beds
in
them
up
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
A
double
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
Family
on
the
opposite
side
.
 
<EOS>
Five
children
milk
-
and
-
watering
in
the
parlour
,
and
one
little
boy
,
expelled
for
bad
behaviour
,
screaming
on
his
back
in
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
terms
?
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
The
mistress
of
the
house
was
considering
the
expediency
of
putting
on
an
extra
guinea
;
so
,
she
coughed
slightly
,
and
affected
not
to
hear
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
terms
?
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
,
in
a
louder
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
Five
guineas
a
week
,
ma'am
,
WITH
attendance
,
"
replied
the
lodging
-
house
keeper
.
 
<EOS>
(
Attendance
means
the
privilege
of
ringing
the
bell
as
often
as
you
like
,
for
your
own
amusement
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Rather
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
,
ma'am
!
"
replied
the
mistress
of
the
house
,
with
a
benign
smile
of
pity
at
the
ignorance
of
manners
and
customs
,
which
the
observation
betrayed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
cheap
!
"
   
<EOS>
Such
an
authority
was
indisputable
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tuggs
paid
a
week
's
rent
in
advance
,
and
took
the
lodgings
for
a
month
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
hour
's
time
,
the
family
were
seated
at
tea
in
their
new
abode
.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
srimps
!
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
eyed
his
father
with
a
rebellious
scowl
,
as
he
emphatically
said
"
SHRIMPS
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
shrimps
,
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Srimps
or
shrimps
,
do
n't
much
matter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
pity
,
blended
with
malignity
,
in
Mr
Cymon
's
eye
,
as
he
replied
,
"
Do
n't
matter
,
father
!
 
<EOS>
What
would
Captain
Waters
say
,
if
he
heard
such
vulgarity
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
what
would
dear
<EOS>
Mrs
Captain
Waters
say
,
"
added
Charlotta
,
"
if
she
saw
mother
---
ma
,
I
mean
---
eating
them
whole
,
heads
and
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
bear
thinking
of
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Cymon
,
with
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
"
How
different
,
"
he
thought
,
"
from
the
Dowager
Duchess
of
Dobbleton
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
pretty
woman
,
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
is
she
not
,
Cymon
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Miss
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
A
glow
of
nervous
excitement
passed
over
the
countenance
of
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
as
he
replied
,
"
An
angel
of
beauty
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hallo
,
Cymon
,
my
boy
,
take
care
.
<EOS>
Married
lady
,
you
know
;
"
and
he
winked
one
of
his
twinkling
eyes
knowingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
exclaimed
Cymon
,
starting
up
with
an
ebullition
of
fury
,
as
unexpected
as
alarming
,
"
why
am
I
to
be
reminded
of
that
blight
of
my
happiness
,
and
ruin
of
my
hopes
?
 
<EOS>
Why
am
I
to
be
taunted
with
the
miseries
which
are
heaped
upon
my
head
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
enough
to
---
to
---
to
---
"
and
the
orator
paused
;
but
whether
for
want
of
words
,
or
lack
of
breath
,
was
never
distinctly
ascertained
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
impressive
solemnity
in
the
tone
of
this
address
,
and
in
the
air
with
which
the
romantic
Cymon
,
at
its
conclusion
,
rang
the
bell
,
and
demanded
a
flat
candlestick
,
which
effectually
forbade
a
reply
.
 
<EOS>
He
stalked
dramatically
to
bed
,
and
the
Tuggses
went
to
bed
too
,
half
an
hour
afterwards
,
in
a
state
of
considerable
mystification
and
perplexity
.
   
<EOS>
If
the
pier
had
presented
a
scene
of
life
and
bustle
to
the
Tuggses
on
their
first
landing
at
Ramsgate
,
it
was
far
surpassed
by
the
appearance
of
the
sands
on
the
morning
after
their
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
,
bright
,
clear
day
,
with
a
light
breeze
from
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
same
ladies
and
gentlemen
,
the
same
children
,
the
same
nursemaids
,
the
same
telescopes
,
the
same
portable
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
were
employed
in
needlework
,
or
watch
-
guard
making
,
or
knitting
,
or
reading
novels
;
the
gentlemen
were
reading
newspapers
and
magazines
;
the
children
were
digging
holes
in
the
sand
with
wooden
spades
,
and
collecting
water
therein
;
the
nursemaids
,
with
their
youngest
charges
in
their
arms
,
were
running
in
after
the
waves
,
and
then
running
back
with
the
waves
after
them
;
and
,
now
and
then
,
a
little
sailing
-
boat
either
departed
with
a
gay
and
talkative
cargo
of
passengers
,
or
returned
with
a
very
silent
and
particularly
uncomfortable
-
looking
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
never
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Tuggs
,
as
she
and
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
and
Miss
Charlotta
Tuggs
,
and
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
with
their
eight
feet
in
a
corresponding
number
of
yellow
shoes
,
seated
themselves
on
four
rush
-
bottomed
chairs
,
which
,
being
placed
in
a
soft
part
of
the
sand
,
<EOS>
forthwith
sunk
down
some
two
feet
and
a
half
---
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
never
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
,
by
an
exertion
of
great
personal
strength
,
uprooted
the
chairs
,
and
removed
them
further
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
I
'm
blessed
if
there
ai
n't
some
ladies
a
-
going
in
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
with
intense
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
pa
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
IS
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
sure
enough
,
four
young
ladies
,
each
furnished
with
a
towel
,
tripped
up
the
steps
of
a
bathing
-
machine
.
 
<EOS>
In
went
the
horse
,
floundering
about
in
the
water
;
round
turned
the
machine
;
down
sat
the
driver
;
and
presently
out
burst
the
young
ladies
aforesaid
,
with
four
distinct
splashes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
that
's
sing'ler
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
,
after
an
awkward
pause
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
coughed
slightly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
here
's
some
gentlemen
a
-
going
in
on
this
side
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Tuggs
,
in
a
tone
of
horror
.
   
<EOS>
Three
machines
---
three
horses
---
three
flounderings
---
three
turnings
round
---
three
splashes
---
three
gentlemen
,
disporting
themselves
in
the
water
like
so
many
dolphins
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
THAT
'S
sing'ler
!
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
again
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Charlotta
coughed
this
time
,
and
another
pause
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
agreeably
broken
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
,
dear
?
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
looking
for
you
,
all
the
morning
,
"
said
a
voice
to
Miss
Charlotta
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Captain
Waters
was
the
owner
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
?
"
said
Captain
Walter
Waters
,
all
suavity
;
and
a
most
cordial
interchange
of
greetings
ensued
.
   
<EOS>
"
Belinda
,
my
love
,
"
said
Captain
Walter
Waters
,
applying
his
glass
to
his
eye
,
and
looking
in
the
direction
of
the
sea
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Mrs
Captain
Waters
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
Harry
Thompson
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
said
Belinda
,
applying
her
glass
to
her
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bathing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
so
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
He
do
n't
see
us
,
does
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
think
he
does
"
replied
the
captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
,
how
very
singular
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
inquired
Belinda
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
Mary
Golding
,
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
---
<EOS>
where
?
"
 
<EOS>
(
Up
went
the
glass
again
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
the
captain
,
pointing
to
one
of
the
young
ladies
before
noticed
,
who
,
in
her
bathing
costume
,
looked
as
if
she
was
enveloped
in
a
patent
Mackintosh
,
of
scanty
dimensions
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
I
declare
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Captain
Waters
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
very
curious
we
should
see
them
both
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
the
captain
,
with
perfect
coolness
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
reg'lar
thing
here
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
"
whispered
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
to
his
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
it
is
,
"
whispered
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
in
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Queer
,
though
---
ai
n't
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
doing
with
yourself
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
lunch
at
Pegwell
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
that
very
much
indeed
,
"
interposed
Mrs
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
never
heard
of
Pegwell
;
but
the
word
"
lunch
"
had
reached
her
ears
,
and
it
sounded
very
agreeably
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
shall
we
go
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
captain
;
"
it
's
too
warm
to
walk
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
shay
?
"
suggested
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Chaise
,
"
whispered
Mr
Cymon
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
one
would
be
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
aloud
,
quite
unconscious
of
the
meaning
of
the
correction
.
 
<EOS>
"
However
,
two
shays
if
you
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
a
donkey
SO
much
,
"
said
Belinda
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
so
should
I
!
"
echoed
Charlotta
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
we
can
have
a
fly
,
"
suggested
the
captain
,
"
and
you
can
have
a
couple
of
donkeys
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
A
fresh
difficulty
arose
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Captain
Waters
declared
it
would
be
decidedly
improper
for
two
ladies
to
ride
alone
.
 
<EOS>
The
remedy
was
obvious
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
young
Mr
Tuggs
would
be
gallant
enough
to
accompany
them
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
blushed
,
smiled
,
looked
vacant
,
and
faintly
protested
that
he
was
no
horseman
.
 
<EOS>
The
objection
was
at
once
overruled
.
 
<EOS>
A
fly
was
speedily
found
;
and
three
donkeys
---
which
the
proprietor
declared
on
his
solemn
asseveration
to
be
"
three
parts
blood
,
and
the
other
corn
"
---
were
engaged
in
the
service
.
   
<EOS>
"
Kim
up
!
"
<EOS>
shouted
one
of
the
two
boys
who
followed
behind
,
to
propel
the
donkeys
,
when
Belinda
Waters
and
Charlotta
Tuggs
had
been
hoisted
,
and
pushed
,
and
pulled
,
into
their
respective
saddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hi
---
hi
---
hi
!
<EOS>
"
groaned
the
other
boy
behind
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
Away
went
the
donkey
,
with
the
stirrups
jingling
against
the
heels
of
Cymon
's
boots
,
and
Cymon
's
boots
nearly
scraping
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Way
---
way
!
 
<EOS>
Wo
---
o
---
<EOS>
o
---
!
"
cried
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
as
well
as
he
could
,
in
the
midst
of
the
jolting
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make
it
gallop
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
donkey
WILL
go
into
the
public
-
house
!
"
<EOS>
shrieked
Miss
Tuggs
in
the
rear
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hi
---
hi
---
hi
!
"
groaned
both
the
boys
together
;
and
on
went
the
donkeys
as
if
nothing
would
ever
stop
them
.
   
<EOS>
Everything
has
an
end
,
however
;
even
the
galloping
of
donkeys
will
cease
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
animal
which
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
bestrode
,
feeling
sundry
uncomfortable
tugs
at
the
bit
,
the
intent
of
which
he
could
by
no
means
divine
,
abruptly
sidled
against
a
brick
wall
,
and
expressed
his
uneasiness
by
grinding
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
's
leg
on
the
rough
surface
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Captain
Waters
's
donkey
,
apparently
under
the
influence
of
some
playfulness
of
spirit
,
rushed
suddenly
,
head
first
,
into
a
hedge
,
and
declined
to
come
out
again
:
 
and
the
quadruped
on
which
Miss
Tuggs
was
mounted
,
expressed
his
delight
at
this
humorous
proceeding
by
firmly
planting
his
fore
-
feet
against
the
ground
,
and
kicking
up
his
hind
-
legs
in
a
very
agile
,
but
somewhat
alarming
manner
.
   
<EOS>
This
abrupt
termination
to
the
rapidity
of
the
ride
,
naturally
occasioned
some
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
Both
the
ladies
indulged
in
vehement
screaming
for
several
minutes
;
and
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
besides
sustaining
intense
bodily
pain
,
had
the
additional
mental
anguish
of
witnessing
their
distressing
situation
,
without
having
the
power
to
rescue
them
,
by
reason
of
his
leg
being
firmly
screwed
in
between
the
animal
and
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
The
efforts
of
the
boys
,
however
,
assisted
by
the
ingenious
expedient
of
twisting
the
tail
of
the
most
rebellious
donkey
,
restored
order
in
a
much
shorter
time
than
could
have
reasonably
been
expected
,
and
the
little
party
jogged
slowly
on
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
let
'em
walk
,
"
said
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
cruel
to
overdrive
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Werry
well
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
boy
,
with
a
grin
at
his
companion
,
as
if
he
understood
Mr
Cymon
to
mean
that
the
cruelty
applied
less
to
the
animals
than
to
their
riders
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
lovely
day
,
dear
!
"
said
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
;
enchanting
,
dear
!
"
responded
Mrs
Captain
Waters
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
beautiful
prospect
,
Mr
Tuggs
!
"
   
Cymon
looked
full
in
Belinda
's
face
,
as
he
responded
---
"
Beautiful
,
indeed
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
lady
cast
down
her
eyes
,
and
suffered
the
animal
she
was
riding
to
fall
a
little
back
.
 
<EOS>
Cymon
Tuggs
instinctively
did
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
brief
silence
,
broken
only
by
a
sigh
from
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Cymon
,
"
said
the
lady
suddenly
,
in
a
low
tone
,
"
Mr
Cymon
---
I
am
another
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
expressed
his
perfect
concurrence
in
a
statement
which
it
was
impossible
to
controvert
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
been
---
"
resumed
Belinda
;
and
there
she
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
---
what
?
"
said
Mr
Cymon
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
torture
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
been
"
---
continued
Mrs
Captain
Waters
---
"
if
,
in
earlier
life
,
it
had
been
my
fate
to
have
known
,
and
been
beloved
by
,
a
noble
youth
---
a
kindred
soul
---
a
congenial
spirit
---
one
capable
of
feeling
and
appreciating
the
sentiments
<EOS>
which
---
"
   
"
Heavens
!
<EOS>
what
do
I
hear
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
!
<EOS>
can
I
believe
my
---
Come
up
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
This
last
unsentimental
parenthesis
was
addressed
to
the
donkey
,
who
,
with
his
head
between
his
fore
-
legs
,
appeared
to
be
examining
the
state
of
his
shoes
with
great
anxiety
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Hi
---
hi
---
<EOS>
hi
,
"
said
the
boys
behind
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
up
,
"
expostulated
Cymon
Tuggs
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hi
---
hi
---
<EOS>
hi
,
"
repeated
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
And
whether
it
was
that
the
animal
felt
indignant
at
the
tone
of
Mr
Tuggs
's
command
,
or
felt
alarmed
by
the
noise
of
the
deputy
proprietor
's
boots
running
behind
him
;
or
whether
he
burned
with
a
noble
emulation
to
outstrip
the
other
donkeys
;
certain
it
is
that
he
no
sooner
heard
the
second
series
of
"
hi
---
hi
's
,
"
than
he
started
away
,
with
a
celerity
of
pace
which
jerked
Mr
Cymon
's
hat
off
,
instantaneously
,
and
carried
him
to
the
Pegwell
Bay
hotel
in
no
time
,
where
he
deposited
his
rider
without
giving
him
the
trouble
of
dismounting
,
by
sagaciously
pitching
him
over
his
head
,
into
the
very
doorway
of
the
tavern
.
   
<EOS>
Great
was
the
confusion
of
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
when
he
was
put
right
end
uppermost
,
by
two
waiters
;
considerable
was
the
alarm
of
Mrs
Tuggs
in
behalf
of
her
son
;
agonizing
were
the
apprehensions
of
Mrs
Captain
Waters
on
his
account
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
speedily
discovered
,
however
,
that
he
had
not
sustained
much
more
injury
than
the
donkey
---
he
was
grazed
,
and
the
animal
was
grazing
---
and
then
it
WAS
a
delightful
party
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Tuggs
,
and
the
captain
,
had
ordered
lunch
in
the
little
garden
behind
:
 
---
small
saucers
of
large
shrimps
,
dabs
of
butter
,
crusty
loaves
,
and
bottled
ale
.
 
<EOS>
The
sky
was
without
a
cloud
;
there
were
flower
-
pots
and
turf
before
them
;
the
sea
,
from
the
foot
of
the
cliff
,
stretching
away
as
far
as
the
eye
could
discern
anything
at
all
;
<EOS>
vessels
in
the
distance
with
sails
as
white
,
and
as
small
,
as
nicely
-
got
-
up
cambric
handkerchiefs
.
 
<EOS>
The
shrimps
were
delightful
,
the
ale
better
,
and
the
captain
even
more
pleasant
than
either
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Captain
Waters
was
in
SUCH
spirits
after
lunch
!
<EOS>
---
chasing
,
first
the
captain
across
the
turf
,
and
among
the
flower
-
pots
;
and
then
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
;
and
then
Miss
Tuggs
;
and
laughing
,
too
,
quite
boisterously
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
captain
said
,
it
did
n't
matter
;
who
knew
what
they
were
,
there
?
 
<EOS>
For
all
the
people
of
the
house
knew
,
they
might
be
common
people
.
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
responded
,
"
To
be
sure
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
they
went
down
the
steep
wooden
steps
a
little
further
on
,
which
led
to
the
bottom
of
the
cliff
;
and
looked
at
the
crabs
,
and
the
seaweed
,
and
the
eels
,
till
it
was
more
than
fully
time
to
go
back
to
Ramsgate
again
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
ascended
the
steps
last
,
and
Mrs
Captain
Waters
last
but
one
;
and
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
discovered
that
the
foot
and
ankle
of
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
were
even
more
unexceptionable
than
he
had
at
first
supposed
.
   
<EOS>
Taking
a
donkey
towards
his
ordinary
place
of
residence
,
is
a
very
different
thing
,
and
a
feat
much
more
easily
to
be
accomplished
,
than
taking
him
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
requires
a
great
deal
of
foresight
and
presence
of
mind
in
the
one
case
,
to
anticipate
the
numerous
flights
of
his
discursive
imagination
;
whereas
,
in
the
other
,
all
you
have
to
do
,
is
,
to
hold
on
,
and
place
a
blind
confidence
in
the
animal
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
adopted
the
latter
expedient
on
his
return
;
and
his
nerves
were
so
little
discomposed
by
the
journey
,
that
he
distinctly
understood
they
were
all
to
meet
again
at
the
library
in
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
The
library
was
crowded
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
same
ladies
,
and
the
same
gentlemen
,
who
had
been
on
the
sands
in
the
morning
,
and
on
the
pier
the
day
before
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
young
ladies
,
in
maroon
-
coloured
gowns
and
black
velvet
bracelets
,
dispensing
fancy
articles
in
the
shop
,
and
presiding
over
games
of
chance
in
the
concert
-
room
.
<EOS>
There
were
marriageable
daughters
,
and
marriage
-
making
mammas
,
gaming
and
promenading
,
and
turning
over
music
,
and
flirting
.
<EOS>
There
were
some
male
beaux
doing
the
sentimental
in
whispers
,
and
others
doing
the
ferocious
in
moustache
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
Mrs
Tuggs
in
amber
,
Miss
Tuggs
in
sky
-
blue
,
Mrs
Captain
Waters
in
pink
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Captain
Waters
in
a
braided
surtout
;
there
was
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
in
pumps
and
a
gilt
waistcoat
;
there
was
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
in
a
blue
coat
and
a
shirt
-
frill
.
   
<EOS>
"
Numbers
three
,
eight
,
and
eleven
!
"
<EOS>
cried
one
of
the
young
ladies
in
the
maroon
-
coloured
gowns
.
   
<EOS>
"
Numbers
three
,
eight
,
and
eleven
!
"
echoed
another
young
lady
in
the
same
uniform
.
   
<EOS>
"
Number
three
's
gone
,
"
said
the
first
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Numbers
eight
and
eleven
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Numbers
eight
and
eleven
!
"
echoed
the
second
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Number
eight
's
gone
,
Mary
Ann
,
"
said
the
first
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Number
eleven
!
"
screamed
the
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
numbers
are
all
taken
now
,
ladies
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
The
representatives
of
numbers
three
,
eight
,
and
eleven
,
and
the
rest
of
the
numbers
,
crowded
round
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
throw
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
said
the
presiding
goddess
,
handing
the
dice
-
box
to
the
eldest
daughter
of
a
stout
lady
,
with
four
girls
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
profound
silence
among
the
lookers
-
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
Throw
,
Jane
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
stout
lady
.
 
<EOS>
An
interesting
display
of
bashfulness
---
<EOS>
a
little
blushing
in
a
cambric
handkerchief
---
a
whispering
to
a
younger
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amelia
,
my
dear
,
throw
for
your
sister
,
"
said
the
stout
lady
;
and
then
she
turned
to
a
walking
advertisement
of
Rowlands
'
Macassar
Oil
,
who
stood
next
her
,
and
said
,
"
Jane
is
so
VERY
modest
and
retiring
;
but
I
ca
n't
be
angry
with
her
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
An
artless
and
unsophisticated
girl
is
SO
truly
amiable
,
that
I
often
wish
Amelia
was
more
like
her
sister
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
whiskers
whispered
his
admiring
approval
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
!
"
said
the
stout
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Amelia
threw
---
eight
for
her
sister
,
ten
for
herself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nice
figure
,
Amelia
,
"
whispered
the
stout
lady
to
a
thin
youth
beside
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beautiful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
SUCH
a
spirit
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
like
you
in
that
respect
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
NOT
help
admiring
that
life
and
vivacity
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
(
a
sigh
)
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
make
poor
Jane
a
little
more
like
my
dear
Amelia
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
cordially
acquiesced
in
the
sentiment
;
both
he
,
and
the
individual
first
addressed
,
were
perfectly
contented
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
this
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
of
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
as
a
short
female
,
in
a
blue
velvet
hat
and
feathers
,
was
led
into
the
orchestra
,
by
a
fat
man
in
black
tights
and
cloudy
Berlins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Tippin
,
of
the
London
theatres
,
"
replied
Belinda
,
referring
to
the
programme
of
the
concert
.
   
<EOS>
The
talented
Tippin
having
condescendingly
acknowledged
the
clapping
of
hands
,
and
shouts
of
"
bravo
!
"
which
greeted
her
appearance
,
proceeded
to
sing
the
popular
cavatina
of
"
Bid
me
discourse
,
"
accompanied
on
the
piano
by
Mr
Tippin
;
after
which
,
Mr
Tippin
sang
a
comic
song
,
accompanied
on
the
piano
by
Mrs
Tippin
:
 
the
applause
consequent
upon
which
,
was
only
to
be
exceeded
by
the
enthusiastic
approbation
bestowed
upon
an
air
with
variations
on
the
guitar
,
by
Miss
Tippin
,
accompanied
on
the
chin
by
Master
Tippin
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
passed
the
evening
;
thus
passed
the
days
and
evenings
of
the
Tuggses
,
and
the
Waterses
,
for
six
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
Sands
in
the
morning
---
donkeys
at
noon
---
<EOS>
pier
in
the
afternoon
---
library
at
night
---
and
the
same
people
everywhere
.
   
<EOS>
On
that
very
night
six
weeks
,
the
moon
was
shining
brightly
over
the
calm
sea
,
which
dashed
against
the
feet
of
the
tall
gaunt
cliffs
,
with
just
enough
noise
to
lull
the
old
fish
to
sleep
,
without
disturbing
the
young
ones
,
when
two
figures
were
discernible
---
or
would
have
been
,
<EOS>
if
anybody
had
looked
for
them
---
seated
on
one
of
the
wooden
benches
which
are
stationed
near
the
verge
of
the
western
cliff
.
 
<EOS>
The
moon
had
climbed
higher
into
the
heavens
,
by
two
hours
'
journeying
,
since
those
figures
first
sat
down
---
and
yet
they
had
moved
not
.
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
of
loungers
had
thinned
and
dispersed
;
the
noise
of
itinerant
musicians
had
died
away
;
light
after
light
had
appeared
in
the
windows
of
the
different
houses
in
the
distance
;
blockade
-
man
after
blockade
-
man
had
passed
the
spot
,
wending
his
way
towards
his
solitary
post
;
and
yet
those
figures
had
remained
stationary
.
 
<EOS>
Some
portions
of
the
two
forms
were
in
deep
shadow
,
but
the
light
of
the
moon
fell
strongly
on
a
puce
-
coloured
boot
and
a
glazed
stock
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
and
Mrs
Captain
Waters
were
seated
on
that
bench
.
 
<EOS>
They
spoke
not
,
but
were
silently
gazing
on
the
sea
.
   
<EOS>
"
Walter
will
return
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
mournfully
breaking
silence
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
sighed
like
a
gust
of
wind
through
a
forest
of
gooseberry
bushes
,
as
he
replied
,
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
he
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Cymon
!
"
resumed
Belinda
,
"
the
chaste
delight
,
the
calm
happiness
,
of
this
one
week
of
Platonic
love
,
is
too
much
for
me
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cymon
was
about
to
suggest
that
it
was
too
little
for
him
,
but
he
stopped
himself
,
and
murmured
unintelligibly
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
to
think
that
even
this
gleam
of
happiness
,
innocent
as
it
is
,
"
exclaimed
Belinda
,
"
is
now
to
be
lost
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
not
say
for
ever
,
Belinda
,
"
exclaimed
the
excitable
Cymon
,
as
two
strongly
-
defined
tears
chased
each
other
down
his
pale
face
<EOS>
---
it
was
so
long
that
there
was
plenty
of
room
for
a
chase
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
say
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
,
"
replied
Belinda
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
urged
Cymon
,
"
<EOS>
oh
why
?
 
<EOS>
Such
Platonic
acquaintance
as
ours
is
so
harmless
,
that
even
your
husband
can
never
object
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
husband
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Belinda
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
little
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jealous
and
revengeful
;
ferocious
in
his
revenge
---
a
maniac
in
his
jealousy
!
 
<EOS>
Would
you
be
assassinated
before
my
eyes
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
,
in
a
voice
broken
by
emotion
,
expressed
his
disinclination
to
undergo
the
process
of
assassination
before
the
eyes
of
anybody
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
leave
me
,
"
said
Mrs
Captain
Waters
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
,
this
night
,
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
late
:
 
let
us
return
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
sadly
offered
the
lady
his
arm
,
and
escorted
her
to
her
lodgings
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
at
the
door
<EOS>
---
he
felt
a
Platonic
pressure
of
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
"
he
said
,
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
night
,
"
sobbed
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
paused
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
walk
in
,
sir
?
"
said
the
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tuggs
hesitated
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
hesitation
!
 
<EOS>
He
DID
walk
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
again
,
when
he
reached
the
drawing
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
replied
Belinda
;
"
and
,
if
at
any
period
of
my
life
,
I
---
Hush
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
lady
paused
and
stared
with
a
steady
gaze
of
horror
,
on
the
ashy
countenance
of
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
double
knock
at
the
street
-
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
husband
!
"
<EOS>
said
Belinda
,
as
the
captain
's
voice
was
heard
below
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
my
family
!
<EOS>
"
added
Cymon
Tuggs
,
as
the
voices
of
his
relatives
floated
up
the
staircase
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
curtain
!
 
<EOS>
The
curtain
!
"
<EOS>
gasped
Mrs
Captain
Waters
,
pointing
to
the
window
,
before
which
some
chintz
hangings
were
closely
drawn
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
done
nothing
wrong
,
"
said
the
hesitating
Cymon
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
curtain
!
"
reiterated
the
frantic
lady
:
 
"
you
will
be
murdered
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
last
appeal
to
his
feelings
was
irresistible
.
 
<EOS>
The
dismayed
Cymon
concealed
himself
behind
the
curtain
with
pantomimic
suddenness
.
   
<EOS>
Enter
the
captain
,
Joseph
Tuggs
,
Mrs
Tuggs
,
and
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
the
captain
,
"
Lieutenant
,
Slaughter
.
"
 
<EOS>
Two
iron
-
shod
boots
and
one
gruff
voice
were
heard
by
Mr
Cymon
to
advance
,
and
acknowledge
the
honour
of
the
introduction
.
 
<EOS>
The
sabre
of
the
lieutenant
rattled
heavily
upon
the
floor
,
as
he
seated
himself
at
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cymon
's
fears
almost
overcame
his
reason
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
brandy
,
my
dear
!
"
said
the
captain
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
a
situation
!
<EOS>
They
were
going
to
make
a
night
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
was
pent
up
behind
the
curtain
and
afraid
to
breathe
!
   
<EOS>
"
Slaughter
,
"
said
the
captain
,
"
a
cigar
?
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
never
could
smoke
without
feeling
it
indispensably
necessary
to
retire
,
immediately
,
and
never
could
smell
smoke
without
a
strong
disposition
to
cough
.
 
<EOS>
The
cigars
were
introduced
;
the
captain
was
a
professed
smoker
;
so
was
the
lieutenant
;
so
was
Joseph
Tuggs
.
 
<EOS>
The
apartment
was
small
,
the
door
was
closed
,
the
smoke
powerful
:
 
<EOS>
it
hung
in
heavy
wreaths
over
the
room
,
and
at
length
found
its
way
behind
the
curtain
.
 
<EOS>
Cymon
Tuggs
held
his
nose
,
his
mouth
,
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
of
no
use
---
out
came
the
cough
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
captain
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Miss
Tuggs
.
<EOS>
You
dislike
smoking
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
;
I
do
n't
indeed
,
"
said
Charlotta
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
makes
you
cough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
coughed
just
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
Captain
Waters
!
 
<EOS>
Lor
!
<EOS>
how
can
you
say
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Somebody
coughed
,
"
said
the
captain
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
thought
so
,
"
said
Slaughter
.
 
<EOS>
No
<EOS>
;
everybody
denied
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fancy
,
"
said
the
captain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Must
be
,
"
echoed
Slaughter
.
   
<EOS>
Cigars
resumed
---
more
smoke
---
another
cough
---
smothered
,
but
violent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damned
odd
!
"
said
the
captain
,
staring
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sing'ler
!
"
ejaculated
the
unconscious
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
.
   
<EOS>
Lieutenant
Slaughter
looked
first
at
one
person
mysteriously
,
then
at
another
:
 
then
,
laid
down
his
cigar
,
then
approached
the
window
on
tiptoe
,
and
pointed
with
his
right
thumb
over
his
shoulder
,
in
the
direction
of
the
curtain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Slaughter
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
captain
,
rising
from
table
,
"
what
do
you
mean
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
lieutenant
,
in
reply
,
drew
back
the
curtain
and
discovered
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
behind
it
:
 
pallid
with
apprehension
,
and
blue
with
wanting
to
cough
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
captain
,
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
see
?
<EOS>
Slaughter
,
your
sabre
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cymon
!
"
screamed
the
Tuggses
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
!
"
said
Belinda
.
   
<EOS>
"
Platonic
!
"
gasped
Cymon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
sabre
!
"
roared
the
captain
:
 
"
Slaughter
---
<EOS>
unhand
me
---
the
villain
's
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Murder
!
"
screamed
the
Tuggses
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
him
fast
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
faintly
articulated
Cymon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Water
!
"
exclaimed
Joseph
Tuggs
---
and
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
and
all
the
ladies
<EOS>
forthwith
fainted
away
,
and
formed
a
tableau
.
   
<EOS>
Most
willingly
would
we
conceal
the
disastrous
termination
of
the
six
weeks
'
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
A
troublesome
form
,
and
an
arbitrary
custom
,
however
,
prescribe
that
a
story
should
have
a
conclusion
,
in
addition
to
a
commencement
;
we
have
therefore
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
Lieutenant
Slaughter
brought
a
message
---
the
captain
brought
an
action
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Joseph
Tuggs
interposed
---
the
lieutenant
negotiated
.
<EOS>
When
Mr
Cymon
Tuggs
recovered
from
the
nervous
disorder
into
which
misplaced
affection
,
and
exciting
circumstances
,
had
plunged
him
,
he
found
that
his
family
had
lost
their
pleasant
acquaintance
;
that
his
father
was
minus
fifteen
hundred
pounds
;
and
the
captain
plus
the
precise
sum
.
 
<EOS>
The
money
was
paid
to
hush
the
matter
up
,
but
it
got
abroad
notwithstanding
;
and
there
are
not
wanting
some
who
affirm
that
three
designing
impostors
never
found
more
easy
dupes
,
than
did
Captain
Waters
,
Mrs
Waters
,
and
Lieutenant
Slaughter
,
in
the
Tuggses
at

.
   
<EOS>
Horatio
Sparkins
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
my
love
,
he
paid
Teresa
very
great
attention
on
the
last
assembly
night
,
"
said
Mrs
Malderton
,
addressing
her
spouse
,
who
,
after

of
the

in
the

,
was

,

;
---
"
very

;
and
I

again
,
every

ought

.
 
<EOS>
He
positively
must

down

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who

?
<EOS>
"

Malderton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

---

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Young
---

!
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Marianne
,

?
<EOS>
"

Mrs
Malderton
,

her
youngest

,
who
was

in

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
,
ma
,
"

Miss
Marianne
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
yes
,
to
be
sure
---
Horatio
Sparkins
,
"
said
Mrs
Malderton
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Decidedly
the
most
gentleman
-
like

man
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
in
the
beautifully
-

coat
he

the
other

,
he

like
---
like
---
"
   
"
Like
Prince
Leopold
,
ma
---
so

,
so
full

!
<EOS>
"
suggested
Marianne
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
should

,
my

,
"
resumed

Malderton
,
"
that
Teresa
is
now
eight
-
and
-

;
and
that
it
really
is
very
important
that
something
should
be
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Teresa
Malderton
was
a
very
little
girl
,
rather
fat
,
with
vermilion
cheeks
,
but
good
-
humoured
,
and
still
disengaged
,
<EOS>
although
,
to
do
her
justice
,
the
misfortune
arose
from
no
lack
of
perseverance
on
her
part
.
 
<EOS>
In
vain
had
she
flirted
for
ten
years
;
in
vain
had
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Malderton
assiduously
kept
up
an
extensive
acquaintance
among
the
young
eligible
bachelors
of
Camberwell
,
and
even
of
Wandsworth
and
Brixton
;
to
say
nothing
of
those
who
"
dropped
in
"
from
town
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Malderton
was
as
well
known
as
the
lion
on
the
top
of
Northumberland
House
,
and
had
an
equal
chance
of
"
going
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
sure
you
'd
like
him
,
"
continued
Mrs
Malderton
,
"
he
is
so
gentlemanly
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
clever
!
"
said
Miss
Marianne
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
has
such
a
flow
of
language
!
"
<EOS>
added
Miss
Teresa
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
a
great
respect
for
you
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Malderton
to
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Malderton
coughed
,
and
looked
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
I
'm
sure
he
's
very
much
attached
to
pa
's
society
,
"
said
Miss
Marianne
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
,
"
echoed
Miss
Teresa
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
he
said
as
much
to
me
in
confidence
,
"
observed
Mrs
Malderton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
returned
Mr
Malderton
,
somewhat
flattered
;
"
if
I
see
him
at
the
assembly
to
-
morrow
,
perhaps
I
'll
ask
him
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
he
knows
we
live
at
Oak
Lodge
,
Camberwell
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
---
and
that
you
keep
a
one
-
horse

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
about
it
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
,
composing
himself
for
a
nap
;
"
I
'll
see
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Malderton
was
a
man
whose
whole
scope
of
ideas
was
limited
to
Lloyd
's
,
the
Exchange
,
the
India
House
,
and
the
Bank
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
successful
speculations
had
raised
him
from
a
situation
of
obscurity
and
comparative
poverty
,
to
a
state
of
affluence
.
 
<EOS>
As
frequently
happens
in
such
cases
,
the
ideas
of
himself
and
his
family
became
elevated
to
an
extraordinary
pitch
as
their
means
increased
;
they
affected
fashion
,
taste
,
and
many
other
fooleries
,
in
imitation
of
their
betters
,
and
had
a
very
decided
and
becoming
horror
of
anything
which
could
,
by
possibility
,
be
considered
low
.
<EOS>
He
was
hospitable
from
ostentation
,
illiberal
from
ignorance
,
and
prejudiced
from
conceit
.
 
<EOS>
Egotism
and
the
love
of
display
induced
him
to
keep
an
excellent
table
:
 
convenience
,
and
a
love
of
good
things
of
this
life
,
ensured
him
plenty
of
guests
.
 
<EOS>
He
liked
to
have
clever
men
,
or
what
he
considered
such
,
at
his
table
,
because
it
was
a
great
thing
to
talk
about
;
but
he
never
could
endure
what
he
called
"
sharp
fellows
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Probably
,
he
cherished
this
feeling
out
of
compliment
to
his
two
sons
,
who
gave
their
respected
parent
no
uneasiness
in
that
particular
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
were
ambitious
of
forming
acquaintances
and
connexions
in
some
sphere
of
society
superior
to
that
in
which
they
themselves
moved
;
and
one
of
the
necessary
consequences
of
this
desire
,
added
to
their
utter
ignorance
of
the
world
beyond
their
own
small
circle
,
was
,
that
any
one
who
could
lay
claim
to
an
acquaintance
with
people
of
rank
and
title
,
had
a
sure
passport
to
the
table
at
Oak
Lodge
,
Camberwell
.
   
<EOS>
The
appearance
of
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
at
the
assembly
,
had
excited
no
small
degree
of
surprise
and
curiosity
among
its
regular
frequenters
.
 
<EOS>
Who
could
he
be
?
 
<EOS>
He
was
evidently
reserved
,
and
apparently
melancholy
.
 
<EOS>
Was
he
a
clergyman
?
---
<EOS>
He
danced
too
well
.
<EOS>
A
barrister
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
He
said
he
was
not
called
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
very
fine
words
,
and
talked
a
great
deal
.
 
<EOS>
Could
he
be
a
distinguished
foreigner
,
come
to
England
for
the
purpose
of
describing
the
country
,
its
manners
and
customs
;
and
frequenting
public
balls
and
public
dinners
,
with
the
view
of
becoming
acquainted
with
high
life
,
polished
etiquette
,
and
English
refinement
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
No
,
he
had
not
a
foreign
accent
.
 
<EOS>
Was
he
a
surgeon
,
a
contributor
to
the
magazines
,
a
writer
of
fashionable
novels
,
or
an
artist
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
No
;
to
each
and
all
of
these
surmises
,
there
existed
some
valid
objection
.
<EOS>
---
"
Then
,
"
said
everybody
,
"
he
must
be
SOMEBODY
.
"
<EOS>
---
"
I
should
think
he
must
be
,
"
reasoned
Mr
Malderton
,
within
himself
,
"
because
he
perceives
our
superiority
,
and
pays
us
so
much
attention
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
night
succeeding
the
conversation
we
have
just
recorded
,
was
"
assembly
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
double
-
fly
was
ordered
to
be
at
the
door
of
Oak
Lodge
at
nine
o'clock
precisely
.
 
<EOS>
The
Miss
Maldertons
were
dressed
in
sky
-
blue
satin
trimmed
with
artificial
flowers
;
and
Mrs
M
(
who
was
a
little
fat
woman
)
,
in
ditto
ditto
,
looked
like
her
eldest
daughter
multiplied
by
two
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Frederick
Malderton
,
the
eldest
son
,
in
full
-
dress
costume
,
was
the
very
BEAU
IDEAL
of
a
smart
waiter
;
and
Mr
Thomas
Malderton
,
the
youngest
,
with
his
white
dress
-
stock
,
blue
coat
,
bright
buttons
,
and
red
watch
-
ribbon
,
strongly
resembled
the
portrait
of
that
interesting
,
but
rash
young
gentleman
,
George
Barnwell
.
 
<EOS>
Every
member
of
the
party
had
made
up
his
or
her
mind
to
cultivate
the
acquaintance
of
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Teresa
,
of
course
,
was
to
be
as
amiable
and
interesting
as
ladies
of
eight
-
and
-
twenty
on
the
look
-
out
for
a
husband
,
usually
are
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Malderton
would
be
all
smiles
and
graces
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Marianne
would
request
the
favour
of
some
verses
for
her
album
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Malderton
would
patronise
the
great
unknown
by
asking
him
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
intended
to
ascertain
the
extent
of
his
information
on
the
interesting
topics
of
snuff
and
cigars
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Mr
Frederick
Malderton
himself
,
the
family
authority
on
all
points
of
taste
,
dress
,
and
fashionable
arrangement
;
who
had
lodgings
of
his
own
in
town
;
who
had
a
free
admission
to
Covent
-
garden
theatre
;
who
always
dressed
according
to
the
fashions
of
the
months
;
who
went
up
the
water
twice
a
-
week
in
the
season
;
and
who
actually
had
an
intimate
friend
who
once
knew
a
gentleman
who
formerly
lived
in
the
Albany
,
---
even
he
had
determined
that
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
must
be
a
devilish
good
fellow
,
and
that
he
would
do
him
the
honour
of
challenging
him
to
a
game
at
billiards
.
   
<EOS>
The
first
object
that
met
the
anxious
eyes
of
the
expectant
family
on
their
entrance
into
the
ball
-
room
,
was
the
interesting
Horatio
,
with
his
hair
brushed
off
his
forehead
,
and
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
ceiling
,
reclining
in
a
contemplative
attitude
on
one
of
the
seats
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
he
is
,
my
dear
,
"
whispered
Mrs
Malderton
to
Mr
Malderton
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
like
Lord
Byron
!
"
murmured
Miss
Teresa
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
Montgomery
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Miss
Marianne
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Or
the
portraits
of
Captain
Cook
!
"
suggested
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
---
do
n't
be
an
ass
!
"
<EOS>
said
his
father
,
who
checked
him
on
all
occasions
,
probably
with
a
view
to
prevent
his
becoming
"
sharp
"
---
which
was
very
unnecessary
.
   
<EOS>
The
elegant
Sparkins
attitudinised
with
admirable
effect
,
until
the
family
had
crossed
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
started
up
,
with
the
most
natural
appearance
of
surprise
and
delight
;
accosted
Mrs
Malderton
with
the
utmost
cordiality
;
saluted
the
young
ladies
in
the
most
enchanting
manner
;
bowed
to
,
and
shook
hands
with
Mr
Malderton
,
with
a
degree
of
respect
amounting
almost
to
veneration
;
and
returned
the
greetings
of
the
two
young
men
in
a
half
-
gratified
,
half
-
patronising
manner
,
which
fully
convinced
them
that
he
must
be
an
important
,
and
,
at
the
same
time
,
condescending
personage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Malderton
,
"
said
Horatio
,
after
the
ordinary
salutations
,
and
bowing
very
low
,
"
may
I
be
permitted
to
presume
to
hope
that
you
will
allow
me
to
have
the
pleasure
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
I
do
n't
THINK
I
am
engaged
,
"
said
Miss
Teresa
,
with
a
dreadful
affectation
of
indifference
---
<EOS>
"
but
,
really
---
so
many
---
"
   
Horatio
looked
handsomely
miserable
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
most
happy
,
"
simpered
the
interesting
Teresa
,
at
last
.
<EOS>
Horatio
's
countenance
brightened
up
,
like
an
old
hat
in
a
shower
of
rain
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
very
genteel
young
man
,
certainly
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
gratified
Mr
Malderton
,
as
the
obsequious
Sparkins
and
his
partner
joined
the
quadrille
which
was
just
forming
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
a
remarkably
good
address
,
"
said
Mr
Frederick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
is
a
prime
fellow
,
"
interposed
Tom
,
who
always
managed
to
put
his
foot
in
it
---
"
he
talks
just
like
an
auctioneer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
!
"
said
his
father
solemnly
,
"
I
think
I
desired
you
,
before
,
not
to
be
a
fool
.
"
 
<EOS>
Tom
looked
as
happy
as
a
cock
on
a
drizzly
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
delightful
!
"
said
the
interesting
Horatio
to
his
partner
,
as
they
promenaded
the
room
at
the
conclusion
of
the
set
---
"
how
delightful
,
how
refreshing
it
is
,
to
retire
from
the
cloudy
storms
,
the
vicissitudes
,
and
the
troubles
,
of
life
,
even
if
it
be
but
for
a
few
short
fleeting
moments
:
 
and
to
spend
those
moments
,
fading
and
evanescent
though
they
be
,
in
the
delightful
,
the
blessed
society
of
one
individual
---
whose
frowns
would
be
death
,
whose
coldness
would
be
madness
,
whose
falsehood
would
be
ruin
,
whose
constancy
would
be
bliss
;
the
possession
of
whose
affection
would
be
the
brightest
and
best
reward
that
Heaven
could
bestow
on
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
feeling
!
<EOS>
what
sentiment
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Miss
Teresa
,
as
she
leaned
more
heavily
on
her
companion
's
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
enough
---
enough
!
"
resumed
the
elegant
Sparkins
,
with
a
theatrical
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
said
?
<EOS>
what
have
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
to
do
with
sentiments
like
these
!
 
<EOS>
Miss
Malderton
"
---
here
he
stopped
short
---
"
may
I
hope
to
be
permitted
to
offer
the
humble
tribute
of
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Really
,
Mr
Sparkins
,
"
returned
the
enraptured
Teresa
,
blushing
in
the
sweetest
confusion
,
"
I
must
refer
you
to
papa
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
can
,
without
his
consent
,
venture
to
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Surely
he
can
not
object
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
indeed
,
you
know
him
not
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Miss
Teresa
,
<EOS>
well
knowing
there
was
nothing
to
fear
,
but
wishing
to
make
the
interview
resemble
a
scene
in
some
romantic
novel
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
can
not
object
to
my
offering
you
a
glass
of
negus
,
"
returned
the
adorable
Sparkins
,
with
some
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
<EOS>
thought
the
disappointed
Teresa
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
fuss
about
nothing
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
give
me
the
greatest
pleasure
,
sir
,
to
see
you
to
dinner
at
Oak
Lodge
,
Camberwell
,
on
Sunday
next
at
five
o'clock
,
if
you
have
no
better
engagement
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
,
at
the
conclusion
of
the
evening
,
as
he
and
his
sons
were
standing
in
conversation
with
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
.
   
<EOS>
Horatio
bowed
his
acknowledgments
,
and
accepted
the
flattering
invitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
confess
,
"
continued
the
father
,
offering
his
snuff
-
box
to
his
new
acquaintance
,
"
that
I
do
n't
enjoy
these
assemblies
half
so
much
as
the
comfort
<EOS>
---
I
had
almost
said
the
luxury
---
of
Oak
Lodge
.
<EOS>
They
have
no
great
charms
for
an
elderly
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
after
all
,
sir
,
what
is
man
?
"
said
the
metaphysical
Sparkins
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
what
is
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
very
true
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
;
"
very
true
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
know
that
we
live
and
breathe
,
"
continued
Horatio
;
"
that
we
have
wants
and
wishes
,
desires
and
appetites
---
"
   
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Frederick
Malderton
,
looking
profound
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
we
know
that
we
exist
,
"
repeated
Horatio
,
raising
his
voice
,
"
but
there
we
stop
;
there
,
is
an
end
to
our
knowledge
;
there
,
is
the
summit
of
our
attainments
;
there
,
is
the
termination
of
our
ends
.
 
<EOS>
What
more
do
we
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Mr
Frederick
---
than
whom
no
one
was
more
capable
of
answering
for
himself
in
that
particular
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
about
to
hazard
something
,
but
,
fortunately
for
his
reputation
,
he
caught
his
father
's
angry
eye
,
and
slunk
off
like
a
puppy
convicted
of
petty
larceny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
the
elder
,
as
they
were
returning
home
in
the
fly
,
"
that
Mr
Sparkins
is
a
wonderful
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
Such
surprising
knowledge
!
<EOS>
such
extraordinary
information
!
<EOS>
and
such
a
splendid
mode
of
expressing
himself
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
must
be
somebody
in
disguise
,
"
said
Miss
Marianne
.
<EOS>
"
How
charmingly
romantic
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
talks
very
loud
and
nicely
,
"
timidly
observed
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
exactly
understand
what
he
means
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
almost
begin
to
despair
of
your
understanding
anything
,
Tom
,
"
said
his
father
,
who
,
of
course
,
had
been
much
enlightened
by
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
's
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
strikes
me
,
Tom
,
"
said
Miss
Teresa
,
"
that
you
have
made
yourself
very
ridiculous
this
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
,
"
cried
everybody
---
and
<EOS>
the
unfortunate
Tom
reduced
himself
into
the
least
possible
space
.
 
<EOS>
That
night
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Malderton
had
a
long
conversation
respecting
their
daughter
's
prospects
and
future
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Teresa
went
to
bed
,
considering
whether
,
in
the
event
of
her
marrying
a
title
,
she
could
conscientiously
encourage
the
visits
of
her
present
associates
;
and
dreamed
,
all
night
,
of
disguised
noblemen
,
large
routs
,
ostrich
plumes
,
bridal
favours
,
and
Horatio
Sparkins
.
   
<EOS>
Various
surmises
were
hazarded
on
the
Sunday
morning
,
as
to
the
mode
of
conveyance
which
the
anxiously
-
expected
Horatio
would
adopt
.
 
<EOS>
Did
he
keep
a
gig
?
---
was
it
possible
he
could
come
on
horseback
?
<EOS>
---
or
would
he
patronize
the
stage
?
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
other
various
conjectures
of
equal
importance
,
engrossed
the
attention
of
Mrs
Malderton
and
her
daughters
during
the
whole
morning
after
church
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
my
dear
,
it
's
a
most
annoying
thing
that
that
vulgar
brother
of
yours
should
have
invited
himself
to
dine
here
to
-
day
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
to
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
account
of
Mr
Sparkins
's
coming
down
,
I
purposely
abstained
from
asking
any
one
but
Flamwell
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
to
think
of
your
brother
---
a
tradesman
<EOS>
---
it
's
insufferable
!
 
<EOS>
I
declare
I
would
n't
have
him
mention
his
shop
,
before
our
new
guest
---
no
,
not
for
a
thousand
pounds
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
care
if
he
had
the
good
sense
to
conceal
the
disgrace
he
is
to
the
family
;
but
he
's
so
fond
of
his
horrible
business
,
that
he
WILL
let
people
know
what
he
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jacob
Barton
,
the
individual
alluded
to
,
was
a
large
grocer
;
so
vulgar
,
and
so
lost
to
all
sense
of
feeling
,
that
he
actually
never
scrupled
to
avow
that
he
was
n't
above
his
business
:
 
<EOS>
"
he
'd
made
his
money
by
it
,
and
he
did
n't
care
who
know'd
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Flamwell
,
my
dear
fellow
,
how
d'ye
do
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Malderton
,
as
a
little
spoffish
man
,
with
green
spectacles
,
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
You
got
my
note
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
did
;
and
here
I
am
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
happen
to
know
this
Mr
Sparkins
by
name
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
everybody
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flamwell
was
one
of
those
gentlemen
of
remarkably
extensive
information
whom
one
occasionally
meets
in
society
,
who
pretend
to
know
everybody
,
but
in
reality
know
nobody
.
 
<EOS>
At
Malderton
's
,
where
any
stories
about
great
people
were
received
with
a
greedy
ear
,
he
was
an
especial
favourite
;
and
,
knowing
the
kind
of
people
he
had
to
deal
with
,
he
carried
his
passion
of
claiming
acquaintance
with
everybody
,
to
the
most
immoderate
length
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
rather
a
singular
way
of
telling
his
greatest
lies
in
a
parenthesis
,
and
with
an
air
of
self
-
denial
,
as
if
he
feared
being
thought
egotistical
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
I
do
n't
know
him
by
that
name
,
"
returned
Flamwell
,
in
a
low
tone
,
and
with
an
air
of
immense
importance
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
<EOS>
I
know
him
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
Is
he
tall
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Middle
-
sized
,
"
said
Miss
Teresa
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
black
hair
?
"
inquired
Flamwell
,
hazarding
a
bold
guess
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
Miss
Teresa
,
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
a
snub
nose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
disappointed
Teresa
,
"
he
has
a
Roman
nose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
a
Roman
nose
,
did
n't
I
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Flamwell
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
an
elegant
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
remarkably
prepossessing
manners
?
"
   
"
Oh
,
yes
!
"
said
all
the
family
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
thought
you
knew
him
,
if
he
was
anybody
,
"
triumphantly
exclaimed
Mr
Malderton
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
d'ye
think
he
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
from
your
description
,
"
said
Flamwell
,
ruminating
,
and
sinking
his
voice
,
almost
to
a
whisper
,
"
he
bears
a
strong
resemblance
to
the
Honourable
Augustus
Fitz
-
Edward
Fitz
-
John
Fitz
-
Osborne
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
very
talented
young
man
,
and
rather
eccentric
.
<EOS>
It
's
extremely
probable
he
may
have
changed
his
name
for
some
temporary
purpose
.
"
   
<EOS>
Teresa
's
heart
beat
high
.
 
<EOS>
Could
he
be
the
Honourable
Augustus
Fitz
-
Edward
Fitz
-
John
Fitz
-
Osborne
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
name
to
be
elegantly
engraved
upon
two
glazed
cards
,
tied
together
with
a
piece
of
white
satin
ribbon
!
 
<EOS>
"
The
Honourable
Mrs
Augustus
Fitz
-
Edward
Fitz
-
John
Fitz
-
Osborne
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
thought
was
transport
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
five
minutes
to
five
,
"
said
Mr
Malderton
,
looking
at
his
watch
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
's
not
going
to
disappoint
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
he
is
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Teresa
,
as
a
loud
double
-
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
endeavoured
to
look
---
as
people
when
they
particularly
expect
a
visitor
always
do
---
as
if
they
were
perfectly
unsuspicious
of
the
approach
of
anybody
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
-
door
opened
---
"
Mr
Barton
!
"
said
the
servant
.
   
<EOS>
"
Confound
the
man
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
Malderton
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
my
dear
sir
,
how
d'ye
do
!
 
<EOS>
Any
news
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
no
,
"
returned
the
grocer
,
in
his
usual
bluff
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
none
partickler
.
 
<EOS>
None
that
I
am
much
aware
of
.
 
<EOS>
How
d'ye
do
,
gals
and
boys
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flamwell
,
sir
---
glad
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Mr
Sparkins
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
who
had
been
looking
out
at
the
window
,
"
on
SUCH
a
black
horse
!
"
 
<EOS>
There
was
Horatio
,
sure
enough
,
on
a
large
black
horse
,
curvetting
and
prancing
along
,
like
an
Astley
's
supernumerary
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
great
deal
of
reining
in
,
and
pulling
up
,
with
the
accompaniments
of
snorting
,
rearing
,
and
kicking
,
the
animal
consented
to
stop
at
about
a
hundred
yards
from
the
gate
,
where
Mr
Sparkins
dismounted
,
and
confided
him
to
the
care
of
Mr
Malderton
's
groom
.
 
<EOS>
The
ceremony
of
introduction
was
gone
through
,
in
all
due
form
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flamwell
looked
from
behind
his
green
spectacles
at
Horatio
with
an
air
of
mysterious
importance
;
and
the
gallant
Horatio
looked
unutterable
things
at
Teresa
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
the
Honourable
Mr
Augustus
What's
-
his
-
name
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mrs
Malderton
to
Flamwell
,
as
he
was
escorting
her
to
the
dining
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
---
at
least
not
exactly
,
"
returned
that
great
authority
---
"
not
exactly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
IS
he
then
?
"
   
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
said
Flamwell
,
nodding
his
head
with
a
grave
air
,
importing
that
he
knew
very
well
;
but
was
prevented
,
by
some
grave
reasons
of
state
,
from
disclosing
the
important
secret
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
be
one
of
the
ministers
making
himself
acquainted
with
the
views
of
the
people
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Sparkins
,
"
said
the
delighted
Mrs
Malderton
,
"
pray
divide
the
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
John
,
put
a
chair
for
the
gentleman
between
Miss
Teresa
and
Miss
Marianne
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
a
man
who
,
on
ordinary
occasions
,
acted
as
half
-
groom
,
half
-
gardener
;
but
who
,
as
it
was
important
to
make
an
impression
on
Mr
Sparkins
,
had
been
forced
into
a
white
neckerchief
and
shoes
,
and
touched
up
,
and
brushed
,
to
look
like
a
second
footman
.
   
<EOS>
The
dinner
was
excellent
;
Horatio
was
most
attentive
to
Miss
Teresa
,
and
every
one
felt
in
high
spirits
,
except
Mr
Malderton
,
who
,
knowing
the
propensity
of
his
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Mr
Barton
,
endured
that
sort
of
agony
which
the
newspapers
inform
us
is
experienced
by
the
surrounding
neighbourhood
when
a
pot
-
boy
hangs
himself
in
a
hay
-
loft
,
and
which
is
"
much
easier
to
be
imagined
than
described
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
your
friend
,
Sir
Thomas
Noland
,
lately
,
Flamwell
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Malderton
,
casting
a
sidelong
look
at
Horatio
,
to
see
what
effect
the
mention
of
so
great
a
man
had
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
---
not
very
lately
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Lord
Gubbleton
the
day
before
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
his
lordship
is
very
well
?
"
said
Malderton
,
in
a
tone
of
the
greatest
interest
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
scarcely
necessary
to
say
that
,
until
that
moment
,
he
had
been
quite
innocent
of
the
existence
of
such
a
person
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
;
he
was
very
well
---
very
well
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
devilish
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
him
in
the
City
,
and
had
a
long
chat
with
him
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
'm
rather
intimate

.
 
<EOS>
I
could

to
talk

him
as
long
as
I
could
wish
,
though
,
because

was
on

a

,
a

,

a

,

,

I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know

,
"
returned

host
,
consequentially
---
in

Flamwell
himself
.
<EOS>
---
"
He
has
a

business
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Talking

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
A

,
Malderton

---
"
   
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,
"

"

"
   
<EOS>
"
FLOURY
,

"

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

,

;
"
says

,
how

?
 
<EOS>
So

,
jokingly
<EOS>
---
you

---

,

never

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
"
   
"
Mr

,
"
said

,

"
a

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Happy

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
were

,
"
resumed

,

's

---
"

were

the

about

of

.
 
<EOS>
Your

struck

very

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
me
,
"
said
Mr
Frederick
.
 
<EOS>
Horatio
made

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
what
is
your

of
woman
,
Mr
Sparkins
?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

simpered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Man
,
"
replied
Horatio
,
"
man
,
whether

ranged

bright
,
gay
,

of

second

,
or
the
more

,

,
and
<EOS>
I

,
commonplace

,
to

,
in

;
man
,
under
any

,
or

---
whether

were

the

of

,

of
a

---
man
,
without
woman
,

---
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Horatio

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

---
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
What
!
"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Never
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,

,
"

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Horatio
,
who
became

,

,
as

saw

female

the
family
listening
in

---
"
what
!
 
<EOS>
Is
effect
the
consequence
of

?
 
<EOS>
Is

the

of
effect
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
point
,
"
said
Flamwell
.
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,

is

of

,
and

does

,
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
,
"
said

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
At

,

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"
said

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
thought

;
"
<EOS>
but

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mrs

to

,
as

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
's
quite
a
love
!
"
<EOS>
said

young

together
;
"
he
talks
like
an

.
 
<EOS>
He
must
have
seen
a
great
deal
of
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
being
left
to
themselves
,
a

,
during
which
everybody
looked
very
grave
,
as
if

were

.
 
<EOS>
Flamwell
,
who
had

to
find

who

what
<EOS>
Mr

really

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"

have

?
 
<EOS>
I

,
myself
---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-

!
"

;
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nearly
all

,
"
returned

.
   
<EOS>
The

was
thus
pretty
well

in

of
Mr
Flamwell
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
gentleman
"
about

be
called
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
like
to

a

,
"
said
Tom
,
speaking
for
the
first

,
and
looking

to

who
would

.
   
<EOS>
No

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

n't

,
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
,

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray

,

by

you

,
and
do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Barton
resumed
---
"
For
if
a
man
's
above
his
business
---
"
   
The

,
and
did

of

,
in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

,

,
"

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

;
since

,

,
I

,
"

Horatio
,
<EOS>
slightly

;
no

,
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,

,
and

he

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
no

,
"
returned

.
   
<EOS>
The
remainder
of
the
evening
passed
away
most
delightfully
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Malderton
,
relieved
from
his

by
the
circumstance
of
Mr
Barton
's
falling
into

,
was
as
affable
and

as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Teresa
played
the
"
Fall
of
Paris
,
"
as
Mr
Sparkins
declared
,
in
a
most
masterly
manner
,
and
both
of
them
,
assisted
by
Mr
Frederick
,
tried
over
glees
and
trios
without
number
;
they
having
made
the
pleasing
discovery
that
their
voices
harmonised
beautifully
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
they
all
sang
the
first
part
;
and
Horatio
,
in
addition
to
the
slight
drawback
of
having
no
ear
,
was
perfectly
innocent
of
knowing
a
note
of
music
;
still
,
they
passed
the
time
very
agreeably
,
and
it
was
past
twelve
o'clock
before
Mr
Sparkins
ordered
the
mourning
-
coach
-
looking
steed
to
be
brought

---
an

which
was
only
complied
with
,
on
the
distinct
understanding
that
he
was
to
repeat
his
visit
on
the
following
Sunday
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
perhaps
,
Mr
Sparkins
will
form
one
of
our
party
to
-
morrow
evening
?
"
suggested
Mrs
M.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Malderton
intends
taking
the
girls
to
see
the
pantomime
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkins
bowed
,
and
promised
to
join
the
party
in
box
48
,
in
the
course
of
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
tax
you
for
the
morning
,
"
said
Miss
Teresa
,
bewitchingly
;
"
for
ma
is
going
to
take
us
to
all
sorts
of
places
,
shopping
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
gentlemen
have
a
great
horror
of
that
employment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkins
bowed
again
,
and
declared
that
he
should
be
delighted
,
but
business
of
importance
occupied
him
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Flamwell
looked
at
Malderton
significantly
.
<EOS>
---
"
It
's
term
time
!
"
<EOS>
he
whispered
.
   
<EOS>
At
twelve
o'clock
on
the
following
morning
,
the
"
fly
"
was
at
the
door
of
Oak
Lodge
,
to
convey
Mrs
Malderton
and
her
daughters
on
their

for
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
to
dine
and
dress
for
the
play
at
a
friend
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
driving
thither
with
their
band
-
boxes
,
they
departed
on
their
first
errand
to
make
some
purchases
at
Messrs.
Jones
,
Spruggins
,
and
Smith
's
,
of
Tottenham
-
court
-
road
;
after
which
,
they
were
to
go
to
Redmayne
's
in
Bond
-
street
;
thence
,
to
innumerable
places
that
no
one
ever
heard
of
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
beguiled
the
tediousness
of
the
ride
by
eulogising
Mr
Horatio
Sparkins
,
scolding
their
mamma
for
taking
them
so
far
to
save
a
shilling
,
and
wondering
whether
they
should
ever
reach
their
destination
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
vehicle
stopped
before
a
dirty
-
looking
ticketed
linen
-
draper
's
shop
,
with
goods
of
all
kinds
,
and
labels
of
all
sorts
and
sizes
,
in
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
dropsical
figures
of
seven
with
a
little
three
-
farthings
in
the
corner
;
"
perfectly
invisible
to
the
naked
eye
;
"
three
hundred
and
fifty
thousand
ladies
'
boas
,
FROM
one
shilling
and
a
penny
halfpenny
;
real
French
kid
shoes
,
at
two
and
ninepence
per
pair
;
green
parasols
,
at
an
equally
cheap
rate
;
and
"
every
description
of
goods
,
"
as
the
proprietors
said
---
and
they
must
know
best
---
"
fifty
per
cent
.
<EOS>
under
cost
price
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
ma
,
what
a
place
you
have
brought
us
to
!
"
said
Miss
Teresa
;
"

WOULD

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
what

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Pray

,
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
What

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

;

,

,

<EOS>
Horatio
Sparkins
!
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
draw

veil
,
"
as

-

say
,
over

.
 
<EOS>
The
mysterious
,
philosophical
,
romantic
,
metaphysical
Sparkins
---
he
who
,
to
the
interesting
Teresa
,
seemed
like
the
embodied
idea
of
the
young

and

in
blue

dressing

,
and
ditto

,
of
whom

had
read

dreamed
,
but
had
never

behold
,
was

into
Mr
Samuel
Smith
,
the
assistant
at
a
"
cheap
shop
;
"
the

in
a

'

.
 
<EOS>
The
dignified
evanishment
of
the
hero
of
Oak
Lodge
,
on
this

,
could
only

equalled
by
that
of
a
furtive
dog
with
a
considerable

at

.
 
<EOS>
All
the
hopes
of
the
Maldertons
were
destined
at
once
to
melt
away
,
like
the
lemon
ices
at
a
Company
's
dinner
;
Almack
's
was
still
to
them
as
distant
as
the
North

;
and
Miss
Teresa
had
as
much
chance
of
a
husband
as
Captain
Ross
had
of
the
north
-
west

.
   
<EOS>
Years
have
elapsed
since
the
occurrence
of
this
dreadful
morning
.
<EOS>
The
daisies
have
thrice
bloomed
on
Camberwell
-
green
;
the
sparrows
have
thrice
repeated
their
vernal

in
Camberwell
-
grove
;
but
the
Miss
Maldertons
are
still

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Teresa
's
case
is
more
desperate
than
ever
;
but
Flamwell
is
yet
in
the
zenith

;
and
the

have
the
same

for

,

LOW
.
   
<EOS>
The
Black
Veil
<EOS>
One
winter
's
evening
,
towards
the
close
of
the
year
1800
,
or
within
a
year
or
two
of
that
time
,
a
young
medical
practitioner
,
recently
established
in
business
,
was
seated
by
a
cheerful
fire
in
his
little
parlour
,
listening
to
the
wind
which
was
beating
the
rain
in
pattering
drops
against
the
window
,
or
rumbling
dismally
in
the
chimney
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
was
wet
and
cold
;
he
had
been
walking
through
mud
and
water
the
whole
day
,
and
was
now
comfortably
reposing
in
his
dressing
-
gown
and
slippers
,
more
than
half
asleep
and
less
than
half
awake
,
revolving
a
thousand
matters
in
his
wandering
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
he
thought
how
hard
the
wind
was
blowing
,
and
how
the
cold
,
sharp
rain
would
be
at
that
moment
beating
in
his
face
,
if
he
were
not
comfortably
housed
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
his
mind
reverted
to
his
annual
Christmas
visit
to
his
native
place
and
dearest
friends
;
he
thought
how
glad
they
would
all
be
to
see
him
,
and
how
happy
it
would
make
Rose
if
he
could
only
tell
her
that
he
had
found
a
patient
at
last
,
and
hoped
to
have
more
,
and
to
come
down
again
,
in
a
few
months
'
time
,
and
marry
her
,
and
take
her
home
to
gladden
his
lonely
fireside
,
and
stimulate
him
to
fresh
exertions
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
began
to
wonder
when
his
first
patient
would
appear
,
or
whether
he
was
destined
,
by
a
special
dispensation
of
Providence
,
never
to
have
any
patients
at
all
;
and
then
,
he
thought
about
Rose
again
,
and
dropped
to
sleep
and
dreamed
about
her
,
till
the
tones
of
her
sweet
merry
voice
sounded
in
his
ears
,
and
her
soft
tiny
hand
rested
on
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
There
WAS
a
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
but
it
was
neither
soft
nor
tiny
;
its
owner
being
a
corpulent
round
-
headed
boy
,
who
,
in
consideration
of
the
sum
of
one
shilling
per
week
and
his
food
,
was
let
out
by
the
parish
to
carry
medicine
and
messages
.
 
<EOS>
As
there
was
no
demand
for
the
medicine
,
however
,
and
no
necessity
for
the
messages
,
he
usually
occupied
his
unemployed
hours
---
averaging
fourteen
a
day
---
in
abstracting
peppermint
drops
,
taking
animal
nourishment
,
and
going
to
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
lady
,
sir
---
a
lady
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
the
boy
,
rousing
his
master
with
a
shake
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
lady
?
<EOS>
"
cried
our
friend
,
starting
up
,
not
quite
certain
that
his
dream
was
an
illusion
,
and
half
expecting
that
it
might
be
Rose
herself
.
<EOS>
---
"
What
lady
?
 
<EOS>
Where
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
THERE
,
sir
!
"
replied
the
boy
,
pointing
to
the
glass
door
leading
into
the
surgery
,
with
an
expression
of
alarm
which
the
very
unusual
apparition
of
a
customer
might
have
tended
to
excite
.
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
looked
towards
the
door
,
and
started
himself
,
for
an
instant
,
on
beholding
the
appearance
of
his
unlooked
-
for
visitor
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
singularly
tall
woman
,
dressed
in
deep
mourning
,
and
standing
so
close
to
the
door
that
her
face
almost
touched
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
The
upper
part
of
her
figure
was
carefully
muffled
in
a
black
shawl
,
as
if
for
the
purpose
of
concealment
;
and
her
face
was
shrouded
by
a
thick
black
veil
.
 
<EOS>
She
stood
perfectly
erect
,
her
figure
was
drawn
up
to
its
full
height
,
and
though
the
surgeon
felt
that
the
eyes
beneath
the
veil
were
fixed
on
him
,
she
stood
perfectly
motionless
,
and
evinced
,
by
no
gesture
<EOS>
whatever
,
the
slightest
consciousness
of
his
having
turned
towards
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
wish
to
consult
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
,
with
some
hesitation
,
holding
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
opened
inwards
,
and
therefore
the
action
did
not
alter
the
position
of
the
figure
,
which
still
remained
motionless
on
the
same
spot
.
   
<EOS>
She
slightly
inclined
her
head
,
in
token
of
acquiescence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
walk
in
,
"
said
the
surgeon
.
   
<EOS>
The
figure
moved
a
step
forward
;
and
then
,
turning
its
head
in
the
direction
of
the
boy
---
to
his
infinite
horror
---
appeared
to
hesitate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
room
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
addressing

boy
,
whose
large
round

had
been
extended
to

utmost
width
during
this
brief

.
 
<EOS>
"
Draw
the
curtain
,
and

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
drew
a
green
curtain
across
the
glass
part
of
the
door
,
retired
into
the
surgery
,
closed
the
door
after
him
,
and
immediately
applied
one
of
his
large
eyes
to
the
keyhole
on

other
side
.
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
drew
a
chair
to
the
fire
,
and
motioned
the
visitor
to
a
seat
.
 
<EOS>
The
mysterious
figure
slowly
moved
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
blaze
shone
upon
the
black
dress
,
the
surgeon
observed
that
the
bottom
of
it
was
saturated
with
mud
and
rain
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
wet
,
"
be
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
in
a
low
deep
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
are
ill
?
<EOS>
"
added
the
surgeon
,
compassionately
,
for
the
tone
was
that
of
a
person
in
pain
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
was
the
reply
---
"
very
ill
;
not
bodily
,
but
mentally
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
for
myself
,
or
on
my
own
behalf
,
"
continued
the
stranger
,
"
that
I
come
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
laboured
under
bodily
disease
,
I
should
not
be
out
,
alone
,
at
such
an
hour
,
or
on
such
a
night
as
this
;
and
if
I
were
afflicted
with
it
,
twenty
-
four
hours
hence
,
God
knows
how
gladly
I
would
lie
down
and
pray
to
die
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
for
another
that
I
beseech
your
aid
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
be
mad
to
ask
it
for
him
<EOS>
---
I
think
I
am
;
but
,
night
after
night
,
through
the
long
dreary
hours
of
watching
and
weeping
,
the
thought
has
been
ever
present
to
my
mind
;
and
though
even
I
see
the
hopelessness
of
human
assistance
availing
him
,
the
bare
thought
of
laying
him
in
his
grave
without
it
makes
my
blood
run
cold
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
a
shudder
,
such
as
the
surgeon
well
knew
art
could
not
produce
,
trembled
through
the
speaker
's
frame
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
desperate
earnestness
in
this
woman
's
manner
,
<EOS>
that
went
to
the
young
man
's
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
young
in
his
profession
,
and
had
not
yet
witnessed
enough
of
the
miseries
which
are
daily
presented
before
the
eyes
of
its
members
,
to
have
grown
comparatively
callous
to
human
suffering
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
,
"
he
said
,
rising
hastily
,
"
the
person
of
whom
you
speak
,
be
in
so
hopeless
a
condition
as
you
describe
,
not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
go
with
you
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
not
obtain
medical
advice
before
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
it
would
have
been
useless
before
---
because
it
is
useless
even
now
,
"
replied
the
woman
,
clasping
her
hands
passionately
.
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
gazed
,
for
a
moment
,
on
the
black
veil
,
as
if
to
ascertain
the
expression
of
the
features
beneath
it
:
 
its
thickness
,
however
,
rendered
such
a
result
impossible
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ARE
ill
,
"
he
said
,
gently
,
"
although
you
do
not
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
fever
which
has
enabled
you
to
bear
,
without
feeling
it
,
the
fatigue
you
have
evidently
undergone
,
is
burning
within
you
now
.
<EOS>
Put
that
to
your
lips
,
"
he
continued
,
pouring
out

glass
of
water
---
"
compose

for
a
few

,
and
then

me
,
as
calmly
as
you
can
,
what
the
disease
of
the
patient
is
,
and
how
long
he
has
been
ill
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
know
what
it
is
necessary
I
should
know
,
to
render
my
visit
serviceable
to
him
,
I
am
ready
to
accompany
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
lifted
the
glass
of
water
to
her
mouth
,
without
raising
the
veil
;
put
it
down
again
untasted
;
and
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
"
she
said
,
sobbing
aloud
,
"
that
what
I
say
to
you
now
,
seems
like
the
ravings
of
fever
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
told
so
before
,
less
kindly
than
by
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
young
woman
;
and
they
do
say
,
that
as
life
steals
on
towards
its
final
close
,
the
last
short
remnant
,
worthless
as
it
may
seem
to
all
beside
,
is
dearer
to
its
possessor
than
all
the
years
that
have
gone
before
,
connected
though
they
be
with
the
recollection
of
old
friends
long
since
dead
,
and
young
ones
---
children
perhaps
---
who
have
fallen
off
from
,
and
forgotten
one
as
completely
as
if
they
had
died
too
.
 
<EOS>
My
natural
term
of
life
can
not
be
many
years
longer
,
and
should
be
dear
on
that
account
;
but
I
would
lay
it
down
without
a
sigh
---
with
cheerfulness
---
with
joy
---
if
what
I
tell
you
now
,
were
only
false
,
or
imaginary
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
morning
he
of

I
speak
will
be
,
I
KNOW
,
though
I
would
fain

otherwise
,
beyond

reach

human
aid
;
and
yet
,

-
night
,
though
he
is
in

peril
,
you
must
not
see
,
and
could
not
serve
,
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
unwilling

,
"
said

surgeon
,
after

,
"
by
making
any
comment
on
what
you

just
said
,
or
appearing

investigate
a
subject
you
are
so

to
conceal
;
but
there
is
an
inconsistency
in

statement
which
I

not

.
 
<EOS>
This
person
is
dying
to
-
night
,
and
I
can
not
see
him
when
my
assistance
might
possibly
avail
<EOS>
;
you
apprehend
it
will

to
-
morrow
,
and
yet
you
would
have
<EOS>
me
see

!
 
<EOS>
If
he

,

,

,

why
not

to
save
his
life
before
delay

render
