.
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
,
waiter
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
waiter
pulled
down
the
window
-
blind
,
and
then
pulled
it
up
again
---
for
a
regular
waiter
must
do
something
before
he
leaves
the
room
---
adjusted
the
glasses
on
the
side
-
board
,
brushed
a
place
that
was
NOT
dusty
,
rubbed
his
hands
very
hard
,
walked
stealthily
to
the
door
,
and
evaporated
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
,
evidently
,
something
in
the
contents
of
the
letter
,
of
a
nature
,
if
not
wholly
unexpected
,
certainly
extremely
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
Mr
Alexander
Trott
laid
it
down
,
and
took
it
up
again
,
and
walked
about
the
room
on
particular
squares
of
the
carpet
,
and
even
attempted
,
though
unsuccessfully
,
to
whistle
an
air
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
into
a
chair
,
and
read
the
following
epistle
aloud
:
---
   
"
Blue
Lion
and
Stomach
-
warmer
,
"
Great
Winglebury
.
"
<EOS>
Wednesday
Morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
on
discovering
your
intentions
,
I
left
our
counting
-
house
,
and
followed
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
the
purport
of
your
journey
;
---
that
journey
shall
never
be
completed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
friend
here
,
just
now
,
on
whose
secrecy
I
can
rely
.
<EOS>
This
shall
be
no
obstacle
to
my
revenge
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
shall
Emily
Brown
be
exposed
to
the
mercenary
solicitations
of
a
scoundrel
,
odious
in
her
eyes
,
and
contemptible
in
everybody
else
's
:
 
nor
will
I
tamely
submit
to
the
clandestine
attacks
of
a
base
umbrella
-
maker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
From
Great
Winglebury
church
,
a
footpath
leads
through
four
meadows
to
a
retired
spot
known
to
the
townspeople
as
Stiffun
's
Acre
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
[
Mr
Trott
shuddered
.
]
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
waiting
there
alone
,
at
twenty
minutes
before
six
o'clock
to
-
morrow
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Should
I
be
disappointed
in
seeing
you
there
,
I
will
do
myself
the
pleasure
of
calling
with
a
horsewhip
.
   
<EOS>
"
HORACE
HUNTER
.
   
<EOS>
"
PS
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
gunsmiths
in
the
High
-
street
;
and
they
wo
n't
sell
gunpowder
after
dark
---
you
understand
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
PPS
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
not
order
your
breakfast
in
the
morning
until
you
have
met
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
an
unnecessary
expense
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Desperate
-
minded
villain
!
 
<EOS>
I
knew
how
it
would
be
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
terrified
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
told
father
,
that
once
start
me
on
this
expedition
,
and
Hunter
would
pursue
me
like
the
Wandering
Jew
.
<EOS>
It
's
bad
enough
as
it
is
,
to
marry
with
the
old
people
's
commands
,
and
without
the
girl
's
consent
;
but
what
will
Emily
think
of
me
,
if
I
go
down
there
breathless
with
running
away
from
this
infernal
salamander
?
 
<EOS>
What
SHALL
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
What
CAN
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
go
back
to
the
city
,
I
'm
disgraced
for
ever
---
lose
the
girl
---
and
,
what
's
more
,
lose
the
money
too
.
 
<EOS>
Even
if
I
did
go
on
to
the
Browns
'
by
the
coach
,
Hunter
would
be
after
me
in
a
post
-
chaise
;
and
if
I
go
to
this
place
,
this
Stiffun
's
Acre
(
another
shudder
)
,
I
'm
as
good
as
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
seen
him
hit
the
man
at
the
Pall
-
mall
shooting
-
gallery
,
in
the
second
button
-
hole
of
the
waistcoat
,
five
times
out
of
every
six
,
and
when
he
did
n't
hit
him
there
,
he
hit
him
in
the
head
.
<EOS>
"
With
this
consolatory
reminiscence
Mr
Alexander
Trott
again
ejaculated
,
"
What
shall
I
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
Long
and
weary
were
his
reflections
,
as
,
burying
his
face
in

hand
,
he
sat
,
ruminating
on
the
best
course
to
be
pursued
.
 
<EOS>
His
mental
direction
-
post
pointed
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
the
"
governor
's
"
anger
,
and
the
loss
of
the
fortune
which
the
paternal
Brown
had
promised
the
paternal
Trott
his
daughter
should
contribute
to
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
Then

words
"
To
Brown
's
"
were
legibly
inscribed
on
the
said
direction
-
post
,
but
Horace
Hunter
's

rung

;
<EOS>
---
last

all

bore
,
in
red

,

,
"
To
Stiffun
's
Acre
;
"
and
then
Mr
Alexander
Trott
decided
on
adopting
a
plan
which
he
presently
matured
.
   
<EOS>
First
and
foremost
,
he
despatched
the
under
-
boots
to
the
Blue
Lion
and
Stomach
-

,
with
a
gentlemanly
note
to
Mr
Horace
Hunter
,
intimating
that
he
thirsted
for
his
destruction
and
would
do
himself
the
pleasure
of
slaughtering
him
next
morning
,
without
fail
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
wrote
another
letter
,
and
requested
the
attendance
of
the
other
boots
---
for
they
kept
a
pair
.
 
<EOS>
A
modest
knock
at
the
room
door
was
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
Mr
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
thrust
in
a
red
head
with
one

in
it
,
and
being
again
desired
to
"
come

,
"
brought
in
the

the

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
upper
-

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
am
the
upper
-

,
"

-

-

---
"
that

,
I
'm

b'longs

;

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Top
-

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're

London
?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Driv
a
cab
once
<EOS>
,
"
was

laconic

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
do

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Over
-

,
and
driv

a
'
ooman
,
"
replied
the
top
-

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
the
mayor
's
house
?
"
inquired
Mr
Trott
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
,
"
replied
the
boots
,
significantly
,
as
if
he
had
some
good
reason
to
remember
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
you
could
manage
to
leave
a
letter
there
?
"
<EOS>
interrogated
Trott
.
   
<EOS>
"
Should
n't
wonder
,
"
responded
boots
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
this
letter
,
"
said
Trott
,
holding
a
deformed
note
with
a
paralytic
direction
in
one
hand
,
and
five
shillings
in
the
other
---
"
this
letter
is
anonymous
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
---
<EOS>
what
?
<EOS>
"
interrupted
the
boots
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anonymous
<EOS>
---
he
's
not
to
know
who
it
comes
from
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
,
"
responded
the
reg'lar
,
with
a
knowing
wink
,
but
without
evincing
the
slightest
disinclination
to
undertake
the
charge
---
"
I
see
---
<EOS>
bit
o
'
Sving
,
eh
?
"
and
his
one
eye
wandered
round
the
room
,
as
if
in
quest
of
a
dark
lantern
and
phosphorus
-
box
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
say
!
<EOS>
"
he
continued
,
recalling
the
eye
from
its
search
,
and
bringing
it
to
bear
on
Mr
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
he
's
a
lawyer
,
our
mayor
,
and
insured
in
the
County
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
've
a
spite
agen
him
,
you
'd
better
not
burn
his
house
down
---
blessed
if
I
do
n't
think
it
would
be
the
greatest
favour
you
could
do
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
chuckled
inwardly
.
   
<EOS>
If
Mr
Alexander
Trott
had
been
in
any
other
situation
,
his
first
act
would
have
been
to
kick
the
man
down
-
stairs
by
deputy
;
or
,
in
other
words
,
to
ring
the
bell
,
and
desire
the
landlord
to
take
his
boots
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
contented
himself
,
however
,
with
doubling
the
fee
and
explaining
that
the
letter
merely
related
to
a
breach
of
the
peace
.
 
<EOS>
The
top
-
boots
retired
,
solemnly
pledged
to
secrecy
;
and
Mr
Alexander
Trott
sat
down
to
a
fried
sole
,
maintenon
cutlet
,
Madeira
,
and
sundries
,
with
greater
composure
than
he
had
experienced
since
the
receipt
of
Horace
Hunter
's
letter
of
defiance
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
who
alighted
from
the
London
coach
had
no
sooner
been
installed
in
number
twenty
-
five
,
and
made
some
alteration
in
her
travelling
-
dress
,
than
she
indited
a
note
to
Joseph
Overton
,
esquire
,
solicitor
,
and
mayor
of
Great
Winglebury
,
requesting
his
immediate
attendance
on
private
business
of
paramount
importance
---
a
summons
which
that
worthy
functionary
lost
no
time
in
obeying
;
for
after
sundry
openings
of
his
eyes
,
divers
ejaculations
of
"
Bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
and
other
manifestations
of
surprise
,
he
took
his
broad
-
brimmed
hat
from
its
accustomed
peg
in
his
little
front
office
,
and
walked
briskly
down
the
High
-
street
to
the
Winglebury
Arms
;
through
the
hall
and
up
the
staircase
of
which
establishment
he
was
ushered
by
the
landlady
,
and
a
crowd
of
officious
waiters
,
to
the
door
of
number
twenty
-
five
.
   
<EOS>
"
Show
the
gentleman
in
,
"
said
the
stranger
lady
,
in
reply
to
the
foremost
waiter
's
announcement
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
was
shown
in
accordingly
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
rose
from
the
sofa
;
the
mayor
advanced
a
step
from
the
door
;
and
there
they
both
paused
,
for
a
minute
or
two
,
looking
at
one
another
as
if
by
mutual
consent
.
 
<EOS>
The
mayor
saw
before
him
a
buxom
,
richly
-
dressed
female
of
about
forty
;
the
lady
looked
upon
a
sleek
man
,
about
ten
years
older
,
in
drab
shorts
and
continuations
,
black
coat
,
neckcloth
,
and
gloves
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Julia
Manners
!
"
exclaimed
the
mayor
at
length
,
"
you
astonish
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
unfair
of
you
,
Overton
,
"
replied
Miss
Julia
,
"
for
I
have
known
you
,
long
enough
,
not
to
be
surprised
at
anything
you
do
,
and
you
might
extend
equal
courtesy
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
to
run
away
---
actually
run
away
---
with
a
young
man
!
"
remonstrated
the
mayor
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
have
me
actually
run
away
with
an
old
one
,
I
presume
?
<EOS>
"
was
the
cool
rejoinder
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
then
to
ask
me
---
me
---
of
all
people
in
the
world
---
a
man
of
my
age
and
appearance
---
mayor
of
the
town
---
to
promote
such
a
scheme
!
"
<EOS>
pettishly
ejaculated
Joseph
Overton
;
throwing
himself
into
an
arm
-
chair
,
and
producing
Miss
Julia
's
letter
from
his
pocket
,
as
if
to
corroborate
the
assertion
that
he
HAD
been
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Overton
,
"
replied
the
lady
,
"
I
want
your
assistance
in
this
matter
,
and
I
must
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
lifetime
of
that
poor
old
dear
,
Mr
Cornberry
,
who
---
who
---
"
   
"
Who
was
to
have
married
you
,
and
did
n't
,
because
he
died
first
;
and
who
left
you
his
property
unencumbered
with
the
addition
of
himself
,
"
suggested
the
mayor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
replied
Miss
Julia
,
reddening
slightly
,
"
in
the
lifetime
of
the
poor
old
dear
,
the
property
had
the
incumbrance
of
your
management
;
and
all
I
will
say
of
that
,
is
,
that
I
only
wonder
it
did
n't
die
of
consumption
instead
of
its
master
.
 
<EOS>
You
helped
yourself
then
:
---
help
me
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Joseph
Overton
was
a
man
of
the
world
,
and
an
attorney
;
and
as
certain
indistinct
recollections
of
an
odd
thousand
pounds
or
two
,
appropriated
by
mistake
,
passed
across
his
mind
he
hemmed
deprecatingly
,
smiled
blandly
,
remained
silent
for
a
few
seconds
;
and
finally
inquired
,
"
What
do
you
wish
me
to
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
replied
Miss
Julia
---
"
I
'll
tell
you
in
three
words
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Lord
Peter
---
"
   
"
That
's
the
young
man
,
I
suppose
---
"
interrupted
the
mayor
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
young
Nobleman
,
"
replied
the
lady
,
with
a
great
stress
on
the
last
word
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Lord
Peter
is
considerably
afraid
of
the
resentment
of
his
family
;
and
we
have
therefore
thought
it
better
to
make
the
match
a
stolen
one
.
 
<EOS>
He
left
town
,
to
avoid
suspicion
,
on
a
visit
to
his
friend
,
the
Honourable
Augustus
Flair
,
whose
seat
,
as
you
know
,
is
about
thirty
miles
from
this
,
accompanied
only
by
his
favourite
tiger
.
 
<EOS>
We
arranged
that
I
should
come
here
alone
in
the
London
coach
;
and
that
he
,
leaving
his
tiger
and
cab
behind
him
,
should
come
on
,
and
arrive
here
as
soon
as
possible
this
afternoon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
observed
Joseph
Overton
,
"
and
then
he
can
order
the
chaise
,
and
you
can
go
on
to
Gretna
Green
together
,
without
requiring
the
presence
or
interference
of
a
third
party
,
ca
n't
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Miss
Julia
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
every
reason
to
believe
---
<EOS>
dear
Lord
Peter
not
being
considered
very
prudent
or
sagacious
by
his
friends
,
and
they
having
discovered
his
attachment
to
me
---
that
,
immediately
on
his
absence
being
observed
,
pursuit
will
be
made
in
this
direction
:
---
to
elude
which
,
and
to
prevent
our
being
traced
,
I
wish
it
to
be
understood
in
this
house
,
that
dear
Lord
Peter
is
slightly
deranged
,
though
perfectly
harmless
;
and
that
I
am
,
unknown
to
him
,
awaiting
his
arrival
to
convey
him
in
a
post
-
chaise
to
a
private
asylum
---
at
Berwick
,
say
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
do
n't
show
myself
much
,
I
dare
say
I
can
manage
to
pass
for
his
mother
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
thought
occurred
to
the
mayor
's
mind
that
the
lady
might
show
herself
a
good
deal
without
fear
of
detection
;
seeing
that
she
was
about
double
the
age
of
her
intended
husband
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
,
however
,
and
the
lady
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
whole
of
this
arrangement
<EOS>
dear
Lord
Peter
is
acquainted
;
and
all
I
want
you
to
do
,
is
,
to
make
the
delusion
more
complete
by
giving
it
the
sanction
of
your
influence
in
this
place
,
and
assigning
this
as
a
reason
to
the
people
of
the
house
for
my
taking
the
young
gentleman
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
would
not
be
consistent
with
the
story
that
I
should
see
him
until
after
he
has
entered
the
chaise
,
I
also
wish
you
to
communicate
with
him
,
and
inform
him
that
it
is
all
going
on
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
arrived
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Overton
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
how
am
I
to
know
!
"
inquired
the
mayor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
will
not
give
his
own
name
at
the
bar
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
begged
him
,
immediately
on
his
arrival
,
to
write
you
a
note
,
"
replied
Miss
Manners
;
"
and
to
prevent
the
possibility
of
our
project
being
discovered
through
its
means
,
I
desired
him
to
write
anonymously
,
and
in
mysterious
terms
,
to
acquaint
you
with
the
number
of
his
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
mayor
,
rising
from
his
seat
,
and
searching
his
pockets
---
<EOS>
"
most
extraordinary
circumstance
---
he
has
arrived
---
mysterious
note
left
at
my
house
in
a
most
mysterious
manner
,
just
before
yours
---
did
n't
know
what
to
make
of
it
before
,
and
certainly
should
n't
have
attended
to
it
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
here
it
is
.
"
<EOS>
And
Joseph
Overton
pulled
out
of
an
inner
coat
-
pocket
the
identical
letter
penned
by
Alexander
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
his
lordship
's
hand
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
"
replied
Julia
;
"
good
,
punctual
creature
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
it
more
than
once
or
twice
,
but
<EOS>
I
know
he
writes
very
badly
and
very
large
.
 
<EOS>
These
dear
,
wild
young
noblemen
,
you
know
,
Overton
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Ay
,
ay
,
I
see
,
"
replied
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
---
"
Horses
and
dogs
,
play
and
wine
---
grooms
,
actresses
,
and
cigars
---
the
stable
,
the
green
-
room
,
the
saloon
,
and
the
tavern
;
and
the
legislative
assembly
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
what
he
says
,
"
pursued
the
mayor
;
"
"
Sir
,
---
A
young
gentleman
in
number
nineteen
at
the
Winglebury
Arms
,
is
bent
on
committing
a
rash
act
to
-
morrow
morning
at
an
early
hour
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
That
's
good
---
he
means
marrying
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
any
regard
for
the
peace
of
this
town
,
or
the
preservation
of
one
---
it
may
be
two
---
human
lives
"
---
What
the
deuce
does
he
mean
by
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
he
's
so
anxious
for
the
ceremony
,
he
will
expire
if
it
's
put
off
,
and
that
I
may
possibly
do
the
same
,
"
replied
the
lady
with
great
complacency
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
---
not
much
fear
of
that
;
---
well
---
"
two
human
lives
<EOS>
,
you
will
cause
him
to
be
removed
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
He
wants
to
start
at
once
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
not
to
do
this
on
your
responsibility
:
 
for
to
-
morrow
the
absolute
necessity
of
the
proceeding
will
be
but
too
apparent
.
<EOS>
Remember
:
 
number
nineteen
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
is
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
No
delay
;
for
life
and
death
depend
upon
your
promptitude
.
"
 
<EOS>
Passionate
language
,
certainly
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
see
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
,
"
replied
Miss
Julia
;
"
and
entreat
him
to
act
his
part
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
half
afraid
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
to
be
cautious
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
the
mayor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Settle
all
the
arrangements
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
the
mayor
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
say
I
think
the
chaise
had
better
be
ordered
for
one
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
the
mayor
once
more
;
and
,
ruminating
on
the
absurdity
of
the
situation
in
which
fate
and
old
acquaintance
had
placed
him
,
he
desired
a
waiter
to
herald
his
approach
to
the
temporary
representative
of
number
nineteen
.
   
<EOS>
The
announcement
,
"
Gentleman
to
speak
with
you
,
sir
,
"
induced
Mr
Trott
to
pause
half
-
way
in
the
glass
of
port
,
the
contents
of
which
he
was
in
the
act
of
imbibing
at
the
moment
;
to
rise
from
his
chair
;
and
retreat
a
few
paces
towards
the
window
,
as
if
to
secure
a
retreat
,
in
the
event
of
the
visitor
assuming
the
form
and
appearance
of
Horace
Hunter
.
 
<EOS>
One
glance
at
Joseph
Overton
,
however
,
quieted
his
apprehensions
.
 
<EOS>
He
courteously
motioned
the
stranger
to
a
seat
.
 
<EOS>
The
waiter
,
after
a
little
jingling
with
the
decanter
and

,
consented
to
leave
the
room
;
and
Joseph
Overton
,
placing
the
broad
-

hat
on
the

,
and
bending

forward
,

business
by
saying
in
a
very

,
   
"
My
lord
---
"
   
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Alexander
Trott
,
in
a
loud

,
with
the
vacant
and

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
---
hush
!
"
said
the
cautious

:
 
"
to
be
sure
---
quite
right
---
<EOS>
no
titles
here
<EOS>
---
my

Overton
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Overton
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
:
 
the
mayor
of
this
place
<EOS>
---
you
sent
me
a
letter
with
anonymous

,
this

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,

?
"
exclaimed
Trott

ill

;
for
,
coward

,

of

letter

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
,

;
did

?
"
responded
Overton
,

.
<EOS>
"
Either
this
letter

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Stay
,

,
"

,
"

;

.
 
<EOS>
What

do
,

?
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
friend
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
be
sure
,
to
be
sure
,
"
said
the
mayor
,

,
"
you
could
not

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

;
it

to

in
a
post

.
 
<EOS>
And

boys

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

!
"
<EOS>

,
in

,
"
can

in

?
 
<EOS>

!
"
 
<EOS>
He
wiped

down

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

"
that
,

,

ca

<EOS>

<EOS>

That

"

.
<EOS>
This
was

done
.
 
<EOS>
Every

the
story
was
implicitly
believed
,
and
the
one
-

was

to
repair
to
number

,
to
act
as

of
the
person
of
the
supposed

until

-

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
that

-

,

,

,

's

,

without

,
and
mounted

in
,
by

on

,
where
he
proceeded
to
beguile

time
by
whistling
a
popular
air
with
great

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
here
,
you

?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Alexander
Trott
,
with
a
proper

of

at

.
   
<EOS>
The
boots
beat
time
with
his

,
as
he
looked
gently
round
at
Mr
Trott
with
a
smile
of

,
and

an
ADAGIO
movement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

in

Mr

's

?
"
<EOS>

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep

,

,
"

,
"

do

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
protest

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

large

.
   
<EOS>
"
Under

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Under

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

"
the

"

;

and

,
<EOS>
exactly
opposite
him
,
with
the
stick
ready
for
immediate
action
in
case
of
emergency
.
   
<EOS>
Long
and
dreary
were
the
hours
that
followed
.
 
<EOS>
The
bell
of
Great
Winglebury
church
had
just
struck
ten
,
and
two
hours
and
a
half
would
probably
elapse
before
succour
arrived
.
   
<EOS>
For
half
an
hour
,
the
noise
occasioned
by
shutting
up
the
shops
in
the
street
beneath
,
betokened
something
like
life
in
the
town
,
and
rendered
Mr
Trott
's
situation
a
little
less
insupportable
;
but
,
when
even
these
ceased
,
and
nothing
was
heard
beyond
the
occasional
rattling
of
a
post
-
chaise
as
it
drove
up
the
yard
to
change
horses
,
and
then
drove
away
again
,
or
the
clattering
of
horses
'
hoofs
in
the
stables
behind
,
it
became
almost
unbearable
.
 
<EOS>
The
boots
occasionally
moved
an
inch
or
two
,
to
knock
superfluous
bits
of
wax
off
the
candles
,
which
were
burning
low
,
but
instantaneously
resumed
his
former
position
;
and
as
he
remembered
to
have
heard
,
somewhere
or
other
,
that
the
human
eye
had
an
unfailing
effect
in
controlling
mad
people
,
he
kept
his
solitary
organ
of
vision
constantly
fixed
on
Mr
Alexander
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
That
unfortunate
individual
stared
at
his
companion
in
his
turn
,
until
his
features
grew
more
and
more
indistinct
---
his
hair
gradually
less
red
---
and
the
room
more
misty
and
obscure
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Alexander
Trott
fell
into
a
sound
sleep
,
from
which
he
was
awakened
by
a
rumbling
in
the
street
,
and
a
cry
of
"
Chaise
-
and
-
four
for
number
twenty
-
five
!
"
 
<EOS>
A
bustle
on
the
stairs
succeeded
;
the
room
door
was
hastily
thrown
open
;
and
Mr
Joseph
Overton
entered
,
followed
by
four
stout
waiters
,
and
Mrs
Williamson
,
the
stout
landlady
of
the
Winglebury
Arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Overton
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Alexander
Trott
,
jumping
up
in
a
frenzy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
this
man
,
sir
;
consider
the
situation
in
which
I
have
been
placed
for
three
hours
past
---
the
person
you
sent
to
guard
me
,
sir
,
was
a
madman
---
a
madman
---
a
raging
,
ravaging
,
furious
madman
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mr
Overton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
compassionate
Mrs
Williamson
,
"
mad
people
always
thinks
other
people
's
mad
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Alexander
Trott
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
do
you
mean
by
poor
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
the
landlady
of
this
house
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
replied
the
stout

lady
,
"
do
n't
exert
yourself
,
there
's
a
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Consider
your
health
,
now
;
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exert
myself
!
"
<EOS>
shouted
Mr
Alexander
Trott
;
<EOS>
"
it
's
a
mercy
,
ma'am
,
that
I
have
any
breath
to
exert
myself
with
!
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
been
assassinated
three
hours
ago
by
that
one
-
eyed
monster
with
the
oakum

.
 
<EOS>
How
dare

have
a
madman
,
ma'am
<EOS>
---
how
dare

have
a
madman
,
to

and

the
visitors
to

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
never
have
another
,
"
said
Mrs
Williamson
,

at

.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
,
capital
,
"
whispered
Overton
again
,
as
he
enveloped
Mr
Alexander
Trott
in
a
thick

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
,
sir
!
"
exclaimed
Trott
,
aloud
;
"
it
's
horrible
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
recollection
makes
me
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
rather
fight
four
duels
in
three
hours
,

the
first
three
,
than
I
'd
sit
for
that

with

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
it
up
,
my

,

,
"

Overton
,
"
your

,
and
your
portmanteau
in

.
"
 
<EOS>
And
then

added

,
"
<EOS>
Now
,

,
the

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
At

,

Mr
Alexander

.
 
<EOS>
One
took
one

;
another
,
the
other
;
a

,

before
with

;
the

,
behind

;
the
boots
and
Mrs

brought

;
and
down

stairs
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>
Mr
Alexander
Trott
expressing

either

to
go
,
or
his

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Overton
was

at

,

,

"
the

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Alexander
Trott
's

,

(
which

)
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

"

:
 
"
the

.

<EOS>
"
The
other

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

;

,

,
I

---
but

,

.

<EOS>
"
I
wo

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

---
I

---
"

Bravo
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
push

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
wo

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

!
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
This

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

Horses

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

's

!
"
<EOS>
---

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"

,

:

<EOS>
"
Dear

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
How

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>
till

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Whither

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

consented
;
the

was

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Trott
was
a
young
man
,
had
highly
promising

,
an
undeniable
tailor
,
and
an
insinuating

---
he
wanted
nothing
but
valour
,
and
who
wants
that
with
three
thousand
a
-
year
?
 
<EOS>
The
lady
had
this
,
and
more
;
she
wanted
a
young

,
and
the
only

open

Mr
Trott
to

his
disgrace
<EOS>
was
a
rich

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
came
to
the

that
it
would

a

and

;

,

to
Gretna

,

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
And
the
very
next

the
Blacksmith
's

,

Emily
Brown

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Hunter
took

,

,

WAS

;
and
Mr
Trott
took
HIS

home
,

,
and
was

.
 
<EOS>
And
Lord
Peter
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

Hunter
took

of
Alexander
Trott
;
and

were

,

;
and

Winglebury

,

The

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Joseph
Porter
Most
extensive
were
the
preparations
at
Rose
Villa
,
Clapham
Rise
,
in
the
occupation
of
Mr
Gattleton
(
a
stock
-
broker
in
especially
comfortable

)
,
and
great

the

of
Mr
Gattleton
's
interesting

,
as

day
fixed
for
the
representation
of
the
Private
Play
which
had
been
"
many
months
in

,
"
approached
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
family
was
infected
with
the
mania
for
Private
Theatricals
;
the
house
,
usually
so
clean
and
tidy
,
was
,
to
use
Mr
Gattleton
's

,
"
regularly
turned
out
o
'
windows
;
"
the
large

,

,

,
presented

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

in

included

"
properties
.
"
 
<EOS>
The

were
crowded
with

,
the

was
occupied

.
 
<EOS>
Rehearsals
took
place
every
other
night
in
the
drawing
-

,
and
every

in
the
house
was

by

Mr
Sempronius
Gattleton
,

,

"
Othello
"
---
it

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
When

're
a
LEETLE
more

,
I
think
it

,
"
said
Mr
Sempronius
,

CORPS
DRAMATIQUE
,
at

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
Mr
Sempronius
had
been
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Evans
,
"

,

,

,

---
"
Evans
,

RODERIGO
beautifully
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beautifully
,
"

Miss
Gattletons
;
for

Evans
was

by

"
quite

dear
.
"
 
<EOS>
He

,

:
 
to

for

in

and

!
<EOS>
RODERIGO
simpered

.
   
<EOS>
"
But
I

,
"

,
"

in
the
---
fall
---
in

-

,
where
you
are
---
you

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

difficult
,
"
said
Mr
Evans
,

;
<EOS>
"
I
've

,

,

our

-

lately
,

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
Being

backward
<EOS>
you
see
,

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

<EOS>
you

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
The

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

ca

<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>
Harleigh

.
"
   
<EOS>
Everybody

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Harleigh

,

---
not

---
hummed
"
 
Behold

brightly

,
"

<EOS>
"

"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,

Tom
;

,

"

?
"
&
c.
 
<EOS>
The
audience
applauded
again
,
by
way
of
raising
the
spirits
of
the
performers
;
and
then
Mr
Sempronius
desired
the
prompter
,
in
a
very
audible
voice
,
to
"
clear
the
stage
,
and
ring
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ting
,
ting
,
ting
!
<EOS>
went
the
bell
again
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
sat
down
;
the
curtain
shook
;
rose
sufficiently
high
to
display
several
pair
of
yellow
boots
paddling
about
;
and
there
remained
.
   
<EOS>
Ting
,
ting
,
ting
!
<EOS>
went
the
bell
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
curtain
was
violently
convulsed
,
but
rose
no
higher
;
the
audience
tittered
;
Mrs
Porter
looked
at
Uncle
Tom
;
Uncle
Tom
looked
at
everybody
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
and
laughing
with
perfect
rapture
.
 
<EOS>
After
as
much
ringing
with
the
little
bell
as
a
muffin
-
boy
would
make
in
going
down
a
tolerably
long
street
,
and
a
vast
deal
of
whispering
,
hammering
,
and
calling
for
nails
and
cord
,
the
curtain
at
length
rose
,
and
discovered
Mr
Sempronius
Gattleton
SOLUS
,
and
decked
for
OTHELLO
.
<EOS>
After
three
distinct
rounds
of
applause
,
during
which
Mr
Sempronius
applied
his
right
hand
to
his
left
breast
,
and
bowed
in
the
most
approved
manner
,
the
manager
advanced
and
said
:
   
"
Ladies
and
Gentlemen
---
<EOS>
I
assure
you
it
is
with
sincere
regret
,
that
I
regret
to
be
compelled
to
inform
you
,
that
IAGO
who
was
to
have
played
Mr
Wilson
---
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Ladies
and
Gentlemen
,
but
I
am
naturally
somewhat
agitated
(
applause
)
<EOS>
---
I
mean
,
Mr
Wilson
,
who
was
to
have
played
IAGO
,
is
---
that
is
,
has
been
---
or
,
in
other
words
,
Ladies
and
Gentlemen
,
the
fact

,
that
I
have
just
received

,
in
which
I
am
informed
that
IAGO
is
unavoidably
detained
at
the
Post
-
office
this

.
 
<EOS>
Under
these
circumstances
,
I
trust
---
a
---
a
---
amateur
performance
---
a
---
another
gentleman
undertaken
to
read
the
part
---
request
indulgence
for
a
short
time
---
courtesy
and
kindness
of
a
British
audience
.
"
<EOS>
Overwhelming
applause
.
 
<EOS>
Exit
Mr
Sempronius
Gattleton
,
and
curtain
falls
.
   
<EOS>
The
audience
were
,
of
course
,
exceedingly
good
-
humoured
;
the
whole
business
was
a
joke
;
and
accordingly
they
waited
for
an
hour
with
the
utmost
patience
,
being
enlivened
by
an
interlude
of
rout
-
cakes
and
lemonade
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
by
Mr
Sempronius
's
subsequent
explanation
,
that
the
delay
would
not
have
been
so
great
,
<EOS>
had
it
not
so
happened
that
when
the
substitute
IAGO
had
finished
dressing
,
and
just
as
the
play
was
on
the
point
of
commencing
,
the
original
IAGO
unexpectedly
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
The
former
was
therefore
compelled
to
undress
,
and
the
latter
to
dress
for
his
part
;
which
,
as
he
found
some
difficulty
in
getting
into
his
clothes
,
occupied
no
inconsiderable
time
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
the
tragedy
began
in
real
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
It
went
off
well
enough
,
until
the
third
scene
of
the
first
act
,
in
which
OTHELLO
addresses
the
Senate
:
 
<EOS>
the
only
remarkable
circumstance
being
,
that
as
IAGO
could
not
get
on
any
of
the
stage
boots
,
in
consequence
of
his
feet
being
violently
swelled
with
the
heat
and
excitement
<EOS>
,
he
was
under
the
necessity
of
playing
the
part
in
a
pair
of
Wellingtons
,
which
contrasted
rather
oddly
with
his
richly
embroidered

.
 
<EOS>
When
OTHELLO
started
with
his
address
to
the
Senate
(
whose
dignity
was
represented
by
,
the
DUKE
,
<EOS>
A
carpenter
,
two
men
engaged
on
the

of
the
gardener
,
and
a
boy
)
,
Mrs
Porter
found
the
opportunity
she
so

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sempronius
proceeded
:
   
"
"
Most
potent
,
grave
,
and
reverend
signiors
,
My
very
noble
and
approv'd
<EOS>
good
masters
,
<EOS>
That
I
have
ta'en
away
<EOS>
this
old
man
's
daughter
<EOS>
,
It
is
most
true
;
---
rude
am
I
in
my
speech
---
"
"
   
"
Is
that
right
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mrs
Porter
to
Uncle
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
so
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
Sem
!
"
called
out
Uncle
Tom
,
"
that
's
wrong
,
my
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
wrong
,
uncle
?
"
demanded
OTHELLO
,
quite
forgetting
the
dignity
of
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
left
out
something
.
 
<EOS>
"
True
I
have
married
---
"
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
ah
!
"
said
Mr
Sempronius
,
endeavouring
to
hide
his

as
much
and
as

as
the
audience
attempted
to
conceal
their
half
-
suppressed
tittering
,
by
coughing
with
extraordinary
violence
<EOS>
---
   
---
<EOS>
"
"
true
I
have
married
her
;
---
The
very
head
and
front
of
my
offending
Hath
this
extent
;
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
ASIDE
)
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
prompt
,
father
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
've
mislaid
my
spectacles
,
"
said
poor
Mr
Gattleton
,
almost
dead
with
the
heat
and
bustle
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
now
it
's
"
rude
am
I
,
"
"
said
Uncle
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
know
it
is
,
"
returned
the
unfortunate
manager
,
proceeding
with
his
part
.
   
<EOS>
It
would
be
useless
and
tiresome
to
quote
the
number
of
instances
in
which
Uncle
Tom
,
now
completely
in
his
element
,
and
instigated
by
the
mischievous
Mrs
Porter
,
corrected
the
mistakes
of
the
performers
;
suffice
it
to
say
,
that
having
mounted
his
hobby
,
nothing
could
induce
him
to
dismount
;
so
,
during
the
whole
remainder
of
the
play
,
he
performed
a
kind
of
running
accompaniment
,
by
muttering
everybody
's
part
as
it
was
being
delivered
,
in
an
under
-
tone
.
 
<EOS>
The
audience
were
highly
amused
,
Mrs
Porter
delighted
,
the
performers
embarrassed
;
Uncle
Tom
never
was
better
pleased
in
all
his
life
;
and
Uncle
Tom
's
nephews
and
nieces
<EOS>
had
never
,
although
the
declared
heirs
to
his
large
property
,
so
heartily
wished
him
gathered
to
his
fathers
as
on
that
memorable
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
Several
other
minor
causes
,
too
,
united
to
damp
the
ardour
of
the
DRAMATIS
PERSONAE
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
the
performers
could
walk
in
their
tights
,
or
move
their
arms
in
their
jackets
;
the
pantaloons
were
too
small
,
the
boots
too
large
,
and
the
swords
of
all
shapes
and
sizes
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Evans
,
naturally
too
tall
for
the
scenery
,
wore
a
black
velvet
hat
with
immense
white
plumes
,
the
glory
of
which
was
lost
in
"
the
flies
;
"
and
the
only
other
inconvenience
of
which
was
,
that
when
it
was
off
his
head
he
could
not
put
it
on
,
and
when
it
was
on
<EOS>
he
could
not
take
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
all
his
practice
,
too
,
he
fell
with
his
head
and
shoulders
as
neatly
through
one
of
the
side
scenes
,
as
a
harlequin
would
jump
through
a
panel
in
a
Christmas
pantomime
.
 
<EOS>
The
pianoforte
player
,
overpowered
by
the
extreme
heat
of
the
room
,
fainted
away
at
the
commencement
of
the
entertainments
,
leaving
the
music
of
"
Masaniello
"
to
the
flute
and
violoncello
.
 
<EOS>
The
orchestra
complained
that
Mr
Harleigh
put
them
out
,
and
Mr
Harleigh
declared
that
the
orchestra
prevented
his
singing
a
note
.
 
<EOS>
The
fishermen
,
who
were
hired
for
the
occasion
,
revolted
to
the
very
life
,
positively
refusing
to
play
without
an
increased
allowance
of
spirits
;
and
,
their
demand
being
complied
with
,
getting
drunk
in
the
eruption
-
scene
as
naturally
as
possible
.
<EOS>
The
red
fire
,
which
was
burnt
at
the
conclusion
of
the
second
act
,
not
only
nearly
suffocated
the
audience
,
but
nearly
set
the
house
on
fire
into
the
bargain
;
and
,
as
it
was
,
the
remainder
of
the
piece
was
acted
in
a
thick
fog
.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
whole
affair
was
,
as
Mrs
Joseph
Porter
triumphantly
told
everybody
,
"
a
complete
failure
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
audience
went
home
at
four
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
exhausted
with
laughter
,
suffering
from
severe
headaches
,
and
smelling
terribly
of
brimstone
and
gunpowder
.
 
<EOS>
The
Messrs.
Gattleton
,
senior
and
junior
,
retired
to
rest
,
with
the
vague
idea
of
emigrating
to
Swan
River
early
in
the
ensuing
week
.
   
<EOS>
Rose
Villa
has
once
again
resumed
its
wonted
appearance
;
the
dining
-
room
furniture
has
been
replaced
;
the
tables
are
as
nicely
polished
as
formerly
;
the
horsehair
chairs
are
ranged
against
the
wall
,
as
regularly
as
ever
;
Venetian
blinds
have
been
fitted
to
every
window
in
the
house
to
intercept
the
prying
gaze
of
Mrs
Joseph
Porter
.
 
<EOS>
The
subject
of
theatricals
is
never
mentioned
in
the
Gattleton
family
,
unless
,
indeed
,
by
Uncle
Tom
,
who
can
not
refrain
from
sometimes
expressing
his
surprise
and
regret
at
finding
that
his
nephews
and
nieces
appear
to
have
lost
the
relish
they
once
possessed
for
the
beauties
of
Shakspeare
,
and
quotations
from
the
works
of
that
immortal
bard
.
   
<EOS>
A
Passage
in
the
life
of
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
Chapter
<EOS>
the
First
Matrimony
is
proverbially
a
serious
undertaking
.
 
<EOS>
Like
an
over
-
weening
predilection
for
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
it
is
a
misfortune
into
which
a
man
easily
falls
,
and
from
which
he
finds
it
remarkably
difficult
to
extricate
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
of
no
use
telling
a
man
who
is
timorous
on
these
points
,
that
it
is
but
one
plunge
,
and
all
is
over
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
same
thing
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
and
the
unfortunate
victims
derive
as
much
comfort
from
the
assurance
in
the
one
case
as
in
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
was
a
rather
uncommon
compound
of
strong
uxorious
inclinations
,
and
an
unparalleled
degree
of
anti
-
connubial
timidity
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
about
fifty
years
of
age
;
stood
four
feet
six
inches
and
three
-
quarters
in
his
socks
---
for
he
never
stood
in
stockings
at
all
---
plump
,
clean
,
and
rosy
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
something
like
a
vignette
to
one
of
Richardson
's
novels
,
and
had
a
clean
-
cravatish
formality
of
manner
,
and
kitchen
-
pokerness
of
carriage
,
which
Sir
Charles
Grandison
himself
might
have
envied
.
 
<EOS>
He
lived
on
an
annuity
,
which
was
well
adapted
to
the
individual
who
received
it
,
in
one
respect
---
it
was
rather
small
.
 
<EOS>
He
received
it
in
periodical
payments
on
every
alternate
Monday
;
but
he
ran
himself
out
,
about
a
day
after
the
expiration
of
the
first
week
,
as
regularly
as
an
eight
-
day
clock
;
and
then
,
to
make
the
comparison
complete
,
his
landlady
wound
him
up
,
and
he
went
on
with
a
regular
tick
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
had
long
lived
in
a
state
of
single
blessedness
,
as
bachelors
say
,
or
single
cursedness
,
as
spinsters
think
;
but
the
idea
of
matrimony
had
never
ceased
to
haunt
him
.
 
<EOS>
Wrapt
in
profound
reveries
on
this
never
-
failing
theme
,
fancy
transformed
his
small
parlour
in
Cecil
-
street
,
Strand
,
into
a
neat
house
in
the
suburbs
;
the
half
-
hundredweight
of
coals
under
the
kitchen
-
stairs
suddenly
sprang
up
into
three
tons
of
the
best
Walls
-
end
;
his
small
French
bedstead
was
converted
into
a
regular
matrimonial
four
-
poster
;
and
in
the
empty
chair
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
fireplace
,
imagination
seated
a
beautiful
young
lady
,
with
a
very
little
independence
or
will
of
her
own
,
and
a
very
large
independence
under
a
will
of
her
father
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
as
a
gentle
tap
at
his
room
-
door
disturbed
these
meditations
one
evening
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
my
dear
fellow
,
how
DO
you
do
?
"
said
a
short
elderly
gentleman
with
a
gruffish
voice
,
bursting
into
the
room
,
and
replying
to
the
question
by
asking
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
Told
you
I
should
drop
in
some
evening
,
"
said
the
short
gentleman
,
as
he
delivered
his
hat
into
Tottle
's
hand
,
after
a
little
struggling
and
dodging
.
   
<EOS>
"
Delighted
to
see
you
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
wishing
internally
that
his
visitor
had
"
dropped
in
"
to
the
Thames
at
the
bottom
of
the
street
,
instead
of
dropping
into
his
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
The
fortnight
was
nearly
up
,
and
Watkins
was
hard
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
Mrs
Gabriel
Parsons
?
"
inquired
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
well
,
thank
you
,
"
replied
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
for
that
<EOS>
was
the
name
the
short
gentleman
revelled
in
.
 
<EOS>
Here
there
was
a
pause
;
the
short
gentleman
looked
at
the
left
hob
of
the
fireplace
;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
stared
vacancy
out
of
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
well
,
"
repeated
the
short
gentleman
,
when
five
minutes
had
expired
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
say
remarkably
well
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
rubbed
the
palms
of
his
hands
as
hard
as
if
he
were
going
to
strike
a
light
by
friction
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
take
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tottle
,
with
the
desperate
suddenness
of
a
man
who
knew
that
unless
the
visitor
took
his
leave
,
he
stood
very
little
chance
of
taking
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
do
n't
know
---
have
you
any
whiskey
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
replied
Tottle
,
very
slowly
,
for
all
this
was
gaining
time
,
"
I
HAD
some
capital
,
and
remarkably
strong
whiskey
last
week
;
but
it
's
all
gone
---
and
therefore
its
strength
---
"
   
"
Is
much
beyond
proof
;
or
,
in
other
words
,
impossible
to
be
proved
,
"
said
the
short
gentleman
;
and
he
laughed
very
heartily
,
and
seemed
quite
glad
the
whiskey
had
been
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tottle
smiled
---
but
it
was
the
smile
of
despair
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
had
done
laughing
,
he
delicately
insinuated
that
,
in
the
absence
of
whiskey
,
he
would
not
be
averse
to
brandy
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
lighting
a
flat
candle
very
ostentatiously
;
and
displaying
an
immense
key
,
which
belonged
to
the
street
-
door
,
but
which
,
for
the
sake
of
appearances
,
occasionally
did
duty
in
an
imaginary
wine
-
cellar
;
left
the
room
to
entreat
his
landlady
to
charge
their
glasses
,
and
charge
them
in
the
bill
.
 
<EOS>
The
application
was
successful
;
the
spirits
were
speedily
called
---
not
from
the
vasty
deep
,
but
the
adjacent
wine
-
vaults
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
short
gentlemen
mixed
their
grog
;
and
then
sat
cosily
down
before
the
fire
---
a
pair
of
shorts
,
airing
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
"
you
know
my
way
---
off
-
hand
,
open
,
say
what
I
mean
,
mean
what
I
say
,
hate
reserve
,
and
ca
n't
bear
affectation
.
 
<EOS>
One
,
is
a
bad
domino
which
only
hides
what
good
people
have
about
'em
,
without
making
the
bad
look
better
;
and
the
other
is
much
about
the
same
thing
as
pinking
a
white
cotton
stocking
to
make
it
look
like
a
silk
one
.
 
<EOS>
Now
listen
to
what
I
'm
going
to
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
,
the
little
gentleman
paused
,
and
took
a
long
pull
at
his
brandy
-
and
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
took
a
sip
of
his
,
stirred
the
fire
,
and
assumed
an
air
of
profound
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
humming
and
ha'ing
about
the
matter
,
"
resumed
the
short
gentleman
.
<EOS>
---
"
You
want
to
get
married
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
replied
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
evasively
;
for
he
trembled
violently
,
and
felt
a
sudden
tingling
throughout
his
whole
frame
;
"
why
---
I
should
certainly
---
at
least
,
I
THINK
I
should
like
---
"
   
"
Wo
n't
do
,
"
said
the
short
gentleman
.
<EOS>
---
"
Plain
and
free
---
or
there
's
an
end
of
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
want
money
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
admire
the
sex
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
'd
like
to
be
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
shall
be
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
an
end
of
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
saying
,
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
took
a
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
mixed
another
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
entreat
you
to
be
more
explanatory
,
"
said
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
as
the
party
principally
interested
,
I
can
not
consent
to
be
disposed
of
,
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
replied
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
warming
with
the
subject
,
and
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
---
"
I
know
a
lady
<EOS>
---
she
's
stopping
with
my
wife
now
---
<EOS>
who
is
just
the
thing
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
Well
educated
;
talks
French
;
plays
the
piano
;
knows
a
good
deal
about
flowers
,
and
shells
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
;
and
has
five
hundred
a
year
,
with
an
uncontrolled
power
of
disposing
of
it
,
by
her
last
will
and
testament
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
pay
my
addresses
to
her
,
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
n't
VERY
young
---
is
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
very
;
just
the
thing
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
said
that
already
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
coloured
hair
has
the
lady
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Egad
,
I
hardly
recollect
,
"
replied
Gabriel
,
with
coolness
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
ought
to
have
observed
,
at
first
,
she
wears
a
front
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
?
"
ejaculated
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
of
those
things
with
curls
,
along
here
,
"
said
Parsons
,
drawing
a
straight
line
across
his
forehead
,
just
over
his
eyes
,
in
illustration
of
his
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
front
's
black
;
I
ca
n't
speak
quite
positively
about
her
own
hair
;
because
,
unless
one
walks
behind
her
,
and
catches
a
glimpse
of
it
under
her
bonnet
,
one
seldom
sees
it
;
but
I
should
say
that
it
was
RATHER
lighter
than
the
front
---
a
shade
of
a
greyish
tinge
,
perhaps
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
looked
as
if
he
had
certain
misgivings
of
mind
.
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
perceived
it
,
and
thought
it
would
be
safe
to
begin
the
next
attack
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
were
you
ever
in
love
,
Tottle
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
blushed
up
to
the
eyes
,
and
down
to
the
chin
,
and
exhibited
a
most
extensive
combination
of
colours
as
he
confessed
the
soft
impeachment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
popped
the
question
,
more
than
once
,
when
you
were
a
young
---
I
beg
your
pardon
---
a
younger
---
man
,
"
said
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
in
my
life
!
"
replied
his
friend
,
apparently
indignant
at
being
suspected
of
such
an
act
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
that
I
entertain
,
as
you
know
,
peculiar
opinions
on
these
subjects
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
afraid
of
ladies
,
young
or
old
---
far
from
it
;
but
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
that
in
compliance
with
the
custom
of
the
present
day
,
they
allow
too
much
freedom
of
speech
and
manner
to
marriageable
men
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
fact
is
,
that
anything
like
this
easy
freedom
I
never
could
acquire
;
and
as
I
am
always
afraid
of
going
too
far
,
I
am
generally
,
I
dare
say
,
considered
formal
and
cold
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wonder
if
you
were
,
"
replied
Parsons
,
gravely
;
"
I
should
n't
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
you
'll
be
all
right
in
this
case
;
for
the
strictness
and
delicacy
of
this
lady
's
ideas
greatly
exceed
your
own
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
bless
you
,
why
,
when
she
came
to
our
house
,
there
was
an
old
portrait
of
some
man
or
other
,
with
two
large
,
black
,
staring
eyes
,
hanging
up
in
her
bedroom
;
she
positively
refused
to
go
to
bed
there
,
till
it
was
taken
down
,
considering
it
decidedly
wrong
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
;
"
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
the
other
night
---
I
never
laughed
so
much
in
my
life
"
---
resumed
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
;
"
I
had
driven
home
in
an
easterly
wind
,
and
caught
a
devil
of
a
face
-
ache
.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
as
Fanny
---
that
's
Mrs
Parsons
,
you
know
---
and
this
friend
of
hers
,
and
I
,
and
Frank
Ross
,
were
playing
a
rubber
,
I
said
,
jokingly
,
that
when
I
went
to
bed
I
should
wrap
my
head
in
Fanny
's
flannel
petticoat
.
 
<EOS>
She
instantly
threw
up
her
cards
,
and
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
right
!
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
;
"
she
could
not
possibly
have
behaved
in
a
more
dignified
manner
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
?
---
<EOS>
Frank
took
dummy
;
and
I
won
sixpence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
did
n't
you
apologise
for
hurting
her
feelings
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Devil
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
Next
morning
at
breakfast
,
we
talked
it
over
.
 
<EOS>
She
contended
that
any
reference
to
a
flannel
petticoat
was
improper
;
---
men
ought
not
to
be
supposed
to
know
that
such
things
were
.
 
<EOS>
I
pleaded
my
coverture
;
being
a
married
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
the
lady
say
to
that
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tottle
,
deeply
interested
.
   
<EOS>
"
Changed
her
ground
,
and
said
that
Frank
being
a
single
man
,
its
impropriety
was
obvious
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Noble
-
minded
creature
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
enraptured
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
both
Fanny
<EOS>
and
I
said
,
at
once
,
that
she
was
regularly
cut
out
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
gleam
of
placid
satisfaction
shone
on
the
circular
face
of
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
as
he
heard
the
prophecy
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
one
thing
I
ca
n't
understand
,
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
as
he
rose
to
depart
;
"
I
can
not
,
for
the
life
and
soul
of
me
,
imagine
how
the
deuce
you
'll
ever
contrive
to
come
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
would
certainly
go
into
convulsions
if
the
subject
were
mentioned
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
sat
down
again
,
and
laughed
until
he
was
weak
.
 
<EOS>
Tottle
owed
him
money
,
so
he
had
a
perfect
right
to
laugh
at
Tottle
's
expense
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
feared
,
in
his
own
mind
,
that
this
was
another
characteristic
which
he
had
in
common
with
this
modern
Lucretia
.
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
accepted
the
invitation
to
dine
with
the
Parsonses
on
the
next
day
but
one
,
with
great
firmness
:
 
and
looked
forward
to
the
introduction
,
when
again
left
alone
,
with
tolerable
composure
.
   
<EOS>
The
sun
that
rose
on
the
next
day
but
one
,
had
never
beheld
a
sprucer
personage
on
the
outside
of
the
Norwood
stage
,
than
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
;
and
when
the
coach
drew
up
before
a
cardboard
-
looking
house
with
disguised
chimneys
,
and
a
lawn
like
a
large
sheet
of
green
letter
-
paper
,
he
certainly
had
never
lighted
to
his
place
of
destination
a
gentleman
who
felt
more
uncomfortable
.
   
<EOS>
The
coach
stopped
,
and
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
jumped
---
we
beg
his
pardon
---
alighted
,
with
great
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
right
!
"
said
he
,
and
away
went
the
coach
up
the
hill
with
that
beautiful
equanimity
of
pace
for
which
"
short
"
stages
are
generally
remarkable
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
gave
a
faltering
jerk
to
the
handle
of
the
garden
-
gate
bell
.
 
<EOS>
He
essayed
a
more
energetic
tug
,
and
his
previous
nervousness
was
not
at
all
diminished
by
hearing
the
bell
ringing
like
a
fire
alarum
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Parsons
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tottle
of
the
man
who
opened
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
hear
himself
speak
,
for
the
bell
had
not
yet
done
tolling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
"
shouted
a
voice
on
the
lawn
,
---
and
there
was
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
in
a
flannel
jacket
,
running
backwards
and
forwards
,
from
a
wicket
to
two
hats
piled
on
each
other
,
and
from
the
two
hats
to
the
wicket
,
in
the
most
violent
manner
,
while
another
gentleman
with
his
coat
off
was
getting
down
the
area
of
the
house
,
after
a
ball
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
gentleman
without
the
coat
had
found
it
---
which
he
did
in
less
than
ten
minutes
---
he
ran
back
to
the
hats
,
and
Gabriel
Parsons
pulled
up
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
the
gentleman
without
the
coat
called
out
"
play
,
"
very
loudly
,
and
bowled
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
knocked
the
ball
several
yards
,
and
took
another
run
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
the
other
gentleman
aimed
at
the
wicket
,
and
did
n't
hit
it
;
and
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
having
finished
running
on
his
own
account
,
laid
down
the
bat
and
ran
after
the
ball
,
which
went
into
a
neighbouring
field
.
 
<EOS>
They
called
this
cricket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
will
you
"
go
in
?
"
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
as
he
approached
him
,
wiping
the
perspiration
off
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
declined
the
offer
,
the
bare
idea
of
accepting
which
made
him
even
warmer
than
his
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
we
'll
go
into
the
house
,
as
it
's
past
four
,
and
I
shall
have
to
wash
my
hands
before
dinner
,
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
I
hate
ceremony
,
you
know
!
 
<EOS>
Timson
,
that
's
Tottle
---
<EOS>
Tottle
,
that
's
Timson
;
bred
for
the
church
,
which
I
fear
will
never
be
bread
for
him
;
"
and
he
chuckled
at
the
old
joke
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Timson
bowed
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
bowed
stiffly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
led
the
way
to
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
rich
sugar
-
baker
,
who
mistook
rudeness
for
honesty
,
and
abrupt
bluntness
for
an
open
and
candid
manner
;
many
besides
Gabriel
mistake
bluntness
for
sincerity
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gabriel
Parsons
received
the
visitors
most
graciously
on
the
steps
,
and
preceded
them
to
the
drawing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
sofa
,
was
seated
a
lady
of
very
prim
appearance
,
and
remarkably
inanimate
.
<EOS>
She
was
one
of
those
persons
at
whose
age
it
is
impossible
to
make
any
reasonable
guess
;
her
features
might
have
been
remarkably
pretty
when
she
was
younger
,
and
they
might
always
have
presented
the
same
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Her
complexion
---
with
a
slight
trace
of
powder
here
and
there
---
was
as
clear
as
that
of
a
well
-
made
wax
doll
,
and
her
face
as
expressive
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
handsomely
dressed
,
and
was
winding
up
a
gold
watch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
,
my
dear
,
this
is
our
friend
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
;
a
very
old
acquaintance
I
assure
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
presenting
the
Strephon
of
Cecil
-
street
,
Strand
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
rose
,
and
made
a
deep
courtesy
;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
made
a
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Splendid
,
majestic
creature
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Timson
advanced
,
and
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
began
to
hate
him
.
 
<EOS>
Men
generally
discover
a
rival
,
instinctively
,
and
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
felt
that
his
hate
was
deserved
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
beg
,
"
said
the
reverend
gentleman
,
---
"
May
I
beg
to
call
upon
you
,
Miss
Lillerton
,
for
some
trifling
donation
to
my
soup
,
coals
,
and
blanket
distribution
society
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Put
my
name
down
,
for
two
sovereigns
,
if
you
please
,
"
responded
Miss
Lillerton
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
truly
charitable
,
madam
,
"
said
the
Reverend
Mr
Timson
,
"
and
we
know
that
charity
will
cover
a
multitude
of
sins
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
beg
you
to
understand
that
I
do
not
say
this
from
the
supposition
that
you
have
many
sins
which
require
palliation
;
believe
me
when
I
say
that
I
never
yet
met
any
one
who
had
fewer
to
atone
for
,
than
Miss
Lillerton
.
"
   
<EOS>
Something
like
a
bad
imitation
of
animation
lighted
up
the
lady
's
face
,
as
she
acknowledged
the
compliment
.
 
<EOS>
Watkins
Tottle
incurred
the
sin
of
wishing
that
the
ashes
of
the
Reverend
Charles
Timson
were
quietly
deposited
in
the
churchyard
of
his
curacy
,
wherever
it
might
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
"
interrupted
Parsons
,
who
had
just
appeared
with
clean
hands
,
and
a
black
coat
,
"
it
's
my
private
opinion
,
Timson
,
that
your
"
distribution
society
"
is
rather
a
humbug
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
severe
,
"
replied
Timson
,
with
a
Christian
smile
:
 
he
disliked
Parsons
,
but
liked
his
dinners
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
positively
unjust
!
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
observed
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
looked
up
;
her
eyes
met
those
of
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
She
withdrew
them
in
a
sweet
confusion
,
and
Watkins
Tottle
did
the
same
---
the
confusion
was
mutual
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
urged
Mr
Parsons
,
pursuing
his
objections
,
"
what
on
earth
is
the
use
of
giving
a
man
coals
who
has
nothing
to
cook
,
or
giving
him
blankets
when
he
has
n't
a
bed
,
or
giving
him
soup
when
he
requires
substantial
food
?
---
"
like
sending
them
ruffles
when
wanting
a
shirt
.
"
 
<EOS>
Why
not
give
'em
a
trifle
of
money
,
as
I
do
,
when
I
think
they
deserve
it
,
and
let
them
purchase
what
they
think
best
?
 
<EOS>
Why
?
---
<EOS>
because
your
subscribers
would
n't
see
their
names
flourishing
in
print
on
the
church
-
door
---
that
's
the
reason
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
Mr
Parsons
,
I
hope
you
do
n't
mean
to
insinuate
that
I
wish
to
see
MY
name
in
print
,
on
the
church
-
door
,
"
interrupted
Miss
Lillerton
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
putting
in
another
word
,
and
getting
another
glance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
you
would
n't
mind
seeing
it
in
writing
,
though
,
in
the
church
register
---
eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Register
!
 
<EOS>
What
register
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
lady
gravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
register
of
marriages
,
to
be
sure
,
"
replied
Parsons
,
chuckling
at
the
sally
,
and
glancing
at
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
thought
he
should
have
fainted
for
shame
,
and
it
is
quite
impossible
to
imagine
what
effect
the
joke
would
have
had
upon
the
lady
,
if
dinner
had
not
been
,
at
that
moment
,
announced
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
with
an
unprecedented
effort
of
gallantry
,
offered
the
tip
of
his
little
finger
;
Miss
Lillerton
accepted
it
gracefully
,
with
maiden
modesty
;
and
they
proceeded
in
due
state
to
the
dinner
-
table
,
where
they
were
soon
deposited
side
by
side
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
was
very
snug
,
the
dinner
very
good
,
and
the
little
party
in
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
The
conversation
became
pretty
general
,
and
when
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
had
extracted
one
or
two
cold
observations
from
his
neighbour
,
and
had
taken
wine
with
her
,
he
began
to
acquire
confidence
rapidly
.
 
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
removed
;
Mrs
Gabriel
Parsons
drank
four
glasses
of
port
on
the
plea
of
being
a
nurse
just
then
;
and
Miss
Lillerton
took
about
the
same
number
of
sips
,
on
the
plea
of
not
wanting
any
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
ladies
retired
,
to
the
great
gratification
of
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
who
had
been
coughing
and
frowning
at
his
wife
,
for
half
-
an
-
hour
previously
---
signals
which
Mrs
Parsons
never
happened
to
observe
,
until
she
had
been
pressed
to
take
her
ordinary
quantum
,
which
,
to
avoid
giving
trouble
,
she
generally
did
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
her
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
of
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
in
an
under
-
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dote
on
her
with
enthusiasm
already
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
pray
let
us
drink
"
the
ladies
,
"
"
said
the
Reverend
Mr
Timson
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
ladies
!
"
said
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
,
emptying
his
glass
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
fulness
of
his
confidence
,
he
felt
as
if
he
could
make
love
to
a
dozen
ladies
,
off
-
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
"
I
remember
when
I
was
a
young
man
---
fill
your
glass
,
Timson
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
this
moment
emptied
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
fill
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
Timson
,
suiting
the
action
to
the
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
,
"
resumed
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
"
when
I
was
a
younger
man
,
with
what
a
strange
compound
of
feelings
I
used
to
drink
that
toast
,
and
how
I
used
to
think
every
woman
was
an
angel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
that
before
you
were
married
?
"
<EOS>
mildly
inquired
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
thought
so
since
;
and
a
precious
milksop
I
must
have
been
,
ever
to
have
thought
so
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
you
know
,
I
married
Fanny
under
the
oddest
,
and
most
ridiculous
circumstances
possible
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
were
they
,
if
one
may
inquire
?
"
asked
Timson
,
who
had
heard
the
story
,
on
an
average
,
twice
a
week
for
the
last
six
months
.
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
listened
attentively
,
in
the
hope
of
picking
up
some
suggestion
that
might
be
useful
to
him
in
his
new
undertaking
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
spent
my
wedding
-
night
in
a
back
-
kitchen
chimney
,
"
said
Parsons
,
by
way
of
a
beginning
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
back
-
kitchen
chimney
!
"
ejaculated
Watkins
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
dreadful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
was
n't
very
pleasant
,
"
replied
the
small
host
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
Fanny
's
father
and
mother
liked
me
well
enough
as
an
individual
,
but
had
a
decided
objection
to
my
becoming
a
husband
.
<EOS>
You
see
,
I
had
n't
any
money
in
those
days
,
and
they
had
;
and
so
they
wanted
Fanny
to
pick
up
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
we
managed
to
discover
the
state
of
each
other
's
affections
somehow
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
meet
her
,
at
some
mutual
friends
'
parties
;
at
first
we
danced
together
,
and
talked
,
and
flirted
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
;
then
,
I
used
to
like
nothing
so
well
as
sitting
by
her
side
---
we
did
n't
talk
so
much
then
,
but
I
remember
I
used
to
have
a
great
notion
of
looking
at
her
out
of
the
extreme
corner
of
my
left
eye
---
and
then
I
got
very
miserable
and
sentimental
,
and
began
to
write
verses
,
and
use
Macassar
oil
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
could
n't
bear
it
any
longer
,
and
after
I
had
walked
up
and
down
the
sunny
side
of
Oxford
-
street
in
tight
boots
for
a
week
---
and
a
devilish
hot
summer
<EOS>
it
was
too
---
<EOS>
in
the
hope
of
meeting
her
,
I
sat
down
and
wrote
a
letter
,
and
begged
her
to
manage
to
see
me
clandestinely
,
for
I
wanted
to
hear
her
decision
from
her
own
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
had
discovered
,
to
my
perfect
satisfaction
,
that
I
could
n't
live
without
her
,
and
that
if
she
did
n't
have
me
,
I
had
made
up
my
mind
to
take
prussic
acid
,
or
take
to
drinking
,
or
emigrate
,
so
as
to
take
myself
off
in
some
way
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
borrowed
a
pound
,
and
bribed
the
housemaid
to
give
her
the
note
,
which
she
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
was
the
reply
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Timson
,
who
had
found
,
before
,
that
to
encourage
the
repetition
of
old
stories
is
to
get
a
general
invitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
the
usual
one
!
 
<EOS>
Fanny
expressed
herself
very
miserable
;
hinted
at
the
possibility
of
an
early
grave
;
said
that
nothing
should
induce
her
to
swerve
from
the
duty
she
owed
her
parents
;
implored
me
to
forget
her
,
and
find
out
somebody
more
deserving
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
she
could
,
on
no
account
,
think
of
meeting
me
unknown
to
her
pa
and
ma
;
and
entreated
me
,
as
she
should
be
in
a
particular
part
of
Kensington
Gardens
at
eleven
o'clock
next
morning
,
not
to
attempt
to
meet
her
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
go
,
of
course
?
"
said
Watkins
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
?
---
<EOS>
Of
course
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
There
she
was
,
with
the
identical
housemaid
in
perspective
,
in
order
that
there
might
be
no
interruption
.
 
<EOS>
We
walked
about
,
for
a
couple
of
hours
;
made
ourselves
delightfully
miserable
;
and
were
regularly
engaged
.
<EOS>
Then
,
we
began
to
"
correspond
"
---
that
is
to
say
,
we
used
to
exchange
about
four
letters
a
day
;
what
we
used
to
say
in
'em
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
used
to
have
an
interview
,
in
the
kitchen
,
or
the
cellar
,
or
some
such
place
,
every
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
things
went
on
in
this
way
for
some
time
;
and
we
got
fonder
of
each
other
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
as
our
love
was
raised
to
such
a
pitch
,
and
as
my
salary
had
been
raised
too
,
shortly
before
,
we
determined
on
a
secret
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
arranged
to
sleep
at
a
friend
's
,
on
the
previous
night
;
we
were
to
be
married
early
in
the
morning
;
and
then
we
were
to
return
to
her
home
and
be
pathetic
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
to
fall
at
the
old
gentleman
's
feet
,
and
bathe
his
boots
with
her
tears
;
and
I
was
to
hug
the
old
lady
and
call
her
"
mother
,
"
and
use
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
as
much
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Married
we
were
,
the
next
morning
;
two
girls
-
friends
of
Fanny
's
---
acting
as
bridesmaids
;
and
a
man
,
who
was
hired
for
five
shillings
and
a
pint
of
porter
,
officiating
as
father
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
old
lady
unfortunately
put
off
her
return
from
Ramsgate
,
where
she
had
been
paying
a
visit
,
until
the
next
morning
;
and
as
we
placed
great
reliance
on
her
,
we
agreed
to
postpone
our
confession
for
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
.
 
<EOS>
My
newly
-
made
wife
returned
home
,
and
I
spent
my
wedding
-
day
in
strolling
about
Hampstead
-
heath
,
and
execrating
my
father
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
Of

,

,

<EOS>

,

:
 
upon

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

about

,

,

for

,

,

,
to

that

old

---

---
<EOS>
prompted
I
suppose

the

,
was

---

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
a

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
My

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

;

,

I

the
candle
which
my
unconscious
father
-
in
-
law

in

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

of

on

;

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
So
,

Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>
Having

,

,

in

,

off
,
and
was

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
continued
to
pace
up
and
down
the
pathway
for
some
minutes
,
apparently
absorbed
in
deep
meditation
.
<EOS>
The
result
of
his
cogitations
seemed
to
be
perfectly
satisfactory
to
himself
,
for
he
ran
briskly
into
the
house
;
said
that
business
had
suddenly

him
to
town
;
that
he
had
desired
the
messenger
to
inform
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
of

;
and
that
they
would
return
together
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
then
hastily
equipped
himself
for
a
drive
,
and
mounting
his
gig
,
was
soon
on
his
way
to
the
establishment
of
Mr
Solomon
Jacobs
,
situate
(
as
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
had
informed
him
)
in
Cursitor
-
street
,
Chancery
-
lane
.
   
<EOS>
When
a
man
is
in
a
violent
hurry
to
get
on
,
and
has
a
specific
object
in
view
,
the
attainment
of
which
depends
on
the
completion
of
his
journey
,
the
difficulties
which
interpose
themselves
in
his
way
appear
not
only
to
be
innumerable
,
but
to
have
been
called
into
existence
especially
for
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
The
remark
is
by
no
means
a
new
one
,
and
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
had
practical
and
painful
experience
of
its
justice
in
the
course
of
his
drive
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
three
classes
of
animated
objects
which
prevent
your
driving
with
any
degree
of
comfort
or
celerity
through
streets
which
are
but
little
frequented
---
they
are
pigs
,
children
,
and
old
women
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
occasion
we
are
describing
,
the
pigs
were
luxuriating
on
cabbage
-
stalks
,
and
the
shuttlecocks
fluttered
from
the
little
deal
battledores
,
and
the
children
played
in
the
road
;
and
women
,
with
a
basket
in
one
hand
,
and
the
street
-
door
key
in
the
other
,
WOULD
cross
just
before
the
horse
's
head
,
until
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
was
perfectly
savage
with
vexation
,
and
quite
hoarse
with
hoi
-
ing
and
imprecating
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
when
he
got
into
Fleet
-
street
,
there
was
"
a
stoppage
,
"
in
which
people
in
vehicles
have
the
satisfaction
of
remaining
stationary
for
half
an
hour
,
and
envying
the
slowest
pedestrians
;
and
where
policemen
rush
about
,
and
seize
hold
of
horses
'
bridles
,
and
back
them
into
shop
-
windows
,
by
way
of
clearing
the
road
and
preventing
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
turned
into
Chancery
-
lane
,
and
having
inquired
for
,
and
been
directed
to
Cursitor
-
street
(
for
it
was
a
locality
of
which
he
was
quite

)
,
he
soon
found
himself
opposite
the
house
of
Mr
Solomon
Jacobs
.
 
<EOS>
Confiding
his
horse
and

to

,
Mr

crossed
the

and

an

,
the

which
was
of
glass
,
grated
like
the

of
this
inviting

with
iron

---
painted
white
to
look
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
The

answered
by
a

,
red

,
who
,

Mr
Gabriel

through

,

,
which
was
in

lock
,
but
which
,
taken
in

with

iron

,
gave
the

the
appearance
of
being
subject

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
see
Mr
Watkins

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Up

,

,

"
First

---
door

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Being
informed
that
the
unfortunate
object
of

visit
had
just

up

stairs
to
write

,

had

.
   
<EOS>
The
room
---
which
was

,

---
was
partitioned
off
into
boxes
,
like
the

of
some

.
<EOS>
The
dirty
floor
had
evidently

as

to

as
to

:
 
and

by

oil

.
 
<EOS>
The
gray
ashes
on

,
and

the

,
fully

;
and

Solomon

<EOS>
Over

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
From

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Certainly
,
"
whispered
Tottle
,
whose
courage
was
vanishing
fast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
now
,
you
'd
better
begin
to
pave
the
way
,
"
said
Parsons
,
who
,
having
invested
some
money
in
the
speculation
,
assumed
the
office
of
director
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
I
will
---
presently
,
"
replied
Tottle
,
greatly
flurried
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
something
to
her
,
man
,
"
urged
Parsons
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Confound
it
!
<EOS>
pay
her
a
compliment
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
not
till
after
dinner
,
"
replied
the
bashful
Tottle
,
anxious
to
postpone
the
evil
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
"
you
are
really
very
polite
;
you
stay
away
the
whole
morning
,
after
promising
to
take
us
out
,
and
when
you
do
come
home
,
you
stand

together
and
take
no

of
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
were
talking
of
the
BUSINESS
,
my
dear
,
which
detained
us
this
morning
,
"
replied
Parsons
,
looking
significantly
at
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
how
very
quickly
the
morning
has
gone
,
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
,
referring
to
the
gold
watch
,
which
was
wound
up
on
state
occasions
,
whether
it
required
it
or
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
has
passed
very
slowly
,
"
mildly
suggested
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
(
"
That
's
right
---
bravo
!
"
)
<EOS>
whispered
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
,
with
an
air
of
majestic
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
impute
it
to
my
unavoidable
absence
from
your
society
,
madam
,
"
said
Watkins
,
"
and
that
of
Mrs
Parsons
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
During
this
short
dialogue
,
the
ladies
had
been
leading
the
way
to
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
deuce
did
you
stick
Fanny
into
that
last

for
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Parsons
,
as
they
followed
together
;
"
it
quite
spoilt
the
effect
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
really
would
have
been
too
broad
without
,
"
replied
Watkins
Tottle
,
"
much
too
broad
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
mad
!
"
<EOS>
Parsons
whispered
his
wife
,
as
they
entered
the
drawing

,
"
mad
from
modesty
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
ejaculated
the
lady
,
"
I
never
heard

such

thing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
find
we
have
quite

,
Mr
Tottle
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
when

:
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
is
one
of
us
,
and
,
of
course
,
we
make
no
stranger
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
expressed
a
hope
that
the
Parsons
family
never
would
make
a
stranger
of
him
;
and
wished
internally
that
his
bashfulness
would
allow
him
to
feel
a

less

himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
off
the
covers
,
Martha
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
directing
the
shifting
of
the
scenery
with
great
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
The
order
was
obeyed
,
and
a
pair
of
boiled
fowls
,
with
tongue
and
et
ceteras
,
were
displayed
at
the
top
,
and
a
fillet
of
veal
at
the
bottom
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
the
table
two
green
sauce
-
tureens
,
with
ladles
of
the
same
,
were
setting
to
each
other
in
a
green
dish
;
and
on
the
other
was
a
curried
rabbit
,
in
a
brown
suit
,
turned
up
with
lemon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
"
shall
I
assist
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
no
;
I
think
I
'll
trouble
Mr
Tottle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Watkins
started
---
trembled
---
helped
the
rabbit
---
and
broke
a
tumbler
.
 
<EOS>
The
countenance
of
the
lady
of
the
house
,
which
had
been
all
smiles
previously
,
underwent
an
awful
change
.
   
<EOS>
"
Extremely
sorry
,
"
stammered
Watkins
,
assisting
himself
to
currie
and
parsley
and
butter
,
in
the
extremity
of
his
confusion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
consequence
,
"
replied
Mrs
Parsons
,
in
a
tone
which
implied
that
it
was
of
the
greatest
consequence
possible
,
---
directing
aside
the
researches
of
the
boy
,
who
was
groping
under
the
table
for
the
bits
of
broken
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
presume
,
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
,
"
that
Mr
Tottle
is
aware
of
the
interest
which
bachelors
usually
pay
in
such
cases
;
a
dozen
glasses
for
one
is
the
lowest
penalty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
gave
his
friend
an

on
the
toe
.
<EOS>
Here
was
a
clear
hint
that
the
sooner
he
ceased
to
be
a
bachelor
and
emancipated
himself
from
such
penalties
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
viewed

in

,
and

Parsons
to
take
wine
,
with

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
,
"
said

,
"
may
I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
most
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
will
you
assist
Miss
Lillerton
,
and
pass
the

.
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
The
usual
pantomimic
ceremony
of
nodding
and
sipping
gone
through
)
---
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
were
you
ever
in
Suffolk
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
master
of
the
house
,
who
was
burning
to
tell
one
of
his
seven
stock
stories
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
responded
Watkins
,
adding
,
by

saving

,
"
but
I
've
been
in
Devonshire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
replied
Gabriel
,
"
it
was
in
Suffolk
that
a
rather
singular
circumstance
happened
to
me
many
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
happen
to
hear
me
mention
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
HAD
happened
to
hear
his
friend
mention
it
some
four
hundred
times
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
he
expressed
great
curiosity
,
and
evinced
the
utmost
impatience
to
hear
the
story
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
forthwith
attempted
to
proceed
,
in
spite
of
the
interruptions
to
which
,
as
our
readers
must
frequently
have
observed
,
the
master
of
the
house
is
often
exposed
in
such
cases
.
<EOS>
We
will
attempt
to
give
them
an
idea
of
our
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
in
Suffolk
---
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
off
the
fowls
first
,
Martha
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
in
Suffolk
,
"
resumed
Mr
Parsons
,
with
an

at
his
wife
,
who

,
"
which
is
now
years
ago
,
business
led
me
to
the
town
of
Bury
St
Edmund
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
to
stop
at
the
principal
places
in
my
way
,
and
therefore
,
for
the
sake
of

,
I
travelled
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
left
Sudbury
one
dark
night
---
it
was
winter
time
---
about
nine
o'clock
;
the
rain
poured
in

,
the

among
the
trees
that
skirted
the

,
and
I
was

to
proceed
at
a
foot
-
pace
,
for
I
could
hardly
see
my
hand
before
me
<EOS>
,
it
was
so
dark
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
John
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Parsons
,
in

,
"
do

spill

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
said

,
"
I
wish

'd

.
 
<EOS>
Really
,
my
dear
,
these

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
did

,
"
said

Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
my
dear
,
you
DID

,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
very

,
my
love
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
give

to
the
servants
;
I

that
if
I

and
allowed
John
to
spill

over
the
new

,
you
'd
be
the
first
to

when
you
saw
the
stain
to
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
continued
Gabriel
with

,

no
getting

,
"
<EOS>
I
was
just

,

was
so

that

.
 
<EOS>
The
road
was
very

,
and
I
assure

,
Tottle
(
this
was

device
to

wandering

of
that

,
which

Mrs

,

)
<EOS>
,
I

,
Tottle
,
I

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pie
to

,
"
interrupted

Parsons
,
again

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
pray
,
my
dear
,
"
remonstrated
Parsons
once
more
,
very

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
P
turned
up
her
hands
and
eyebrows
,
and
appealed
in
dumb
show
to
Miss
Lillerton
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
turned
a
corner
of
the
road
,
"
resumed
Gabriel
,
"
the
horse
stopped
short
,
and
reared
tremendously
.
 
<EOS>
I
pulled
up
,
jumped
out
,
ran
to
his
head
,
and
found
a
man
lying
on
his
back
in
the
middle
of
the
road
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
sky
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
was
dead
;
but
no
,
he
was
alive
,
and
there
appeared
to
be
nothing
the
matter
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
jumped
up
,
and
putting
his
hand
to
his
chest
,
and
fixing
upon
me
the
most
earnest
gaze
you
can
imagine
,
exclaimed
---
"
   
"
Pudding
here
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
's
no
use
,
"
exclaimed
the
host
,
now
rendered
desperate
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Tottle
;
a
glass
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
useless
to
attempt
relating
anything
when
Mrs
Parsons
is
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
attack
was
received
in
the
usual
way
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Parsons
talked
TO
Miss
Lillerton
and
AT
her
better
half
;
expatiated
on
the
impatience
of
men
generally
;
hinted
that
her
husband
was
peculiarly
vicious
in
this
respect
,
and
wound
up
by
insinuating
that
she
must
be
one
of
the
best
tempers
that
ever
existed
,
or
she
never
could
put
up
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Really
what
she
had
to
endure
sometimes
,
was
more
than
any
one
who
saw
her
in
every
-
day
life
could
by
possibility
suppose
.
<EOS>
---
The
story
was
now
a
painful
subject
,
and
therefore
Mr
Parsons
declined
to
enter
into
any
details
,
and
contented
himself
by
stating
that
the
man
was
a
maniac
,
who
had
escaped
from
a
neighbouring
mad
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
removed
;
the
ladies
soon
afterwards
retired
,
and
Miss
Lillerton
played
the
piano
in
the
drawing
-
room
overhead
,
very
loudly
,
for
the
edification
of
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
and
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
sat
chatting
comfortably
enough
,
until
the
conclusion
of
the
second
bottle
,
when
the
latter
,
in
proposing
an
adjournment
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
informed
Watkins
that
he
had
concerted
a
plan
with
his
wife
,
for
leaving
him
and
Miss
Lillerton
alone
,
soon
after
tea
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
Tottle
,
as
they
went
up
-
stairs
,
"
do
n't
you
think
it
would
be
better
if
we
put
it
off
till
-
till
-
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
YOU
think
it
would
have
been
much
better
if
I
had
left
you
in
that
wretched
hole
<EOS>
I
found
you
in
this
morning
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Parsons
bluntly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
---
well
---
I
only
made
a
suggestion
,
"
said
poor
Watkins
Tottle
,
with
a
deep
sigh
.
   
<EOS>
Tea
was
soon
concluded
,
and
Miss
Lillerton
,
drawing
a
small
work
-
table
on
one
side
of
the
fire
,
and
placing
a
little
wooden
frame
upon
it
,
something
like
a
miniature
clay
-
mill
without
the
horse
,
was
soon
busily
engaged
in
making
a
watch
-
guard
with
brown
silk
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Parsons
,
starting
up
with
well
-
feigned
surprise
,
"
I
've
forgotten
those
confounded
letters
.
 
<EOS>
Tottle
,
I
know
you
'll
excuse
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
Tottle
had
been
a
free
agent
,
he
would
have
allowed
no
one
to
leave
the
room
on
any
pretence
,
except
himself
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
however
,
he
was
obliged
to
look
cheerful
when
Parsons
quitted
the
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
left
,
when
Martha
put
her
head
into
the
room
,
with
---
"
Please
,
ma'am
,
you
're
wanted
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Parsons
left
the
room
,
shut
the
door
carefully
after
her
,
and
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
was
left
alone
with
Miss
Lillerton
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
first
five
minutes
there
was
a
dead
silence
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
was
thinking
how
he
should
begin
,
and
Miss
Lillerton
appeared
to
be
thinking
of
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
The
fire
was
burning
low
;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
stirred

,
and
put
some

on
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
coughed
Miss
Lillerton
;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
thought
the
fair
creature
had
spoken
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
I
thought
you
spoke
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
No

"

"
Madam

<EOS>
"
To

!
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
---
"
Speak
---
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
you
,
madam
---
and
on

the

of

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

hastily
rose
and
would

;
but
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
gently
detained

,
and
holding

as

as

joint

would

<EOS>
,

thus

:
 
"

,

---
for

I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
---
that

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
---
"
here

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Disinterested

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

"

<EOS>

"

,
wrapped
up
in
a
hopera
-
cloak
,
as
it
might
be
,
and
all
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
the
gate
that
night
,
so
<EOS>
I
went
up
when
the
coach
come
,
and
he
vos
a
waitin
'
at
the
parlour
door
---
and
was
n't
he
a
trembling
,
neither
?
 
<EOS>
The
poor
creetur
see
him
,
and
could
hardly
walk
to
meet
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Harry
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
says
,
"
that
it
should
have
come
to
this
;
and
all
for
my
sake
,
"
says
she
,
putting
her
hand
upon

shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
puts
his
arm
round
her
pretty
little

,
and
leading
her
gently
a
little
way
into
the
room
,
so
that
he
might
be
able
to
shut
the
door
,
he
says
,
<EOS>
so
kind
and
soft

like
---
"
Why
,
Kate
,
"
says
he
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
gentleman
you
want
,
"
said
Ikey
,
abruptly

off
in

,

introducing
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
to
the
crest
-

Watkins
Tottle
,
who
at
that

entered

room
.
<EOS>
Watkins
advanced
with
a

of
passive

,
and
accepted

which
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
held

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
with
a

strongly

of
his
dislike
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
way
,
"
replied
the
imprisoned
one
,
leading
the
way
to
the
front
drawing
-
room
,
where
rich
debtors
did
the
luxurious
at
the
rate
of
a
couple
of
guineas
a
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
here
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Watkins
,
as
he
sat
down
on
the
sofa
;
and
placing
the

of
his
hands
on
his

,
anxiously
glanced
at
his
friend
's
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
here
you
're
likely
to
be
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
coolly
,
as
he
rattled
the
money
in
his
unmentionable

,
and
looked
out
of
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
amount
with
the
costs
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Parsons
,
after

.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
any
money
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nine
and
sixpence
halfpenny
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
walked
up
and
down
the
room
for
a
few
seconds
,
before
he
could
make
up
his
mind
to
disclose
the
plan
he
had
formed
;
he
was
accustomed
to
drive
hard
bargains
,
but
was
always
most
anxious
to
conceal
his
avarice
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
stopped
short
,
and
said
,
"
Tottle
,
you
owe

fifty
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

all
I
see
,
I
infer
that
you
are
likely
to
owe

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Though
you

?
"
   
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"

Gabriel

,
"

:
 
<EOS>
here

.
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Accept

---
<EOS>
yes

---
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

10L.

(

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

---
"
   
"

---

;

,
that

"
   
<EOS>
"
At

!
 
<EOS>
My

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
for

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
knows
you
well
from
reputation
,
though

.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding

,

out

hand

.
<EOS>
My

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
---

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"

,
"

,

,

,

forth
;

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

Tottle

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
---

.
 
<EOS>
The

of
hand

---
the

---
Ikey

for

,

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

---
<EOS>
"

-

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

---
I

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

,
"

.
<EOS>
---
"
What
fun
!
"
<EOS>
and

so

and
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never

,
"
replied
Watkins
,

,
as

made

to
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Mr
Tottle
,
my

,
"
said
Mrs

,

Lillerton
.
 
<EOS>
The

,
and
acknowledged

with
the
same

that
Watkins
had
noticed
on

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did

see

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
really

looked
as

rather

seen

else
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,

!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Parsons
again
<EOS>
---
"
it
's

with
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
They
never
show

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the

with
the

sex
,
and
no

.
 
<EOS>
Fanny

,

,

---
see

.

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Certainly
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

---

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Confound

!
<EOS>
pay

,
ca

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,
"

;

.

<EOS>
"
We

of

BUSINESS
,

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
<EOS>
how

,
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
(
"
That

!
"
)
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
During

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

,

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"

"
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Miss

one

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
expressed
a

that

never

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Take

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
obeyed
,
and
a

,
with

and
et
ceteras
,
were
displayed
at
the
top
,
and
a

of
veal
at

bottom
.
 
<EOS>
On
one

of
the
table
two

-

,
with

of
the
same
,

in

;
and
on

other
was
a
curried

,
in

brown

,
turned

with
