.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
,
"
shall
I
assist
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
no
;
I
think
I
'll
trouble
Mr
Tottle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Watkins
started
---
trembled
---
helped
the
rabbit
---
and
broke
a
tumbler
.
 
<EOS>
The
countenance
of
the
lady
of
the
house
,
which
had
been
all
smiles
previously
,
underwent
an
awful
change
.
   
<EOS>
"
Extremely
sorry
,
"
stammered
Watkins
,
assisting
himself
to
currie
and
parsley
and
butter
,
in
the

of
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
consequence
,
"
replied
Mrs
Parsons
,
in
a
tone
which
implied
that
it
was
of
the
greatest
consequence
possible
,
---
directing
aside
the
researches
of
the
boy
,
who
was
groping
under
the
table
for
the
bits
of
broken
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
presume
,
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
,
"
that
Mr
Tottle
is
aware
of
the
interest
which
bachelors
usually
pay
in
such
cases
;
a
dozen
glasses
for
one
is
the
lowest
penalty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
gave
his
friend
an

tread
on
the
toe
.
<EOS>
Here
was
a
clear
hint
that
the
sooner
he
ceased
to
be
a
bachelor
and-'emancipated
himself
from
such
penalties
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
viewed
the
observation
in
the
same
light
,
and
challenged
Mrs
Parsons
to
take
wine
,
with
a
degree
of
presence

mind
,
which
,
under
all

,
was
really

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
"
may
I
have
the
pleasure
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
most
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
will
you
assist
Miss
Lillerton
,
and
pass
the
decanter
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
The
usual
pantomimic
ceremony
of
nodding
and
sipping
gone
through
)
---
   
<EOS>
"
Tottle
,
were
you
ever
in
Suffolk
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
master
of
the
house
,
who
was
burning
to

one
of
his
seven
stock

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
responded
Watkins
,

,

,
"
but
I
've

in
Devonshire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
replied
Gabriel
,
"
it
was
in
Suffolk
that
a
rather
singular
circumstance
happened
to
me
many
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
happen
to
hear
me
mention
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
HAD
happened
to
hear
his
friend
mention
it
some
four
hundred
times
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
he
expressed
great
curiosity
,
and
evinced
the
utmost
impatience
to
hear
the
story
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
forthwith
attempted
to
proceed
,
in
spite
of
the
interruptions
to
which
,
as
our
readers
must
frequently
have
observed
,
the
master
of
the
house
is
often
exposed
in
such
cases
.
<EOS>
We
will
attempt
to
give
them
an
idea
of
our
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
in
Suffolk
---
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
off
the
fowls
first
,
Martha
,
"
said
Mrs
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
in
Suffolk
,
"
resumed
Mr
Parsons
,
with
an
impatient

at
his
wife
,
who
pretended
not
to
observe
it
,
"
which
is
now
years
ago
,
business
led
me
to
the
town
of
Bury
St
Edmund
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
to
stop
at
the
principal
places
in
my
way
,
and
therefore
,
for
the

,
I
travelled
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
left
Sudbury
one
dark
night
---
it
was
winter
time
---
about
nine

;
the
rain
poured
in

,
the

among
the
trees
that

the

,
and
I
was

at
a
foot

,
for
I
could
hardly
see
my
hand
before
me
<EOS>
,

was
so
dark
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
John
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Parsons
,
in

,
"
do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Really
,
my

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

,

!
 
<EOS>
I
must

the
servants
;
I
am

if

John
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

,
"
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
Tottle
(

,

---

<EOS>
"
Pie

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
P
turned
up

and

,
and

to
Miss
Lillerton
.
 
<EOS>
"
As

a

road
,
"
resumed
Gabriel
,
"
the
horse

short
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
but
no

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

most

,

"
Pudding

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,

;
a

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

to

when
Mrs
Parsons
is

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

was
received
in

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Parsons
talked
TO

Lillerton
and
AT
her
better

;
expatiated
on
the

of

;

was

in

,

must

one

the
best

that

existed
,
or
she
never

.
 
<EOS>
Really

endure
sometimes
,
was
more

saw
her
in
every
-
day
life
could
by

.
<EOS>
---
The
story
was
now
a
painful
subject
,
and
therefore
Mr
Parsons
declined
to
enter
into
any
details
,
and
contented

by
stating
that
the
man
was
a

,
who
had

from
a

.
   
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
removed
;
the
ladies
soon

,
and
Miss
Lillerton
played
the
piano
in

-
room
overhead
,

,
for
the

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
and
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
sat

comfortably

,
until
the

the

,

,
in

,

for

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,
"

-

-

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

YOU

hole

I

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

Well
---
well
---
I

,
"

poor
Watkins

,

.
   
<EOS>
Tea

,
and
Miss
Lillerton
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed

,
starting

well
-

,
"
I
've

.
 
<EOS>
Tottle
,
I
know
you
'll

.
"
   
<EOS>
If
Tottle
had
been
a
free
agent
,
he

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.
   
<EOS>
He

---
"
Please
,

,

.

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
was
thinking
how
he
should
begin
,

appeared

.
 
<EOS>
The
fire
was

;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
coughed

Lillerton
;
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
thought
the
fair

had

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
I
thought

spoke
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

No

"

<EOS>
"
To

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
---
"
Speak
---
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
you
,
madam
---
and
on

of

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

;
but
Mr
Watkins

gently

,

would

<EOS>
,

thus

:
 
"
Pray

---
for

.
 
<EOS>
I

will

Parsons
,

<EOS>
---

---
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
---
"
here
Watkins

.
   
<EOS>
"
Am

,

"
   
<EOS>

She

.
"
   
<EOS>

Then
,

?

,

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
How

,
Mr

?
"
   
<EOS>
Here

---
<EOS>
"
By

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

---

,

---

---
<EOS>

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Disinterested

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

thought

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

My

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

.
"
 
<EOS>
Watkins

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Our

,

is

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

It

,

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Only

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
<EOS>

,

Parsons

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

---
pray

---

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Lillerton
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

!
<EOS>
"
thought

Tottle
;
"
who
the
deuce
is
that
to
be
,
I
wonder
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tottle
,
"
continued
Miss
Lillerton
,
"
you
have
made
me
a
most
disinterested
and
kind
offer
---
<EOS>
that
offer
I
accept
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
at
once
be
the
bearer
of
a
note
from
me
to
---
to
Mr
Timson
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Timson
!
"
said
Watkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
After
what
has
passed
between
us
,
"
responded
Miss
Lillerton
,
still
averting
her
head
,
"
you
must
understand
whom
I
mean
;
Mr
Timson
,
the
---
the
---
clergyman
.
"
   
"
Mr
Timson
,
the
clergyman
!
"
ejaculated
Watkins
Tottle
,
in
a
state
of
inexpressible
beatitude
,
and
positive
wonder
at
his
own
success
.
"
<EOS>
Angel
!
 
<EOS>
Certainly
---
this
moment
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
prepare
it
immediately
,
"
said
Miss
Lillerton
,
making
for
the
door
;
"
the
events
of
this
day
have
flurried
me
so
much
,
Mr
Tottle
,
that
I
shall
not
leave
my
room
again
this
evening
;
I
will
send
you
the
note
by
the
servant
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
---
stay
,
"
cried
Watkins
Tottle
,
still
keeping
a
most
respectful
distance
from
the
lady
;
"
when
shall
we
meet
again
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tottle
,
"
replied
Miss
Lillerton
,
coquettishly
,
"
when
we
are
married
,
I
can
never
see
you
too
often
,
nor
thank
you
too
much
;
"
and
she
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
flung
himself
into
an
arm
-
chair
,
and
indulged
in
the
most
delicious
reveries
of
future
bliss
,
in
which
the
idea
of
"
Five
hundred
pounds
per
annum
,
with
an
uncontrolled
power
of
disposing
of
it
by
her
last
will
and
testament
,
"
was
somehow
or
other
the
foremost
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
gone
through
the
interview
so
well
,
and
it
had
terminated
so
admirably
,
that
he
almost
began
to
wish
he
had
expressly
stipulated
for
the
settlement
of
the
annual
five
hundred
on
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
come
in
?
"
said
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
,
peeping
in
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
,
"
replied
Watkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
have
you
done
it
?
"
<EOS>
anxiously
inquired
Gabriel
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
I
done
it
!
"
said
Watkins
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
---
I
'm
going
to
the
clergyman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
well
you
have
managed
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
does
Timson
live
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Watkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
his
uncle
's
,
"
replied
Gabriel
,
"
just
round
the
lane
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
waiting
for
a
living
,
and
has
been
assisting
his
uncle
here
for
the
last
two
or
three
months
.
 
<EOS>
But
how
well
you
have
done
it
<EOS>
---
I
did
n't
think
you
could
have
carried
it
off
so
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
was
proceeding
to
demonstrate
that
the
Richardsonian
principle
was
the
best
on
which
love
could
possibly
be
made
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
the
entrance
of
Martha
,
with
a
little
pink
note
folded
like
a
fancy
cocked
-
hat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Lillerton
's
compliments
,
"
said
Martha
,
as
she
delivered
it
into
Tottle
's
hands
,
and
vanished
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
observe
the
delicacy
?
"
said
Tottle
,
appealing
to
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
COMPLIMENTS
,
not
LOVE
,
by
the
servant
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
did
n't
exactly
know
what
reply
to
make
,
so
he
poked
the
forefinger
of
his
right
hand
between
the
third
and
fourth
ribs
of
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
Watkins
,
when
the
explosion
of
mirth
,
consequent
on
this
practical
jest
,
had
subsided
,
"
we
'll
be
off
at
once
---
<EOS>
let
's
lose
no
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
!
"
echoed
Gabriel
Parsons
;
and
in
five
minutes
they
were
at
the
garden
-
gate
of
the
villa
tenanted
by
the
uncle
of
Mr
Timson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Charles
Timson
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
of
Mr
Charles
Timson
's
uncle
's
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Charles
IS
at
home
,
"
replied
the
man
,
stammering
;
"
but
he
desired
me
to
say
he
could
n't
be
interrupted
,
sir
,
by
any
of
the
parishioners
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
a
parishioner
,
"
replied
Watkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Charles
writing
a
sermon
,
Tom
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Parsons
,
thrusting
himself
forward
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
Mr
Parsons
,
sir
;
he
's
not
exactly
writing
a
sermon
,
but
he
is
practising
the
violoncello
in
his
own
bedroom
,
and
gave
strict
orders
not
to
be
disturbed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
I
'm
here
,
"
replied
Gabriel
,
leading
the
way
across
the
garden
;
"
Mr
Parsons
and
Mr
Tottle
,
on
private
and
particular
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
shown
into
the
parlour
,
and
the
servant
departed
to
deliver
his
message
.
 
<EOS>
The
distant
groaning
of
the
violoncello
ceased
;
footsteps
were
heard
on
the
stairs
;
and
Mr
Timson
presented
himself
,
and
shook
hands
with
Parsons
with
the
utmost
cordiality
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
sir
?
"
said
Watkins
Tottle
,
with
great
solemnity
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
YOU
do
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Timson
,
with
as
much
coldness
as
if
it
were
a
matter
of
perfect
indifference
to
him
how
he
did
,
as
it
very
likely
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
to
deliver
this
note
to
you
,
"
said
Watkins
Tottle
,
producing
the
cocked
-
hat
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
Miss
Lillerton
!
"
said
Timson
,
suddenly
changing
colour
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pray
sit
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
sat
down
;
and
while
Timson
perused
the
note
,
fixed
his
eyes
on
an
oyster
-
sauce
-
coloured
portrait
of
the
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
,
which
hung
over
the
fireplace
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Timson
rose
from
his
seat
when
he
had
concluded
the
note
,
and
looked
dubiously
at
Parsons
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
,
"
he
inquired
,
appealing
to
Watkins
Tottle
,
"
whether
our
friend
here
is
acquainted
with
the
object
of
your
visit
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Our
friend
is
in
MY
confidence
,
"
replied
Watkins
,
with
considerable
importance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sir
,
"
said
Timson
,
seizing
both
Tottle
's
hands
,
"
allow
me
in
his

to
thank
you
most
unfeignedly
and
cordially
,
for
the
noble
part
you
have
acted
in
this
affair
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
thinks
I
recommended
him
,
"
thought
Tottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Confound
these
fellows
!
<EOS>
they
never
think
of
anything
but
their
fees
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
deeply
regret
having
misunderstood
your
intentions
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
continued
Timson
.
 
<EOS>
"
Disinterested
and
manly
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
There
are
very
few
men
who
would
have
acted
as
you
have
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
could
not
help
thinking
that
this
last
remark
was
anything
but
complimentary
.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
inquired
,
rather
hastily
,
"
When
is
it
to
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
Thursday
,
"
replied
Timson
,
---
"
on
Thursday
morning
at
half
-
past
eight
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Uncommonly
early
,
"
observed
Watkins
Tottle
,
with
an
air
of
triumphant
self
-
denial
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
hardly
be
able
to
get
down
here
by
that
hour
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
This
was
intended
for
a
joke
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
replied
Timson
,
all
suavity
,
shaking
hands
with
Tottle
again
most
heartily
,
"
so
long
as
we
see
you
to
breakfast
,
you
know
---
"
   
"
Eh
!
"
said
Parsons
,
with
one
of
the
most
extraordinary
expressions
of
countenance
that
ever
appeared
in
a
human
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Watkins
Tottle
,
at
the
same
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
that
so
long
as
we
see
you
to
breakfast
,
"
replied
Timson
,
"
we
will
excuse
your
being
absent
from
the
ceremony
,
though
of
course
your
presence
at
it
would
give
us
the
utmost
pleasure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
staggered
against
the
wall
,
and
fixed
his
eyes
on
Timson
with
appalling
perseverance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Timson
,
"
said
Parsons
,
hurriedly
brushing
his
hat
with
his
left
arm
,
"
when
you
say
"
us
,
"
whom
do
you
mean
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Timson
looked
foolish
in
his
turn
,
when
he
replied
,
"
Why
---
Mrs
Timson
that
will
be
this
day
week
:
 
Miss
Lillerton
that
is
---
"
   
"
Now
do
n't
stare
at
that
idiot
in
the
corner
,
"
angrily
exclaimed
Parsons
,
as
the
extraordinary
convulsions
of
Watkins
Tottle
's
countenance
excited
the
wondering
gaze
of
Timson
,
---
"
but
have
the
goodness
to
tell
me
in
three
words
the
contents
of
that
note
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
note
,
"
replied
Timson
,
"
is
from
Miss
Lillerton
,
to
whom
I
have
been
for
the
last
five
weeks
regularly
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
Her
singular
scruples
and
strange
feeling
on
some
points
have
hitherto
prevented
my
bringing
the
engagement
to
that
termination
which
I
so
anxiously
desire
.
 
<EOS>
She
informs
me
here
,
that
she
sounded
Mrs
Parsons
with
the
view
of
making
her
her
confidante
and
go
-
between
,
that
Mrs
Parsons
informed
this
elderly
gentleman
,
Mr
Tottle
,
of
the
circumstance
,
and
that
he
,
in
the
most
kind
and
delicate
terms
,
offered
to
assist
us
in
any
way
,
and
even
undertook
to
convey
this
note
,
which
contains
the
promise
I
have
long
sought
in
vain
---
an
act
of
kindness
for
which
I
can
never
be
sufficiently
grateful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Timson
,
"
said
Parsons
,
hurrying
off
,
and
carrying
the
bewildered
Tottle
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
stay
---
and
have
something
?
"
said
Timson
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
ye
,
"
replied
Parsons
;
"
I
've
had
quite
enough
;
"
and
away
he
went
,
followed
by
Watkins
Tottle
in
a
state
of
stupefaction
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gabriel
Parsons
whistled
until
they
had
walked
some
quarter
of
a
mile
past
his
own
gate
,
when
he
suddenly
stopped
,
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
clever
fellow
,
Tottle
,
ai
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
the
unfortunate
Watkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
'll
say
this
is
Fanny
's
fault
,
wo
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Gabriel
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
it
,
"
replied
the
bewildered
Tottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Parsons
,
turning
on
his
heel
to
go
home
,
"
the
next
time
you
make
an
offer
,
you
had
better
speak
plainly
,
and
do
n't
throw
a
chance
away
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
next
time
you
're
locked
up
in
a
spunging
-
house
<EOS>
,
just
wait
there
till
I
come
and
take
you
out
<EOS>
,
there
's
a
good
fellow
.
"
   
<EOS>
How
,
or
at
what
hour
,
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
returned
to
Cecil
-
street
is
unknown
.
 
<EOS>
His
boots
were
seen
outside
his
bedroom
-
door
next
morning
;
but
we
have
the
authority
of
his
landlady
for
stating
that
he
neither
emerged
therefrom
nor
accepted
sustenance
for
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
period
,
and
when
a
council
of
war
was
being
held
in
the
kitchen
on
the
propriety
of
summoning
the
parochial
beadle
to
break
his
door
open
,
he
rang
his
bell
,
and
demanded
a
cup
of
milk
-
and
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
morning
he
went
through
the
formalities
of
eating
and
drinking
as
usual
,
but
a
week
afterwards
he
was
seized
with
a
relapse
,
while
perusing
the
list
of
marriages
in
a
morning
paper
,
from
which
he
never
perfectly
recovered
.
   
<EOS>
A
few
weeks
after
the
last
-
named
occurrence
,
the
body
of
a
gentleman
unknown
,
was
found
in
the
Regent
's
canal
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
trousers
-
pockets
were
four
shillings
and
threepence
halfpenny
;
a
matrimonial
advertisement
from
a
lady
,
which
appeared
to
have
been
cut
out
of
a
Sunday
paper
:
 
a
tooth
-
pick
,
and
a
card
-
case
,
which
it
is
confidently
believed
would
have
led
to
the
identification
of
the
unfortunate
gentleman
,
but
for
the
circumstance
of
there
being
none
but
blank
cards
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Watkins
Tottle
absented
himself
from
his
lodgings
shortly
before
.
 
<EOS>
A
bill
,
which
has
not
been
taken
up
,
was
presented
next
morning
;
and
a
bill
,
which
has
not
been
taken
down
,
was
soon
afterwards
affixed
in
his
parlour
-
window
.
   
<EOS>
The
Bloomsbury
christening
Mr
Nicodemus
Dumps
,
or
,
as
his
acquaintance
called
him
,
"
long
Dumps
,
"
was
a
bachelor
,
six
feet
high
,
and
fifty
years
old
:
 
cross
,
cadaverous
,
odd
,
and
ill
-
natured
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
never
happy
but
when
he
was
miserable
;
and
always
miserable
when
he
had
the
best
reason
to
be
happy
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
real
comfort
of
his
existence
was
to
make
everybody
about
him
wretched
---
then
he
might
be
truly
said
to
enjoy
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
afflicted
with
a
situation
in
the
Bank
worth
five
hundred
a
-
year
,
and
he
rented
a
"
first
-
floor
furnished
,
"
at
Pentonville
,
which
he
originally
took
because
it
commanded
a
dismal
prospect
of
an
adjacent
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
familiar
with
the
face
of
every
tombstone
,
and
the
burial
service
seemed
to
excite
his
strongest
sympathy
.
 
<EOS>
His
friends
said
he
was
surly
---
he
insisted
he
was
nervous
;
they
thought
him
a
lucky
dog
,
but
he
protested
that
he
was
"
the
most
unfortunate
man
in
the
world
.
"
 
<EOS>
Cold
as
he
was
,
and
wretched
as
he
declared
himself
to
be
<EOS>
,
he
was
not
wholly
unsusceptible
of
attachments
.
 
<EOS>
He
revered
the
memory
of
Hoyle
,
as
he
was
himself
an
admirable
and
imperturbable
whist
-
player
,
and
he
chuckled
with
delight
at
a
fretful
and
impatient
adversary
.
 
<EOS>
He
adored
King
Herod
for
his
massacre
of
the
innocents
;
and
if
he
hated
one
thing
more
than
another
,
it
was
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
could
hardly
be
said
to
hate
anything
in
particular
,
because
he
disliked
everything
in
general
;
but
perhaps
his
greatest
antipathies
were
cabs
,
old
women
,
doors
that
would
not
shut
,
musical
amateurs
,
and
omnibus
cads
.
 
<EOS>
He
subscribed
to
the
"
Society
for
the
Suppression
of
Vice
"
for
the
pleasure
of
putting
a
stop
to
any
harmless
amusements
;
and
he
contributed
largely
towards
the
support
of
two
itinerant
methodist
parsons
,
in
the
amiable
hope
that
if
circumstances
rendered
any
people
happy
in
this
world
,
they
might
perchance
be
rendered
miserable
by
fears
for
the
next
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dumps
had
a
nephew
who
had
been
married
about
a
year
,
and
who
was
somewhat
of
a
favourite
with
his
uncle
,
because
he
was
an
admirable
subject
to
exercise
his
misery
-
creating
powers
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Charles
Kitterbell
was
a
small
,
sharp
,
spare
man
,
with
a
very
large
head
,
and
a
broad
,
good
-
humoured
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
like
a
faded
giant
,
with
the
head
and
face
partially
restored
;
and
he
had
a
cast
in
his
eye
which
rendered
it
quite
impossible
for
any
one
with
whom
he
conversed
to
know
where
he
was
looking
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
appeared
fixed
on
the
wall
,
and
he
was
staring
you
out
of
countenance
;
in
short
,
there
was
no
catching
his
eye
,
and
perhaps
it
is
a
merciful
dispensation
of
Providence
that
such
eyes
are
not
catching
.
 
<EOS>
In
addition
to
these
characteristics
,
it
may
be
added
that
Mr
Charles
Kitterbell
was
one
of
the
most
credulous
and
matter
-
of
-
fact
little
personages
that
ever
took
TO
himself
a
wife
,
and
FOR
himself
a
house
in
Great
Russell
-
street
,
Bedford
-
square
.
<EOS>
(
Uncle
Dumps
always
dropped
the
"
Bedford
-
square
,
"
and
inserted
in
lieu
thereof
the
dreadful
words
"
Tottenham
-
court
-
road
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
but
,
uncle
,
"
pon
my
life
<EOS>
you
must
---
you
must
promise
to
be
godfather
,
"
said
Mr
Kitterbell
,
as
he
sat
in
conversation
with
his
respected
relative
one
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
,
indeed
I
can
not
,
"
returned
Dumps
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
Jemima
will
think
it
very
unkind
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
very
little
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
the
trouble
,
"
rejoined
the
most
unhappy
man
in
existence
,
"
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
that
;
but
my
nerves
are
in
that
state
<EOS>
---
I
can
not
go
through
the
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
I
do
n't
like
going
out
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
,
Charles
,
do
n't
fidget
with
that
stool
so
;
you
'll
drive
me
mad
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Kitterbell
,
quite
regardless
of
his
uncle
's
nerves
,
had
occupied
himself
for
some
ten
minutes
in
describing
a
circle
on
the
floor
with
one
leg
of
the
office
-
stool
on
which
he
was
seated
,
keeping
the
other
three
up
in
the
air
,
and
holding
fast
on
by
the
desk
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
uncle
,
"
said
Kitterbell
,
quite
abashed
,
suddenly
releasing
his
hold
of
the
desk
,
and
bringing
the
three
wandering
legs
back
to
the
floor
,
with
a
force
sufficient
to
drive
them
through
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
come
,
do
n't
refuse
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
's
a
boy
,
you
know
,
we
must
have
two
godfathers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
IF
it
's
a
boy
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dumps
;
<EOS>
"
why
ca
n't
you
say
at
once
whether
it
IS
a
boy
or
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
happy
to
tell
you
,
but
it
's
impossible
I
can
undertake
to
say
whether
it
's
a
girl
or
a
boy
,
if
the
child
is
n't
born
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
born
yet
!
"
echoed
Dumps
,
with
a
gleam
of
hope
lighting
up
his
lugubrious
visage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
well
,
it
MAY
be
a
girl
,
and
then
you
wo
n't
want
me
;
or
if
it
is
a
boy
,
it
MAY
die
before
it
is
christened
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
the
father
that
expected
to
be
,
looking
very
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
acquiesced
Dumps
,
evidently
pleased
with
the
subject
.
<EOS>
He
was
beginning
to
get
happy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
but
distressing
cases
frequently
occur
during
the
first
two
or
three
days
of
a
child
's
life
;
fits
,
I
am
told
,
are
exceedingly
common
,
and
alarming
convulsions
are
almost
matters
of
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
,
uncle
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
little
Kitterbell
,
gasping
for
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
my
landlady
was
confined
---
<EOS>
let
me
see
---
last
Tuesday
:
 
an
uncommonly
fine
boy
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
night
the
nurse
was
sitting
with
him
upon
her
knee
before
the
fire
,
and
he
was
as
well
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
he
became
black
in
the
face
,
and
alarmingly
spasmodic
.
 
<EOS>
The
medical
man
was
instantly
sent
for
,
and
every
remedy
was
tried
,
but
---
"
   
"
How
frightful
!
<EOS>
"
interrupted
the
horror
-
stricken
Kitterbell
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
child
died
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
your
child
MAY
not
die
;
and
if
it
should
be
a
boy
,
and
should
LIVE
to
be
christened
<EOS>
,
why
I
suppose
I
must
be
one
of
the
sponsors
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Dumps
was
evidently
good
-
natured
on
the
faith
of
his
anticipations
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
uncle
,
"
said
his
agitated
nephew
,
grasping
his
hand
as
warmly
as
if
he
had
done
him
some
essential
service
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
had
better
not
tell
Mrs
K
what
you
have
mentioned
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
if
she
's
low
-
spirited
,
perhaps
you
had
better
not
mention
the
melancholy
case
to
her
,
"
returned
Dumps
,
who
of
course
had
invented
the
whole
story
;
"
though
perhaps
it
would
be
but
doing
your
duty
as
a

to
prepare
her
for
the
WORST
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
day
or
two
afterwards
,
as
Dumps
was
perusing
a
morning
paper
at
the
chop
-
house
which
he
regularly
frequented
,
the
following
-
paragraph
met
his
eyes
:
<EOS>
---
   
"
BIRTHS
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
On
Saturday
,
the
18th
inst
.
,
in
Great
Russell
-
street
,
the
lady
of
Charles
Kitterbell
,
Esq
,
of
a
son
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS
a
boy
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
dashing
down
the
paper
,
to
the

of
the
waiters
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
IS
a
boy
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
speedily
regained
his
composure
as
his
eye
rested
on
a
paragraph
quoting
the
number
of
infant
deaths
from
the
bills
of
mortality
.
   
<EOS>
Six
weeks
passed
away
,
and
as
no
communication
had
been
received
from
the
Kitterbells
,
Dumps
was
beginning
to
flatter
himself
that
the
child
was
dead
,
when
the
following
note
painfully
resolved
his
doubts
:
---
   
"
GREAT
RUSSELL
-
STREET
,
MONDAY
MORNING
.
   
<EOS>
DEAR
UNCLE
,
---
You
will
be
delighted
to
hear
that
my
dear
Jemima
has
left
her
room
,
and
that
your
future
godson
is
getting
on
capitally
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
thin
at
first
,
but
he
is
getting
much
larger
,
and
nurse
says
he
is
filling
out
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
cries
a
good
deal
,
and
is
a
very
singular
colour
,
which
made
Jemima
and
me
rather
uncomfortable
;
but
as
nurse
says
it
's
natural
,
and
as
of
course
we
know
nothing
about
these
things
yet
,
we
are
quite
satisfied
with
what
nurse
says
.
 
<EOS>
We
think
he
will
be
a
sharp
child
;
and
nurse
says
she
's
sure
he
will
,
because
he
never
goes
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
readily
believe
that
we
are
all
very
happy
,
only
we
're
a
little
worn
out
for
want
of
rest
,
as
he
keeps

awake
all
night
;
but
this
we
must
expect
,
nurse
says
,
for
the
first
six
or
eight
months
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
vaccinated
,
but
in
consequence
of
the
operation
being
rather
awkwardly
performed
,
some
small

of
glass
were
introduced
into
the
arm
with
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
this
may
in
some
degree
account
for
his
being
rather
fractious
;
at
least
,
so
nurse
says
.
 
<EOS>
We
propose
to
have
him
christened
at
twelve

on
Friday
,
at
Saint
George
's
church
,
in
Hart
-

,

name
of
Frederick
Charles
William
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
be
later
than
a
quarter
before
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
very
few
friends
in
the
evening
,
when
of
course
we
shall
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
to
say
that
the
dear
boy
appears
rather
restless
and
uneasy
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
the
cause
,
I
fear
,
is
fever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Believe
me
,
dear
Uncle
,
"
Yours

,
"
CHARLES
KITTERBELL
.
   
<EOS>
"
PS
.
<EOS>
---
I
open
this
note
to
say
that
we
have
just
discovered
the
cause
of
little
Frederick
's
restlessness
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
fever
,
as
I
apprehended
,
but
a
small
pin
,
which
nurse
accidentally
stuck
in
his
leg
yesterday
evening
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
taken
it
out
,
and
he
appears
more
composed
,
though
he
still
sobs
a
good
deal
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
almost
unnecessary
to
say
that
the
perusal
of
the
above
interesting
statement
was
no
great
relief
to
the
mind
of
the
hypochondriacal
Dumps
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
recede
,
however
,
and
so
he
put
the
best
face
---
<EOS>
that
is
to
say
,
an
uncommonly
miserable
one
---
upon
the
matter
;
and
purchased
a
handsome
silver
mug
for
the
infant
Kitterbell
,
upon
which
he
ordered
the
initials
"
F*C*W*K
,
"
with
the
customary
untrained
grape
-
vine
-
looking
flourishes
,
and
a
large
full
stop
,
to
be
engraved
forthwith
.
   
<EOS>
Monday
was
a
fine
day
<EOS>
,
Tuesday
was
delightful
,
Wednesday
was
equal
to
either
,
and
Thursday
was
finer
than
ever
;
four
successive
fine
days
in
London
!
 
<EOS>
Hackney
-
coachmen
became
revolutionary
,
and
crossing
-
sweepers
began
to
doubt
the
existence
of
a
First
Cause
.
<EOS>
The
MORNING
HERALD
informed
its
readers
that
an
old
woman
in
Camden
Town
had
been
heard
to
say
that
the
fineness
of
the
season
was
"
unprecedented
in
the
memory
of
the
oldest
inhabitant
;
"
and
Islington
clerks
,
with
large
families
and
small
salaries
,
left
off
their
black
gaiters
,
disdained
to
carry
their
once
green
cotton
umbrellas
,
and
walked
to
town
in
the
conscious
pride
of
white
stockings
and
cleanly
brushed
Bluchers
.
 
<EOS>
Dumps
beheld
all
this
with
an
eye
of
supreme
contempt
---
his
triumph
was
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
if
it
had
been
fine
for
four
weeks
instead
of
four
days
,
it
would
rain
when
he
went
out
;
he
was
lugubriously
happy
in
the
conviction
that
Friday
would
be
a
wretched
day
---
and
so
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
how
it
would
be
,
"
said
Dumps
,
as
he
turned
round
opposite
the
Mansion
-
house
at
half
-
past
eleven
o'clock
on
the
Friday
morning
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
how
it
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
concerned
,
and
that
's
enough
;
"
---
and
certainly
the
appearance
of
the
day
was
sufficient
to
depress
the
spirits
of
a
much
more
buoyant
-
hearted
individual
than
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
rained
,
without
a
moment
's
cessation
,
since
eight
o'clock
;
everybody
that
passed
up
Cheapside
,
and
down
Cheapside
,
looked
wet
,
cold
,
and
dirty
.
 
<EOS>
All
sorts
of
forgotten
and
long
-
concealed
umbrellas
had
been
put
into
requisition
.
 
<EOS>
Cabs
whisked
about
,
with
the
"
fare
"
as
carefully
boxed
up
behind
two
glazed
calico
curtains
as
any
mysterious
picture
in
any
one
of
Mrs
Radcliffe
's
castles
;
omnibus
horses
smoked
like
steam
-
engines
;
nobody
thought
of
"
standing
up
"
under
doorways
or
arches
;
they
were
painfully
convinced
it
was
a
hopeless
case
;
and
so
everybody
went
hastily
along
,
jumbling
and
jostling
,
and
swearing
and
perspiring
,
and
slipping
about
,
like
amateur
skaters
behind
wooden
chairs
on
the
Serpentine
on
a
frosty
Sunday
.
   
<EOS>
Dumps
paused
;
he
could
not
think
of
walking
,
being
rather
smart
for
the
christening
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
took
a
cab
he
was
sure
to
be
spilt
,
and
a
hackney
-
coach
was
too
expensive
for
his
economical
ideas
.
 
<EOS>
An
omnibus
was
waiting
at
the
opposite
corner
---
it
was
a
desperate
case
---
he
had
never
heard
of
an
omnibus
upsetting
or
running
away
,
and
if
the
cad
did
knock
him
down
,
he
could
"
pull
him
up
"
in
return
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
young
gentleman
who
officiated
as
"
cad
"
to
the
"
Lads
of
the
Village
,
"
which
was
the
name
of
the
machine
just
noticed
.
 
<EOS>
Dumps
crossed
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
vay
,
sir
!
"
shouted
the
driver
of
the
"
Hark
-
away
,
"
pulling
up
his
vehicle
immediately
across
the
door
of
the
opposition
---
"
This
vay
,
sir
<EOS>
---
he
's
full
.
"
 
<EOS>
Dumps
hesitated
,
<EOS>
whereupon
the
"
Lads
of
the
Village
"
commenced
pouring
out

of
abuse
against
the
"
Hark
-
away
;
"
but
the

of
the
"
Admiral
Napier
"

the

in
a
most

,
for
all

,
by
seizing

round

,
and
thrusting
him
into
the
middle

his
vehicle
which
had
just
come
up
and
only
wanted
the
sixteenth
inside
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
right
,
"
said
the
"
Admiral
,
"
and
off

thing

,
like

at

,
with

inside
,

,
and

about
with

,

,

,
like

"
Jack
-

-
the

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For

,

?
"

of

,

for

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Anywhere

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
the
BOX
would

,
"
suggested
a

lawyer
's

,
in

,

.
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

;
I

.
"

<EOS>
hollo

:
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

:

,

,

<EOS>
Everything

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

(

mother
,
accepting
Dumps
's
proffered
arm
;
and
the
little
party
entered
the
hackney
-
coach
that
was
to
take
them
to
the
church
;
Dumps
amusing
Mrs
Kitterbell
by
expatiating
largely
on
the
danger
of
measles
,
thrush
,
teeth
-
cutting
,
and
other
interesting
diseases
to
which
children
are
subject
.
   
<EOS>
The
ceremony
(
which
occupied
about
five
minutes
)
passed
off
without
anything
particular
occurring
.
 
<EOS>
The
clergyman
had
to
dine
some
distance
from
town
,
and
had
two
churchings
,
three
christenings
,
and
a
funeral
to
perform
in
something
less
than
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
The
godfathers
and
godmother
,
therefore
,
promised
to
renounce
the
devil
and
all
his
works
---
"
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
"
---
as
little
Kitterbell
said
---
"
in
less
than
no
time
;
"
and
with
the
exception
of
Dumps
nearly
letting
the
child
fall
into
the
font
when
he
handed
it
to
the
clergyman
,
the
whole
affair
went
off
in
the
usual
business
-
like
and
matter
-
of
-
course
manner
,
and
Dumps
re
-
entered
the
Bank
-
gates
at
two
o'clock
with
a
heavy
heart
,
and
the
painful
conviction
that
he
was
regularly
booked
for
an
evening
party
.
   
<EOS>
Evening
came
---
and
so
did
Dumps
's
pumps
,
black
silk
stockings
,
and
white
cravat
which
he
had
ordered
to
be
forwarded
,
per
boy
,
from
Pentonville
.
 
<EOS>
The
depressed
godfather
dressed
himself
at
a
friend
's
counting
-
house
,
from
whence
,
with
his
spirits
fifty
degrees
below
proof
,
he
sallied
forth
---
as
the
weather
had
cleared
up
,
and
the
evening
was
tolerably
fine
---
to
walk
to
Great
Russell
-
street
.
<EOS>
Slowly
he
paced
up
Cheapside
,
Newgate
-
street
,
down
Snow
-
hill
,
and
up
Holborn
ditto
,
looking
as
grim
as
the
figure
-
head
of
a
man
-
of
-
war
,
and
finding
out
fresh
causes
of
misery
at
every
step
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
crossing
the
corner
of
Hatton
-
garden
,
a
man
apparently
intoxicated
,
rushed
against
him
,
and
would
have
knocked
him
down
,
had
he
not
been
providentially
caught
by
a
very
genteel
young
man
,
who
happened
to
be
close
to
him
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
shock
so
disarranged
Dumps
's
nerves
,
as
well
as
his
dress
,
that
he
could
hardly
stand
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
took
his
arm
,
and
in
the
kindest
manner
walked
with
him
as
far
as
Furnival
's
Inn
.
 
<EOS>
Dumps
,
for
about
the
first
time
in
his
life
,
felt
grateful
and
polite
;
and
he
and
the
gentlemanly
-
looking
young
man
parted
with
mutual
expressions
of
good
will
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
at
least
some
well
-
disposed
men
in
the
world
,
"
ruminated
the
misanthropical
Dumps
,
as
he
proceeded
towards
his
destination
.
   
<EOS>
Rat
---
tat
---
ta
-
ra
-
ra
-
ra
-
ra
-
rat
---
knocked
a
hackney
-
coachman
at
Kitterbell
's
door
,
in
imitation
of
a
gentleman
's
servant
,
just
as
Dumps
reached
it
;
and
out
came
an
old
lady
in
a
large
toque
,
and
an
old
gentleman
in
a
blue
coat
,
and
three
female
copies
of
the
old
lady
in
pink
dresses
,
and
shoes
to
match
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
large
party
,
"
sighed
the
unhappy
godfather
,
wiping
the
perspiration
from
his
forehead
,
and
leaning
against
the
area
-
railings
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
before
the
miserable
man
could
muster
up
courage
to
knock
at
the
door
,
and
when
he
did
,
the
smart
appearance
of
a
neighbouring
greengrocer
(
who
had
been
hired
to
wait
for
seven
and
sixpence
,
and
whose
calves
alone
were
worth
double
the
money
)
,
the
lamp
in
the
passage
,
and
the
Venus
on
the
landing
,
<EOS>
added
to
the
hum
of
many
voices
,
and
the
sound
of
a
harp
and
two
violins
,
painfully
convinced
him
that
his
surmises
were
but
too
well
founded
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
"
said
little
Kitterbell
,
in
a
greater
bustle
than
ever
,
bolting
out
of
the
little
back
parlour
with
a
cork
-
screw
in
his
hand
,
and
various
particles
of
sawdust
,
looking
like
so
many
inverted
commas
,
on
his
inexpressibles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
God
!
<EOS>
"
said
Dumps
,
turning
into
the
aforesaid
parlour
to
put
his
shoes
on
,
which
he
had
brought
in
his
coat
-
pocket
,
and
still
more
appalled
by
the
sight
of
seven
fresh
-
drawn
corks
,
and
a
corresponding
number
of
decanters
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
many
people
are
there
up
-
stairs
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not
above
thirty
-
five
.
 
<EOS>
We
've
had
the
carpet
taken
up
in
the
back
drawing
-
room
,
and
the
piano
and
the
card
-
tables
are
in
the
front
.
 
<EOS>
Jemima
thought
we
'd
better
have
a
regular
sit
-
down
supper
in
the
front
parlour
,
because
of
the
speechifying
,
and
all
that
.
<EOS>
But
,
Lord
!
<EOS>
uncle
,
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
continued
the
excited
little
man
,
as
Dumps
stood
with
one
shoe
on
,
rummaging
his
pockets
with
the
most
frightful
distortion
of
visage
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
lost
?
<EOS>
Your
pocket
-
book
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
Dumps
,
diving
first
into
one
pocket
and
then
into
the
other
,
and
speaking
in
a
voice
like
Desdemona
with
the
pillow
over
her
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
card
-
case
?
<EOS>
snuff
-
box
?
<EOS>
the
key
of
your
lodgings
?
"
<EOS>
continued
Kitterbell
,
pouring
question
on
question
with
the
rapidity
of
lightning
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
no
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Dumps
,
still
diving
eagerly
into
his
empty
pockets
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
---
not
---
the
MUG
you
spoke
of
this
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
the
MUG
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Dumps
,
sinking
into
a
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
COULD
you
have
done
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Kitterbell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
you
brought
it
out
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
yes
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
all
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dumps
,
starting
up
as
the
idea
flashed
across
his
mind
;
"
miserable
dog
that
I
am
---
<EOS>
I
was
born
to
suffer
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
all
:
 
<EOS>
it
was
the
gentlemanly
-
looking
young
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dumps
!
"
shouted
the
greengrocer
in
a
stentorian
voice
,
as
he
ushered
the
somewhat
recovered
godfather
into
the
drawing
-
room
half
an
hour
after
the
above
declaration
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dumps
!
"
<EOS>
---
everybody
looked
at
the
door
,
and
in
came
Dumps
,
feeling
about
as
much
out
of
place
as
a
salmon
might
be
supposed
to
be
on
a
gravel
-
walk
.
   
<EOS>
"
Happy
to
see
you
again
,
"
said
Mrs
Kitterbell
,
quite
unconscious
of
the
unfortunate
man
's
confusion
and
misery
;
"
you
must
allow
me
to
introduce
you
to
a
few
of
our
friends
:
---
my
mamma
,
Mr
Dumps
---
my
papa
and
sisters
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Dumps
seized
the
hand
of
the
mother
as
warmly
as
if
she
was
his
own
parent
,
bowed
TO
the
young
ladies
,
and
AGAINST
a
gentleman
behind
him
,
and
took
no
notice
whatever
of
the
father
,
who
had
been
bowing
incessantly
for
three
minutes
and
a
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Uncle
,
"
said
little
Kitterbell
,
after
Dumps
had
been
introduced
to
a
select
dozen
or
two
,
"
you
must
let
me
lead
you
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
,
to
introduce
you
to
my
friend
Danton
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
splendid
fellow
!
<EOS>
---
I
'm
sure
you
'll
like
him
---
this
way
,
"
---
Dumps
followed
as
tractably
as
a
tame
bear
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Danton
was
a
young
man
of
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
,
with
a
considerable
stock
of
impudence
,
and
a
very
small
share
of
ideas
:
he
was
a
great
favourite
,
especially
with
young
ladies
of
from
sixteen
to
twenty
-
six
years
of
age
,
both
inclusive
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
imitate
the
French
-
horn
to
admiration
,
sang
comic
songs
most
inimitably
,
and
had
the
most
insinuating
way
of
saying
impertinent
nothings
to
his
doting
female
admirers
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
acquired
,
somehow
or
other
,
the
reputation
of
being
a
great
wit
,
and
,
accordingly
,
whenever
he
opened
his
mouth
,
everybody
who
knew
him
laughed
very
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
The
introduction
took
place
in
due
form
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Danton
bowed
,
and
twirled
a
lady
's
handkerchief
,
which
he
held
in
his
hand
,
in
a
most
comic
way
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
warm
,
"
said
Dumps
,
feeling
it
necessary
to
say
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
warmer
yesterday
,
"
returned
the
brilliant
Mr
Danton
.
<EOS>
---
A
general
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
great
pleasure
in
congratulating
you
on
your
first
appearance
in
the
character
of
a
father
,
sir
,
"
he
continued
,
addressing
Dumps
---
"
godfather
,
I
mean
.
"
<EOS>
---
The
young
ladies
were
convulsed
,
and
the
gentlemen
in
ecstasies
.
   
<EOS>
A
general
hum
of
admiration
interrupted
the
conversation
,
and
announced
the
entrance
of
nurse
with
the
baby
.
 
<EOS>
An
universal
rush
of
the
young
ladies
immediately
took
place
.
 
<EOS>
(
Girls
are
always
SO
fond
of
babies
in
company
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
dear
!
"
said
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
sweet
!
<EOS>
"
cried
another
,
in
a
low
tone
of
the
most
enthusiastic
admiration
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heavenly
!
"
added
a
third
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
dear
little
arms
!
"
said
a
fourth
,
holding
up
an
arm
and
fist
about
the
size
and
shape
of
the
leg
of
a
fowl
<EOS>
cleanly
picked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
!
"
---
said
a
little
coquette
with
a
large
bustle
,
who
looked
like
a
French
lithograph
,
appealing
to
a
gentleman
in
three
waistcoats
---
"
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
in
my
life
,
"
returned
her
admirer
,
pulling
up
his
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
DO
let
me
take
it
,
nurse
,
"
cried
another
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
love
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
it
open
its
eyes
,
nurse
?
"
inquired
another
,
affecting
the
utmost
innocence
.
<EOS>
---
Suffice
it
to
say
,
that
the
single
ladies
unanimously
voted
him
an
angel
,
and
that
the
married
ones
,
NEM
CON
,
agreed
that
he
was
decidedly
the
finest
baby
they
had
ever
beheld
---
except
their
own
.
   
<EOS>
The
quadrilles
were
resumed
with
great
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Danton
was
universally
admitted
to
be
beyond
himself
;
several
young
ladies
enchanted
the
company
and
gained
admirers
by
singing
<EOS>
"
We
met
"
---
<EOS>
"
I
saw
her
at
the
Fancy
Fair
"
---
and
other
equally
sentimental
and
interesting
ballads
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
young
men
,
"
as
Mrs
Kitterbell
said
,
"
made
themselves
very
agreeable
;
"
the
girls
did
not
lose
their
opportunity
;
and
the
evening
promised
to
go
off
excellently
.
 
<EOS>
Dumps
did
n't
mind
it
:
 
<EOS>
he
had
devised
a
plan
for
himself
---
a
little
bit
of
fun
in
his
own
way
---
and
he
was
almost
happy
!
 
<EOS>
He
played
a
rubber
and
lost
every
point
<EOS>
Mr
Danton
said
he
could
not
have
lost
every
point
,
because
he
made
a
point
of
losing
:
 
everybody
laughed
tremendously
.
 
<EOS>
Dumps
retorted
with
a
better
joke
,
and
nobody
smiled
,
with
the
exception
of
the
host
,
who
seemed
to
consider
it
his
duty
to
laugh
till
he
was
black
in
the
face
,
at
everything
.
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
drawback
---
the
musicians
did
not
play
with
quite
as
much
spirit
as
could
have
been
wished
.
 
<EOS>
The
cause
,
however
,
was
satisfactorily
explained
;
for
it
appeared
,
on
the
testimony
of
a
gentleman
who
had
come
up
from
Gravesend
in
the
afternoon
,
that
they
had
been
engaged
on
board
a
steamer
all
day
,
and
had
played
almost
without
cessation
all
the
way
to
Gravesend
,
and
all
the
way
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
"
sit
-
down
supper
"
was
excellent
;
there
were
four
barley
-
sugar
temples
on
the
table
,
which
would
have
looked
beautiful
if
they
had
not
melted
away
when
the
supper
began
;
and
a
water
-
mill
,
whose
only
fault
was
that
instead
of
going
round
,
it
ran
over
the
table
-
cloth
.
<EOS>
Then
there
were
fowls
,
and
tongue
,
and
trifle
,
and
sweets
,
and
lobster
salad
,
and
potted
beef
---
and
everything
.
 
<EOS>
And
little
Kitterbell
kept
calling
out
for
clean
plates
,
and
<EOS>
the
clean
plates
did
not
come
:
 
and
<EOS>
then
the
gentlemen
who
wanted
the
plates
said
they
did
n't
mind
,
they
'd
take
a
lady
's
;
and
then
Mrs
Kitterbell
applauded
their
gallantry
,
and
the
greengrocer
ran
about
till
he
thought
his
seven
and
sixpence
was
very
hardly
earned
;
and
the
young
ladies
did
n't
eat
much
for
fear
it
should
n't
look
romantic
,
and
the
married
ladies
eat
as
much
as
possible
,
for
fear
they
should
n't
have
enough
;
and
a
great
deal
of
wine
was
drunk
,
and
everybody
talked
and
laughed
considerably
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
hush
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

(

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
I
"

"

<EOS>
order

Order

"

<EOS>
"
Danton

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
He

,

,

and

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
drunkard
's
death
<EOS>
We
will
be
bold
to
say
,
that
there
is
scarcely
a
man
in
the
constant
habit
of
walking
,
day

,
through
any
of
the
crowded

of
London
,
who
can
not
recollect
among
the

whom
he
"
knows
by
sight
,
"
to
use
a
familiar
phrase
,
some
being
of
abject
and
wretched
appearance
whom
he
remembers
to
have
seen
in
a
very
different
condition
,
whom
he
has
observed
sinking
lower
and
lower
,
by
almost

,
and
the
shabbiness
and
utter
destitution
of
whose
appearance
,
at
last
,
strike
forcibly
and

upon

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
any
man
who
has
mixed
much
with
society
,
or
whose
avocations
have
caused
him
to
mingle
,
at
one

,
with
a

,
who

the

some
shabby
,

,

,
who

now
in

of
disease
and

,
with
a
respectable

,
or

,
or
a
man
following
some

,
with
good

,
and
decent

?
<EOS>
---
or

any

call

their
QUONDAM

,
some

,
who

---
from

,
and
who
preserves

from

,
nobody

?
 
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
such
cases
are
of
too
frequent
occurrence
to
be
rare
items
in
any
man
's
experience
;
and
but
too
often
arise
from
one
cause
---

---
that
fierce
rage
for
the
slow
,
sure
poison
,
that
oversteps
every
other

;
that
casts
aside
wife
,
children
,
friends
,
happiness
,
and
station
;
and
hurries
its

madly
on
to

and

.
   
<EOS>
Some
of
these
men
have
been
impelled
,
by
misfortune
and

,
to
the
vice
that
has
degraded

.
 
<EOS>
The
ruin
of
worldly
expectations
,
the
death
of
those
they
loved
,
the
sorrow
that
slowly
consumes
,
but

,
has
driven

;
and
they
present
the
hideous

of
madmen
,
slowly

by

own

.
<EOS>
But
by
far
the
greater
part
have
wilfully
,
and
with
open

,
plunged
into
the
gulf
from
which
the
man
who
once
enters
it
never
rises
more
,
but
into
which
he
sinks
deeper
and
deeper

,
until
recovery
is
hopeless
.
   
<EOS>
Such
a
man
as
this
once
stood
by
the
bedside
of
his
dying
wife
,
while
his
children
knelt
around
,
and
mingled

.
 
<EOS>
The
room
was
scantily
and

;
and
it
needed
but

the
pale

was
fast

away
,
to
know

grief
,
and

,

,
had
been
busy

heart
for
many

.
 
<EOS>
An

,

,

of
the
dying

---
her
daughter
---

.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not

that
the
was
face
turned
;
it

that

they
pressed

husband
's

;
the

so
soon

be
closed
in

rested
on

,
and
the
man
shook

.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
was
slovenly
and

,
his
face

,
his
eyes
bloodshot
and

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
summoned
from
some
wild
debauch
to
the
bed
of
sorrow
and
death
.
   
<EOS>
A
shaded
lamp
by
the
bed
-
side
cast
a
dim
light
on
the
figures
around
,
and
left
the
remainder

the
room
in
thick
,

.
<EOS>
The
silence
of
night
prevailed
without
the
house
,
and
the
stillness
of
death
was
in
the
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
A
watch
hung
over
the
mantel
-
shelf
;
its
low
ticking
was
the
only
sound
that
broke
the
profound
quiet
,
but
it
was
a
solemn
one
,
<EOS>
for
well
they
knew
,
who
heard
it
,
that
before
it
had
recorded
the
passing
of
another
hour
,
it
would
beat
the
knell
of
a
departed
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
dreadful
thing
to
wait
and
watch
for
the
approach
of
death
;
to
know
that
hope
is
gone
,
and
recovery
impossible
;
and
to
sit
and
count
the
dreary
hours
through
long
,
long
nights
---
<EOS>
such
nights
as
only
watchers
by
the
bed
of
sickness
know
.
 
<EOS>
It
chills
the
blood
to
hear
the
dearest
secrets
of
the
heart
---
the
pent
-
up
,
hidden
secrets
of
many
years
---
poured
forth
by
the
unconscious
,
helpless
being
before
you
;
and
to
think
how
little
the
reserve
and
cunning
of
a
whole
life
will
avail
,
when
fever
and
delirium
tear
off
the
mask
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
tales
have
been
told
in
the
wanderings
of
dying
men
;
tales
so
full
of
guilt
and
crime
,
that
those
who
stood
by
the
sick
person
's
couch
have
fled
in
horror
and
affright
,
lest
they
should
be
scared
to
madness
by
what
they
heard
and
saw
;
and
many
a
wretch
has
died
alone
,
raving
of
deeds
the
very
name
of
which
has
driven
the
boldest
man
away
.
   
<EOS>
But
no
such
ravings
were
to
be
heard
at
the
bed
-
side
by
which
the
children
knelt
.
 
<EOS>
Their
half
-
stifled
sobs
and
moaning
alone
broke
the
silence
of
the
lonely
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
at
last
the
mother
's
grasp
relaxed
,
and
,
turning
one
look
from
the
children
to
the
father
,
she
vainly
strove
to
speak
,
and
fell
backward
on
the
pillow
<EOS>
,
all
was
so
calm
and
tranquil
that
she
seemed
to
sink
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
They
leant
over
her
;
they
called
upon
her
name
,
softly
at
first
,
and
then
in
the
loud
and
piercing
tones
of
desperation
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
reply
.
 
<EOS>
They
listened
for
her
breath
,
but
no
sound
came
.
 
<EOS>
They
felt
for
the
palpitation
of
the
heart
,
but
no
faint
throb
responded
to
the
touch
.
 
<EOS>
That
heart
was
broken
,
and
she
was
dead
!
   
<EOS>
The
husband
sunk
into
a
chair
by
the
bed
-
side
,
and
clasped
his
hands
upon
his
burning
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
He
gazed
from
child
to
child
,
but
when
a
weeping
eye
met
his
,
he
quailed
beneath
its
look
.
 
<EOS>
No
word
of
comfort
was
whispered
in
his
ear
,
no
look
of
kindness
lighted
on
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
All
shrunk
from
and
avoided
him
;
and
when
at
last
he
staggered
from
the
room
,
no
one
sought
to
follow
or
console
the
widower
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
had
been
when
many
a
friend
would
have
crowded
round
him
in
his
affliction
,
and
many
a
heartfelt
condolence
would
have
met
him
in
his
grief
.
 
<EOS>
Where
were
they
now
?
 
<EOS>
One
by
one
,
friends
,
relations
,
the
commonest
acquaintance
even
,
had
fallen
off
from
and
deserted
the
drunkard
.
 
<EOS>
His
wife
alone
had
clung
to
him
in
good
and
evil
,
in
sickness
and
poverty
,
and
how
had
he
rewarded
her
?
 
<EOS>
He
had
reeled
from
the
tavern
to
her
bed
-
side
in
time
to
see
her
die
.
   
<EOS>
He
rushed
from
the
house
,
and
walked
swiftly
through
the
streets
.
<EOS>
Remorse
,
fear
,
shame
,
all
crowded
on
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Stupefied
with
drink
,
and
bewildered
with
the
scene
he
had
just
witnessed
,
he
re
-
entered
the
tavern
he
had
quitted
shortly
before
.
 
<EOS>
Glass
succeeded
glass
.
 
<EOS>
His
blood
mounted
,
and
his
brain
whirled
round
.
 
<EOS>
Death
!
<EOS>
Every
one
must
die
,
and
why
not
SHE
?
 
<EOS>
She
was
too
good
for
him
;
her
relations
had
often
told
him
so
.
 
<EOS>
Curses
on
them
!
 
<EOS>
Had
they
not
deserted
her
,
and
left
her
to
whine
away
the
time
at
home
?
 
<EOS>
Well
---
she
was
dead
,
and
happy
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
better
as
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Another
glass
---
one
more
!
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
merry
life
while
it
lasted
;
and
he
would
make
the
most
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Time
went
on
;
the
three
children
who
were
left
to
him
,
grew
up
,
and
were
children
no
longer
.
 
<EOS>
The
father
remained
the
same
---
poorer
,
shabbier
,
and
more
dissolute
-
looking
,
but
the
same
confirmed
and
irreclaimable
drunkard
.
 
<EOS>
The
boys
had
,
long
ago
,
run
wild
in
the
streets
,
and
left
him
;
the
girl
alone
remained
,
but
she
worked
hard
,
and
words
or
blows
could
always
procure
him
something
for
the
tavern
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
went
on
in
the
old
course
,
and
a
merry
life
he
led
.
   
<EOS>
One
night
,
as
early
as
ten
o'clock
---
for
the
girl
had
been
sick
for
many
days
,
and
there
was
,
consequently
,
little
to
spend
at
the
public
-
house
<EOS>
---
he
bent
his
steps
homeward
,
bethinking
himself
that
if
he
would
have
her
able
to
earn
money
,
it
would
be
as
well
to
apply
to
the
parish
surgeon
,
or
,
at
all
events
,
to
take
the
trouble
of
inquiring
what
ailed
her
,
which
he
had
not
yet
thought
it
worth
while
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wet
December
night
;
the
wind
blew
piercing
cold
,
and
the
rain
poured
heavily
down
.
 
<EOS>
He
begged
a
few
halfpence
from
a
passer
-
by
,
and
having
bought
a
small
loaf
(
for
it
was
his
interest
to
keep
the
girl
alive
,
if
he
could
)
,
he
shuffled
onwards
as
fast
as
the
wind
and
rain
would
let
him
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
back
of
Fleet
-
street
,
and
lying
between
it
and
the
water
-
side
,
are
several
mean
and
narrow
courts
,
which
form
a
portion
of
Whitefriars
:
 
<EOS>
it
was
to
one
of
these
that
he
directed
his
steps
.
   
<EOS>
The
alley
into
which
he
turned
,
might
,
for
filth
and
misery
,
have
competed
with
the
darkest
corner
of
this
ancient
sanctuary
in
its
dirtiest
and
most
lawless
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
houses
,
varying
from
two
stories
in
height
to
four
,
were
stained
with
every
indescribable
hue
that
long
exposure
to
the
weather
,
damp
,
and
rottenness
can
impart
to
tenements
composed
originally
of
the
roughest
and
coarsest
materials
.
 
<EOS>
The
windows
were
patched
with
paper
,
and
stuffed
with
the
foulest
rags
;
the
doors
were
falling
from
their
hinges
;
poles
with
lines
on
which
to
dry
clothes
,
projected
from
every
casement
,
and
sounds
of
quarrelling
or
drunkenness
issued
from
every
room
.
   
<EOS>
The
solitary
oil
lamp
in
the
centre
of
the
court
had
been
blown
out
,
either
by
the
violence
of
the
wind
or
the
act
of
some
inhabitant
who
had
excellent
reasons
for
objecting
to
his
residence
being
rendered
too
conspicuous
;
and
the
only
light
which
fell
upon
the
broken
and
uneven

,
was
derived
from
the
miserable
candles
that
here
and
there
twinkled
in
the
rooms
of
such
of
the
more
fortunate
residents
as
could
afford
to
indulge
in
so
expensive
a
luxury
.
 
<EOS>
A
gutter
ran
down
the
centre
of
the
alley
---
all
the
sluggish
odours
of
which
had
been
called
forth
by
the
rain
;
and
as
the
wind
whistled
through
the
old
houses
,
the
doors
and
shutters
creaked
upon
their
hinges
,
and
the
windows
shook
in
their
frames
,
with
a
violence
which
every
moment
seemed
to
threaten
the
destruction
of
the
whole
place
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
whom
we
have
followed
into
this
den
,
walked
on
in
the
darkness
,
sometimes
stumbling
into
the
main
gutter
,
and
at
others
into
some
branch
repositories
of
garbage
which
had
been
formed
by
the
rain
,
until
he
reached
the
last
house
in
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
,
or
rather
what
was
left
of
it
,
stood
ajar
,
for
the
convenience
of
the
numerous
lodgers
;
and
he
proceeded
to
grope

way
up
the
old
and
broken

,
to
the
attic
story
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
within
a
step
or
two
of
his
room
door
,
when
it
opened
,
and
a
girl
,
whose
miserable
and

appearance
was
only
to
be
equalled
by
that
of
the
candle
which
she
shaded
with

,
peeped

out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
you
,
father
?
"
said
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
else
should
it
be
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
man
gruffly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
trembling
at
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
little
enough
that
I
've
had
to
drink
to
-
day
,
for
there
's
no
drink
without
money
,
and
no
money
without
work
.
<EOS>
What
the
devil
's
the
matter
with
the
girl
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
well
,
father
---
not

,
"
said
the
girl
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

,
in

is

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must

somehow
,

we

.
 
<EOS>
You

go

the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
They
're
paid
for

,
damn
'em
.
 
<EOS>
What

standing
before

?
 
<EOS>
Let

,
ca

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"

,

,
"
William

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
"

"
William
;
brother

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

?
"

,

"
money
?
<EOS>
meat
?
<EOS>
drink
?
 
<EOS>
He
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Give

---
give

,
fool
<EOS>
---
I
ai
n't

.
"
 
<EOS>
He

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Sitting

,

<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fasten

,
Mary
,
"

---
"
Fasten

.
 
<EOS>
You
look
as

did
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
long

,

drove

from

;
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shelter
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

:
 
<EOS>
that
's
enough
.
 
<EOS>
If
I

I

;

.
 
<EOS>
Caught

,

I
stop
here
;
that
's
AS

.
 
<EOS>
And
there
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

,
"

:
 
<EOS>
"
John
's
gone
to

,

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
said

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
,
"

young

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
died
in
my
arms
---
shot
like
a
dog
,
by
a
gamekeeper
.
 
<EOS>
He
staggered
back
,
I
caught
him
,
and
his
blood
trickled
down
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
It
poured
out
from
his
side
like
water
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
weak
,
and
it
blinded
him
,
but
he
threw

down
on

,
on

,
and
prayed

,
that
if

,
He

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
her

boy
,
Will
,
"
he

,
"

I

,

,
that

,

I
was

young

then
,

,
I

,

her
as

.
 
<EOS>
O
Will
,
why
was
she
taken

,
and
father

?
<EOS>
"
There
's
his
dying
words
,
father
,
"
said
the
young

;
"
make

can
of

.
 
<EOS>
You
struck
him

,
in
a
drunken

,
the
morning
we
ran
away
;
and
here
's
the
end
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
wept
aloud
;
and
the
father
,
sinking
his

,
rocked

to
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
taken
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
"
I
shall
be
carried
back
into
the
country
,
and
hung

's

.
 
<EOS>
They
can
not
trace

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
For
aught
<EOS>
I
know
,
you

justice
;
but
unless
you
do
,
here
I
stop
,
until
I
can

.
"
   
<EOS>
For
two

days
,
all
three
remained
in

,
without

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

,
the
girl
was
worse

she

,
and

were

.
 
<EOS>
It

that
somebody
should

;
and
as
the
girl
was
too
weak
and

,
the
father
went
,
just

.
   
<EOS>
He
got

,

a
trifle
in

way
of
pecuniary

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

earned
sixpence
by
holding

;
and
he

homewards
with
enough

to
supply
their
most
pressing
wants
for
two

days
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
to
pass
the
public
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
He

for
an

,
walked
past
it
,
turned
back
again
,
lingered

,

.
 
<EOS>
Two

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

his

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
me

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
He
DID
drink
;
and
his
reason

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
And
in
five
minutes
more
,
the
father
had
unconsciously
yielded
up
his
own
son
into
the
hangman
's
hands
.
   
<EOS>
Slowly
and
heavily
the
time
dragged
along
,
as
the
brother
and
sister
,
in
their
miserable
hiding
-
place
,
listened
in
anxious
suspense
to
the
slightest
sound
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
a
heavy
footstep
was
heard
upon
the
stair
;
it
approached
nearer
;
it
reached
the
landing
;
and
the
father
staggered
into
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
saw
that
he
was
intoxicated
,
and
advanced
with
the
candle
in
her
hand
to
meet
him
;
she
stopped
short
,
gave
a
loud
scream
,
and
fell
senseless
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
caught
sight
of
the
shadow
of
a
man
reflected
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
rushed
in
,
and
in
another
instant
the
young
man
was
a
prisoner
,
and
handcuffed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
quietly
done
,
"
said
one
of
the
men
to
his
companion
,
"
thanks
to
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
Lift
up
the
girl
,
Tom
---
come
,
come
<EOS>
,
it
's
no
use
crying
,
young
woman
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
over
now
,
and
ca
n't
be
helped
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
man
stooped
for
an
instant
over
the
girl
,
and
then
turned
fiercely
round
upon
his
father
,
who
had
reeled
against
the
wall
,
and
was
gazing
on
the
group
with
drunken
stupidity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
,
father
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
tone
that
made
the
drunkard
's
flesh
creep
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
brother
's
blood
,
and
mine
,
is
on
your
head
:
 
<EOS>
I
never
had
kind
look
,
or
word
,
or
care
,
from
you
,
and
alive
or
dead
,
I
never
will
forgive
you
.
 
<EOS>
Die
when
you
will
,
or
how
,
I
will
be
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
as
a
dead
man
now
,
and
I
warn
you
,
father
,
that
as
surely
as
you
must
one
day
stand
before
your
Maker
,
so
surely
shall
your
children
be
there
,
hand
in
hand
,
to
cry
for
judgment
against
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
raised
his
manacled
hands
in
a
threatening
attitude
,
fixed
his
eyes
on
his
shrinking
parent
,
and
slowly
left
the
room
;
and
neither
father
nor
sister
ever
beheld
him
more
,
on
this
side
of
the
grave
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
dim
and
misty
light
of
a
winter
's
morning
penetrated
into
the
narrow
court
,
and
struggled
through
the
begrimed
window
of
the
wretched
room
,
Warden
awoke
from
his
heavy
sleep
,
and
found
himself
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
,
and
looked
round
him
;
the
old
flock
mattress
on
the
floor
was
undisturbed
;
everything
was
just
as
he
remembered
to
have
seen
it
last
:
 
<EOS>
and
there
were
no
signs
of
any
one
,
save
himself
,
having
occupied
the
room
during
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
inquired
of
the
other
lodgers
,
and
of
the
neighbours
;
but
his
daughter
had
not
been
seen
or
heard
of
.
 
<EOS>
He
rambled
through
the
streets
,
and
scrutinised
each
wretched
face
among
the
crowds
that
thronged
them
,
with
anxious
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
search
was
fruitless
,
and
he
returned
to
his
garret
when
night
came
on
,
desolate
and
weary
.
   
<EOS>
For
many
days
he
occupied
himself
in
the
same
manner
,
but
no
trace
of
his
daughter
<EOS>
did
he
meet
with
,
and
no
word
of
her
reached
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
gave
up
the
pursuit
as
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
long
thought
of
the
probability
of
her
leaving
him
,
and
endeavouring
to
gain
her
bread
in
quiet
,
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
left
him
at
last
to
starve
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
ground
his
teeth
,
and
cursed
her
!
   
<EOS>
He
begged
his
bread
from
door
to
door
.
 
<EOS>
Every
halfpenny
he
could
wring
from
the
pity
or
credulity
of
those
to
whom
he
addressed
himself
,
was
spent
in
the
old
way
.
 
<EOS>
A
year
passed
over
his
head
;
the
roof
of
a
jail
was
the
only
one
that
had
sheltered
him
for
many
months
.
 
<EOS>
He
slept
under
archways
,
and
in
brickfields
---
anywhere
,
where
there
was
some
warmth
or
shelter
from
the
cold
and
rain
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
the
last
stage
of
poverty
,
disease
,
and
houseless
want
,
he
was
a
drunkard
still
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
bitter
night
,
he
sunk
down
on
a
door
-
step
faint
and
ill
.
 
<EOS>
The
premature
decay
of
vice
and
profligacy
had
worn
him
to
the
bone
.
 
<EOS>
His
cheeks
were
hollow
and
livid
;
his
eyes
were
sunken
,
and
their
sight
was
dim
.
 
<EOS>
His
legs
trembled
beneath
his
weight
,
and
a
cold
shiver
ran
through
every
limb
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
long
-
forgotten
scenes
of
a
misspent
life
crowded
thick
and
fast
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
the
time
when
he
had
a
home
---
a
happy
,
cheerful
home
---
<EOS>
and
of
those
who
peopled
it
,
and
flocked
about
him
then
,
until
the
forms
of
his
elder
children
seemed
to
rise
from
the
grave
,
and
stand
about
him
---
so
plain
,
so
clear
,
and
so
distinct
they
were
that
he
could
touch
and
feel
them
.
 
<EOS>
Looks
that
he
had
long
forgotten
were
fixed
upon
him
once
more
;
voices
long
since
hushed
in
death
sounded
in
his
ears
like
the
music
of
village
bells
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
only
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
beat
heavily
upon
him
;
and
cold
and
hunger
were
gnawing
at
his
heart
again
.
   
<EOS>
He
rose
,
and
dragged
his
feeble
limbs
a
few
paces
further
.
 
<EOS>
The
street
was
silent
and
empty
;
the
few
passengers
who
passed
by
,
at
that
late
hour
,
hurried
quickly
on
,
and
his
tremulous
voice
was
lost
in
the
violence
of
the
storm
.
 
<EOS>
Again
that
heavy
chill
struck
through
his
frame
,
and
his
blood
seemed
to
stagnate
beneath
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
coiled
himself
up
in
a
projecting
doorway
,
and
tried
to
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
But
sleep
had
fled
from
his
dull
and
glazed
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
His
mind
wandered
strangely
,
but
he
was
awake
,
and
conscious
.
 
<EOS>
The
well
-
known
shout
of
drunken
mirth
sounded
in
his
ear
,
the
glass
was
at
his
lips
,
the
board
was
covered
with
choice
rich
food
---
they
were
before
him
:
 
<EOS>
he
could
see
them
all
,
he
had
but
to
reach
out
his
hand
,
and
take
them
---
and
,
<EOS>
though
the
illusion
was
reality
itself
,
he
knew
that
he
was
sitting
alone
in
the
deserted
street
,
watching
the
rain
-
drops
as
they
pattered
on
the
stones
;
that
death
was
coming
upon
him
by
inches
---
and
that
there
were
none
to
care
for
or
help
him
.
   
<EOS>
Suddenly
he
started
up
,
in
the
extremity
of
terror
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
heard
his
own
voice
shouting
in
the
night
air
,
he
knew
not
what
,
or
why
.
<EOS>
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
A
groan
!
<EOS>
---
another
!
 
<EOS>
His
senses
were
leaving
him
:
 
half
-
formed
and
incoherent
words
burst
from
his
lips
;
and
his
hands
sought
to
tear
and
lacerate
his
flesh
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
going
mad
,
and
he
shrieked
for
help
till
his
voice
failed
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
raised
his
head
,
and
looked
up
the
long
dismal
street
.
 
<EOS>
He
recollected
that
outcasts
like
himself
,
condemned
to
wander
day
and
night
in
those
dreadful
streets
,
had
sometimes
gone
distracted
with
their
own
loneliness
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
to
have
heard
many
years
before
that
a
homeless
wretch
had
once
been
found
in
a
solitary
corner
,
sharpening
a
rusty
knife
to
plunge
into
his
own
heart
,
preferring
death
to
that
endless
,
weary
,
wandering
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
instant
his
resolve
was
taken
,
his
limbs
received
new
life
;
he
ran
quickly
from
the
spot
,
and
paused
not
for
breath
until
he
reached
the
river
-
side
.
   
<EOS>
He
crept
softly
down
the
steep
stone
stairs
that
lead
from
the
commencement
of
Waterloo
Bridge
,
down
to
the
water
's
level
.
 
<EOS>
He
crouched
into
a
corner
,
and
held
his
breath
,
as
the
patrol
passed
.
<EOS>
Never
did
prisoner
's
heart
throb
with
the
hope
of
liberty
and
life
half
so
eagerly
as
did
that
of
the
wretched
man
at
the
prospect
of
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
watch
passed
close
to
him
,
but
he
remained
unobserved
;
and
after
waiting
till
the
sound
of
footsteps
had
died
away
in
the
distance
,
he
cautiously
descended
,
and
stood
beneath
the
gloomy
arch
that
forms
the
landing
-
place
from
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
The
tide
was
in
,
and
the
water
flowed
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
had
ceased
,
the
wind
was
lulled
,
and
all
was
,
for
the
moment
,
still
and
quiet
---
so
quiet
,
that
the
slightest
sound
on
the
opposite
bank
,
even
the
rippling
of
the
water
against
the
barges
that
were
moored
there
,
was
distinctly
audible
to
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
The
stream
stole
languidly
and
sluggishly
on
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
and
fantastic
forms
rose
to
the
surface
,
and
beckoned
him
to
approach
;
dark
gleaming
eyes
peered
from
the
water
,
and
seemed
to
mock
his
hesitation
,
while
hollow
murmurs
from
behind
,
urged
him
onwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
retreated
a
few
paces
,
took
a
short
run
,
desperate
leap
,
and
plunged
into
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
Not
five
seconds
had
passed
when
he
rose
to
the
water
's
surface
---
but
what
a
change
had
taken
place
in
that
short
time
,
in
all
his
thoughts
and
feelings
!
 
<EOS>
Life
---
life
in
any
form
,
poverty
,
misery
,
starvation
---
anything
but
death
.
 
<EOS>
He
fought
and
struggled
with
the
water
that
closed
over
his
head
,
and
screamed
in
agonies
of
terror
.
<EOS>
The
curse
of
his
own
son
rang
in
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
The
shore
---
but
one
foot
of
dry
ground
---
he
could
almost
touch
the
step
.
 
<EOS>
One
hand
's
breadth
nearer
,
and
he
was
saved
---
but
the
tide
bore
him
onward
,
under
the
dark
arches
of
the
bridge
,
and
he
sank
to
the
bottom
.
   
<EOS>
Again
he
rose
,
and
struggled
for
life
.
 
<EOS>
For
one
instant
---
for
one
brief
instant
---
the
buildings
on
the
river
's
banks
,
the
lights
on
the
bridge
through
which
the
current
had
borne
him
,
the
black
water
,
and
the
fast
-
flying
clouds
,
were
distinctly
visible
---
once
more
he
sunk
,
and
once
again
he
rose
.
 
<EOS>
Bright
flames
of
fire
shot
up
from
earth
to
heaven
,
and
reeled
before
his
eyes
,
while
the
water
thundered
in
his
ears
,
and
stunned
him
with
its
furious
roar
.
   
<EOS>
A
week
afterwards
the
body
was
washed
ashore
,
some
miles
down
the
river
,
a
swollen
and
disfigured
mass
.
 
<EOS>
Unrecognised
and
unpitied
,
it
was
borne
to
the
grave
;
and
there
it
has
long
since
mouldered
away
!
   
<EOS>
